eponym.desc: In mastocytosis (urticaria pigmentosa), sign is positive when a brown macular or a slightly papular lesion becomes a palpable wheal after being vigorously rubbed with the blunt end of an instrument such as a pen; wheal may not appear for 5-10 minutes.

eponym.name: Darier-White disease
eponym.desc: Keratosis follicularis; autosomal dominant disorder characterized by warty papules and plaques in seborrheic areas (central trunk, flexures, scalp, and forehead), palmoplantar pits, and nail abnormalities; associated with mutation in SERCA2 Ca(2+)-ATPase.

eponym.name: Darkschewitsch, nucleus of
eponym.desc: An ovoid cell group in the ventral central gray substance rostral to the oculomotor nucleus, receiving fibers from the vestibular nuclei by way of the medial longitudinal fasiculus; projections are not known, although some cross in the posterior commissure.

eponym.name: Darwin's tubercle
eponym.desc: Benign and congenital nodule, located near the superior aspect of the auricle (approximately 2/3 of the way from the bottom of the helix), described by Charles Darwin.

eponym.name: Dawson's fingers
eponym.desc: In multiple sclerosis, perivascular demyelination creating the appearance of finger projections oriented transversely on an axial scan.

eponym.name: De Garengeot's hernia
eponym.desc: Appendix in a femoral hernia sac. Compare with Amyand's hernia.

eponym.name: de Musset's sign
eponym.desc: In aortic regurgitation, head bobbing, named after 19th century French poet who had aortic insufficiency from syphilis.

eponym.name: de Quervain's tenosynovitis
eponym.desc: A stenosing tenosynovitis of the thumb extensors and abductors; pain elicited with Finkelstein's test.

eponym.name: de Quervain's thyroiditis
eponym.desc: Subacute granulomatous thyroiditis, viral etiology suspected.

eponym.name: Degos disease
eponym.desc: Malignant atrophic papulosis; multisystem lymphocytic vasculitis characterized by thrombosis primarily of cutaneous small vessels as well as small vessels in GI tract, ocular, and CNS; has characteristic porcelain white atrophic lesion.

eponym.name: Deiters's nucleus
eponym.desc: Lateral vestibular nucleus; site of termination of many vestibular nerve ascending branches.

eponym.name: Dejerine-Roussy syndrome
eponym.desc: Thalamic lesions leading to sensory loss, spontaneous pain, and hypersensitive cutaneous sensations; described in 1906.

eponym.name: Dejerine-Sottas disease
eponym.desc: Hereditary motor and sensory neuropathy III, recessive inheritance, slowly progressive demyelinating disorer, presents in infancy or childhood and progresses to cause severe disability by 30s; nerves typically enlarged.

eponym.name: Delphian nodes
eponym.desc: Lymph nodes in midline of the thyrohyoid membrane; can be involved in thyroid cancer or subacute thyroiditis.

eponym.name: Dennie's lines
eponym.desc: In atopic dermatitis, an accentuated line or fold below the margin of the lower eyelid.

eponym.name: Denonvillier's fascia
eponym.desc: Fascia that separates prostate and seminal vesicles from rectum.

eponym.name: Dent's disease
eponym.desc: X-linked syndrome characterized by renal proximal tubular dysfunction, proteinuria, hypercalciuria, nephrocalcinosis, nephrolithiasis, and rickets due to mutation in voltage-gated chloride channel.

eponym.name: Denver shunt
eponym.desc: For treating refractory ascites, peritoneovenous shunt connecting peritoneum and central venous system, compare with LeVeen shunt; Denver shunt uses valve that lies within a fluid-filled, compressible silicone chamber.

eponym.name: Denys-Drash syndrome
eponym.desc: Gonadal dysgenesis (male pseudohermaphroditism) and nephropathy leading to renal failure (nephrotic syndrome); increased risk of Wilms's tumor; dominant negative missense mutation of WT-1 gene.

eponym.name: Dercum's disease
eponym.desc: Adipositas dolorsa, condition tending to affect obese women in middle age, mostly menopausal, consisting of multiple exquisitely tender lipomas.

eponym.name: Desçemet's membrane
eponym.desc: Membrane that forms the deepest layer of the cornea and functions as thin basement membrane for endothelium; location where copper is deposited in Kayser-Fleischer rings of Wilson's disease.

eponym.name: D'Espine's sign
eponym.desc: Breath sounds louder over C7 vertebra than adjacent lung, suggests lesion in posterior mediastinum, e.g. lymphoma, tuberculosis, etc.

eponym.name: Destot's sign
eponym.desc: Scrotal hematoma suggesting pelvic fracture.

eponym.name: Deutschlander's fracture
eponym.desc: Fracture from overuse, e.g. marching.

eponym.name: Devic's disease
eponym.desc: Neuromyelitis optica; relapsing-remitting demyelinating disorder characterized by bilateral optic neuritis and transverse myelitis occurring in rapid succession. More common in Asians; distinct from multiple sclerosis.

eponym.name: Devon family syndrome
eponym.desc: Inherited condition characterized by inflammatory fibroid polyps, typically in stomach or ileum.

eponym.name: Diamond-Blackfan anemia
eponym.desc: Congenital pure red cell aplasia characterized by increased MCV, reticulocytopenia, bone marrow erythroblastopenia; can be diagnosed by increased erythrocyte adenosine deaminase; 40% associated with congenital abnormalities. Associated with RPS19 ribosomal protein mutations in some. Responds to steroids which increase erythropoietin sensitivity; 20-30% recover spontaneously. Non-responders can be treated with bone marrow transplant.

eponym.name: Dick test
eponym.desc: Injection of erythogenic toxin of Strep. pyogenes; erythematous reaction in individuals lacking antitoxin/exposure to Strep. pyognes. Used in the past to identify children susceptible to scarlet fever. See also Schultz-Charlton phenomenon.

eponym.name: Dietl's crisis
eponym.desc: Episodic renal colic and hydronephrosis caused by "kinking" of ureter due to a "floating" kidney (nephroptosis) or pressure from an artery. Historically, nephropexy was used, though no longer practiced.

eponym.name: Dieulafoy lesion
eponym.desc: An uncommon cause of massive GI bleeding from erosion of large submucosal artery into the gastric mucosa without any overlying ulceration or other obvious mucosal damage; located around 6 cm from the gastroesophageal junction.

eponym.name: DiGeorge syndrome
eponym.desc: Failure of 3rd and 4th pharyngeal pouches to differentiate into the thymus and parathyroid glands, facial abnormalities result primarily from abnormal development of the first arch components during formation of face and ears. Seen in 22q11 deletion, see also mnemonic CATCH-22 (cardiac abnormality/abnormal facies, T-cell deficit owing to thymic hypoplasia, cleft palate, and hypocalcemia).

eponym.name: DiGuglielmo's disease
eponym.desc: Acute myelogenous leukemia M6, erythroleukemia; felt to emerge from myelodysplastic state.

eponym.name: dimple sign
eponym.desc: In dermatofibroma, lateral compression with thumb and index finger produces a depression, or "dimple."

eponym.name: Disse, space of
eponym.desc: Subendothelial space in liver separating endothelial cells from underlying hepatocytes which contains hepatocyte microvilli.

eponym.name: Dix-Hallpike test
eponym.desc: For testing benign paroxysmal positional vertigo, examiner stands at the patient's right side and rotates the patient's head 45 degrees to the right to align the right posterior semicircular canal with the sagital plane of the body; the examiner moves the patient, whose eyes are open, from the seated to the supine right-ear-down position and then extends the patient's neck slightly so that the chin is pointed slightly upward. If rotational nystagmus seen, felt to be positive for BPV.

eponym.name: Dobrin's syndrome
eponym.desc: TINU syndrome (tubulointerstitial nephritis with uveitis), associated with bone marrow granulomas, first described in 1975.

eponym.name: Dock's murmur
eponym.desc: In left anterior descending artery stenosis, diastolic murmur similar to that of aortic regurgitation.

eponym.name: Doderlein's lactobacilli
eponym.desc: Lactobacillus acidophilus; metabolizes the glycogen in glycogen rich cells which are exfoliated in the vagina pre-menopause to lactic acid, resulting in a decrease in pH to 3.5-4.

eponym.name: Döhle bodies
eponym.desc: In neutrophil cytoplasm, irregularly shaped blue to gray-blue inclusions, consisting of ribosomes and/or rough ER; seen in severe bacterial infections.

eponym.name: Doi's sign
eponym.desc: Elicitation of diminished deep tendon reflexes after maximal voluntary contraction in Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome.

eponym.name: Donath-Landsteiner antibody
eponym.desc: In paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria, an antibody associated with syphilis and viral infections, directed against the P red cell erythrocyte antigen and can induce complement-mediated lysis; attacks precipitated by exposure to cold and are associated with hemoglobinemia and hemoglobinuria; chills and fever; back, leg, and abdominal pain; headache and malaise; recovery prompt; asymptomatic otherwise.

eponym.name: Donnai-Barrow syndrome
eponym.desc: Syndrome of diaphragmatic hernia, exomphalos, hypertelorism, agenesis of the corpus callosum, severe sensorineural deafness, and severe myopia.

eponym.name: Donohue syndrome
eponym.desc: Leprechaunism.

eponym.name: Donovan bodies
eponym.desc: In Calymmatobacterium granulomatis or granuloma inguinale, bodies characterized by multiple organisms filling large histiocytes.

eponym.name: Dor procedure
eponym.desc: Endoventricular circular patch plasty, a surgical procedure for treating postinfarction aneurysm where a purse string stitch is sewed around the aneurysm.

eponym.name: Dorello's canal
eponym.desc: Location where the sixth nerve penetrates the dura, an area where the nerve is liable to injury.

eponym.name: Douglas, pouch of
eponym.desc: Rectouterine pouch.

eponym.name: Down syndrome
eponym.desc: Trisomy 21 (in 95%), 1/700 births, 1% mosaics, 40% have congenital heart disease. 10-20 fold increased risk of acute leukemia, individuals older than 40 tend to develop Alzheimer's disease, abnormal immune system.

eponym.name: Dressler's beat
eponym.desc: Fusion beat seen in ventricular tachycardia.

eponym.name: Dressler's syndrome
eponym.desc: Pericarditis, possible autoimmune etiology, found to develop 2 weeks to several months after acute myocardial infarction.

eponym.name: Druckrey relationship
eponym.desc: Relationship between carcinogen dose and tumor induction time: dt^n = k where d is the dose of carcinogen, t is latency period, n is the slope of the double log plot of carcinogen dose versus induction time, and k is a constant.

eponym.name: Drummond, marginal artery of
eponym.desc: Vessel which lies along mesenteric border of colon and supplies vasa recta; arises from right and left branches of middle colic artery and left and right colic arteries; also supplies collateral connection between superior and inferior mesenteric arteries.

eponym.name: Duane's syndrome
eponym.desc: Form of strabismus, congenital absence of cranial nerve VI, resulting in impaired abduction and/or adduction and eyeball retraction and narrowing of palpebral fissure during adduction of affected eye.

eponym.name: Dubin-Johnson syndrome
eponym.desc: Benign autosomal recessive condition of conjugated hyperbilirubinemia from defect in transport of bilirubin and other organic anions across the canaliculus; other liver function tests normal; accumulation of dark pigment in liver lysosomes; due to mutations in ABCC2 (canalicular multispecific organic anion transporter).

eponym.name: Dubowitz syndrome
eponym.desc: Malformation syndrome characterized by intrauterine growth retardation, short stature, microcephaly, mild mental retardation with behavior problems, eczema, and unusual facies.

eponym.name: Duchenne's muscular dystrophy
eponym.desc: X-linked, near or complete absence of dystrophin (normally stabilizes glycoprotein complex on cytoplasmic face of plasma membrane of muscle fibers and protects it from degradation), onset of weakness age 2-3, proximal weakness of limb muscles, see also Gower's maneuver. Characterized by pseudohypertrophy of calves caused by fatty infiltration, cardiomyopathy, frequently mental retardation, CK elevated, wheelchair bound by age of 12; see also Becker's muscular dystrophy.

eponym.name: Duffy blood group system
eponym.desc: Named after Mr. Duffy, a patient with hemophilia in whom anti-Fya was discovered by Cutbush in 1950; abbreviation Fy used because "Du" had already been taken; Fy6 antigen is the receptor for Plasmodium vivax.

eponym.name: Duke criteria for endocarditis
eponym.desc: Criteria for endocarditis, including two major criteria (typical blood culture and positive echocardiogram) and six minor criteria (predisposition, fever, vascular phenomena, immunologic phenomena, suggestive echocardiogram, and suggestive microbiologic findings); described at Duke University in 1994.

eponym.name: Dukes staging
eponym.desc: Staging system for colon cancer; described by Cuthbert Esquire Dukes (1890-1977) in the Journal of Pathology in 1932.

eponym.name: Dukes's disease
eponym.desc: Fourth disease; see Filatov-Dukes's disease.

eponym.name: Duncan's disease
eponym.desc: Also known as X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome. Individuals have normal response to childhood infections but later fatal lymphoproliferative disorders after infection with EBV; most patients with this syndrome die of infectious mononucleosis.

eponym.name: Dunnigan syndrome
eponym.desc: Face-sparing partial lipodystrophy, loss of subcutaneous fat and increase in visceral fat, causing muscular appearance in arms and legs, due to mutation in laminin A/C.

eponym.name: Dunphy sign
eponym.desc: Increased pain with coughing in appendicitis.

eponym.name: Dupuytren's contracture
eponym.desc: Palmar fibromatosis or flexion contracture; most commonly affects ring finger and little finger. Described by Baron Guillaume Dupuytren, a surgeon who developed a procedure to correct it.

eponym.name: Durant's maneuver
eponym.desc: Left lateral decubitus position, used in managing air embolism.

eponym.name: Duret hemorrhage
eponym.desc: Hemorrhage from uncal herniation.

eponym.name: Durkan's test
eponym.desc: For testing carpal tunnel syndrome, direct compression of median nerve to 150 mm Hg via bulb for 30 seconds; alternatively using both thumbs.

eponym.name: Duroziez's sign
eponym.desc: In aortic regurgitation, systolic murmur heard over the femoral artery when it is compressed proximally and a diastolic murmur when it is compressed distally.

eponym.name: Dutcher bodies
eponym.desc: PAS-positive inclusions containing immunoglobulin in the nucleus of lymphocytes, plasma cells, and intermediate lymphocytes in Waldenström's macroglobulinemia and multiple myeloma.

eponym.name: Eagle effect
eponym.desc: Failure of penicillin in streptococcal infection when bacteria are not growing, i.e., beta-lactams being more effective against rapidly growing bacteria in the early stages and less effective as bacterial growth slows. Described by Eagle in 1952.

eponym.name: Eagle-Barrett syndrome
eponym.desc: Prune-belly syndrome with triad of abdominal muscle deficiency, urinary tract abnormalities, and cryptorchidism.

eponym.name: Eales's disease
eponym.desc: Isolated, peripheral retinal vasculitis.

eponym.name: Ebstein's anomaly
eponym.desc: Congenital heart disease with downward displacement of the tricuspid valve into the right ventricle due to anomalous attachment of the tricuspid leaflets; associated with maternal exposure to lithium.

eponym.name: economy class syndrome
eponym.desc: pulmonary embolism after travel, described by Symington and Stack in Br J Dis Chest 1977; 71:138-40.

eponym.name: Edeiken pattern
eponym.desc: Normal variant ST segment elevation seen V2 or V3 where there is a shallow upward concavity; pattern disappears when leads are recorded one interspace lower than usual (Am Heart J 1954;48:331).

eponym.name: Edinger-Westphal nucleus
eponym.desc: Part of the cranial nerve III complex involved in direct and consensual light reflex involved in efferent limb of reflex arc.

eponym.name: Edwards's syndrome
eponym.desc: Trisomy 18, 1/8,000 births, mental retardation, prominent occiput, micrognathia, low-set ears, rocker-bottom feet, flexion deformities of the fingers, and congenital heart disease.

eponym.name: Ehlers-Danlos syndromes
eponym.desc: Clinically and genetically heterogeneous group of disorders that result from defect in collagen synthesis or structure, at least 10 variants, characterized by hyperextensible skin and hypermobile joints.

eponym.name: Ehrlich's reaction
eponym.desc: Reaction where p-dimethylaminobenzaldehyde reacts with urobilinogen in a strong acid medium to produce a brown-orange color.

eponym.name: Eisenmenger complex
eponym.desc: Congenital heart disease with a ventricular septal defect with right ventricular hypertrophy, severe pulmonary hypertension, and frequent straddling of the defect by a misplaced aortic root.

eponym.name: Eisenmenger syndrome
eponym.desc: Cardiac failure with significant right to left shunt producing cyanosis due to higher pressure on the right side of the shunt; usually due to Eisenmenger complex or any anomalous circulatory communication from e.g. congenital heart disease that leads to obliterative pulmonary vascular disease.

eponym.name: Ekbom syndrome
eponym.desc: Restless leg syndrome.

eponym.name: Ekiri syndrome
eponym.desc: Extremely rare, fatal encephalopathy described in Japanese children with Shigella sonnei or Shigella flexneri infections.

eponym.name: Elejalde syndrome
eponym.desc: Neuroectodermal melanolysosomal disease characterized by silvery hair, CNS dysfunction, abnormal melanocytes and melanosomes, and abnormal inclusion bodies in fibroblasts and other cells; similar dermatologic features to Chédiak-Higashi syndrome and Griscelli syndrome but without defect in immune system.

eponym.name: Ellis-van Creveld syndrome
eponym.desc: Chondroectodermdal dysplasia, short-limbed dwarfism, polydactyly, single atrium or atrial septal defect, autosomal recessive, reported most often in Amish. Associated with mutation in EVC gene.

eponym.name: Ellsworth-Howard test
eponym.desc: For diagnosis of pseudohypoparathyroidism, assessing for phosphaturia in response to exogenous PTH.

eponym.name: Elschnig spots
eponym.desc: In hypertensive retinopathy, yellow (early) or hyperpigmented (late) patches of retinal pigment epithelium overlying infarcted choriocapillaris lobules.

eponym.name: Emery-Dreifuss muscular dystrophy
eponym.desc: Distinctive form of muscular dystrophy with humero-peroneal weakness and quite pronounced muscle contractions and by severe cardiac arrhythmias which may cause sudden death; due to mutations in lamin A/C gene on 1q21.2-q21.3.

eponym.name: Epley maneuver
eponym.desc: In benign paroxysmal positional vertigo, a treatment maneuver for moving calcium carbonate debris to the common crus of the anterior and posterior canals and exit into the utricular canal; symptoms are improved in 90% of patients with no recurrence in 50-70% (also see Semont maneuver and Brandt-Daroff exercises).

eponym.name: Epping jaundice
eponym.desc: Outbreak of jaundice that occurred in 84 individuals after ingestion of bread made with flour contaminated with 4,4'-diaminodiphenylmethane in England in 1965.

eponym.name: Epsom salts
eponym.desc: Magnesium sulfate, can be used as laxative.

eponym.name: Epstein-Barr virus
eponym.desc: Member of herpesvirus family; causes mononucleosis 35-50% when infection occurs in adolescence or young adulthood. Associated with Burkitt's lymphoma and nasopharyngeal carcinoma. EBV binds to CD21 found on epithelial cells and B cells; however a large number of T suppressor cells and EBV specific cells are seen as atypical lymphocytes.

eponym.name: Epstein's pearls
eponym.desc: Small, white cysts along the median raphe of the hard palate.

eponym.name: Erb's palsy
eponym.desc: Upper plexus palsy affecting C5 and C6 and +/- C7 nerve roots associated with weakness of shoulder and arm.

eponym.name: Erdheim-Chester disease
eponym.desc: Rare, rapidly fatal, multisystem histiocytosis syndrome that usually affects adults, characterized by bone pain, xanthomas, xanthelasma, exophthalmos, diabetes insipidus, retroperitoneal, and pulmonary disease; tropism for adipose and connective tissues.

eponym.name: Erlenmeyer's flask deformity
eponym.desc: Seen in osteopetrosis, where the ends of long bones are bulbous.

eponym.name: Esmarch bandage
eponym.desc: Rubber bandage applied around a part from distal to proximal in order to expel blood from it (Johannes Friedrich August von Esmarch, German surgeon, 1823-1908).

eponym.name: Esmarch maneuver
eponym.desc: In anesthesia, jaw thrust to open an obstructed airway.

eponym.name: eustachian tube
eponym.desc: A canal leading from the upper part of the pharynx to the middle ear; after Bartolomeo Eustachi, Italian anatomist (died 1574).

eponym.name: eustachian valve
eponym.desc: In the fetus, a membranous fold at the opening of the IVC that directs blood flow from the IVC to the foramen ovale; after closure of the foramen ovale, no specific function; prominent eustachian valve more commonly found in patients with presumed paradoxical embolism; after Bartolomeo Eustachi, Italian anatomist (died 1574).

eponym.name: Evans's syndrome
eponym.desc: Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP) and autoimmune hemolytic anemia. Described by Evans in 1951.

eponym.name: Ewart's sign
eponym.desc: In large pericardial effusion, dullness to percussion of the left lung over the angle of the scapula may occur; due to compressive atelectasis by the large pericardial sac.

eponym.name: Ewing's sarcoma
eponym.desc: Same tumor as primitive neuroectodermal tumor or small round cell tumor of bone, 85% of cases there is a t(11;22)(q24:q12) translocation; second most common cancer of bone in children and adolescents. Onion skinning, a radiographic finding.

eponym.name: Fabricius, bursa of
eponym.desc: In birds, thymus-like gland that is an outgrowth of the cloaca and site for B cell maturation.

eponym.name: Fabry's disease
eponym.desc: X-linked recessive sphingolipidosis (sulfatidose) alpha-galactosidase deficiency resulting in increased globosides, reddish-purple skin rash, kidney and heart failure, peripheral neuropathy, pain in lower extremities (acroparesthesias). Accounts for 1:117,000 live births; most common clinical features are telangiectases and corneal dystrophy; can be treated with biweekly infusions of recombinant human alpha-galactosidase A.

eponym.name: factor V Leiden
eponym.desc: Arg(506)->Gln mutation, results in resistance to cleavage by activated protein C (an anticoagulant) leading to hypercoagulability. Found in 20% of patients with venous thromboembolism, 6% of U.S. population.

eponym.name: Fahr's disease
eponym.desc: Neurodegenerative syndrome associated with symmetric intracerebral calcifications in basal ganglia, associated with cognitive and movement disorders including spastic paralysis, athetosis.

eponym.name: Fallot, tetralogy of
eponym.desc: 1. ventricular septal defect; 2. infundibular, valvar, or supravalvar pulmonic stenosis; 3. an anteriorly displaced aorta that receives blood from both ventricles; 4. right ventricular hypertrophy.

eponym.name: Fanconi-Bickel syndrome
eponym.desc: Type XI glycogen storage disease, hepatic glycogenosis with renal Fanconi syndrome; caused by defect in GLUT-2 transporter. Characterized by proximal renal tubular dysfunction, impaired glucose and galactose utilization, liver and kidney glycogen accumulation. Presents as failure to thrive in first year with hepatomegaly and kidney enlargement.

eponym.name: Fanconi's anemia
eponym.desc: Autosomal recessive disorder characterized by progressive bone marrow failure at age 5-7, congenital malformations (frequently defects in thumbs or forearms, kidneys, GI, skin); 20% develop cancer (primarily AML but also in skin, GI, GU). Can be diagnosed by increased sensitivity of FA cells to bifunctional alkylating agents (e.g. diepoxybutane or mitomycin C).

eponym.name: Fanconi's syndrome
eponym.desc: Generalized dysfunction of proximal renal tubule leading to glycosuria, hyperphosphaturia, hypophasphatemia, aminoaciduria, and systemic acidosis; may be associated with outdated tetracyclines.

eponym.name: Farber's disease
eponym.desc: A lysosomal storage disease or sphingolipidosis from ceraminidase deficiency leading to painful and progressively deformed joints, subcutaneous nodules, granulomas, fatal in early life.

eponym.name: farmer's lung
eponym.desc: Hypersensitivity pneumonitis from exposure to antigens of microorganisms which colonize equipment used in farming, including from moldy hay, grain, silage (e.g. thermophilic actinomycetes, fungus such as Aspergillus umbrosus).

eponym.name: farmer's skin
eponym.desc: Cutis rhomboidalis nuchae.

eponym.name: Fay sign
eponym.desc: In carotid arteritis, pressure along the carotid causing pain to spread in distal branches of external carotid to jaw, ear, and temple.

eponym.name: Fechtner syndrome
eponym.desc: Alport's syndrome with leukocyte inclusions and macrothrombocytopenia; associated with mutations in nonmuscle myosin heavy chain-9.

eponym.name: Felty's syndrome
eponym.desc: Rheumatoid arthritis, splenomegaly, and neutropenia, and also leg ulcers; associated with HLA-DR4.

eponym.name: Ferguson's reflex
eponym.desc: Stimulation of the cervix leading to contraction of the uterus through oxytocin release.

eponym.name: fetor hepaticus
eponym.desc: "Musty" or "sweet odor" from the formation of mercaptans by the action of GI bacteria on the sulfur-containing amino acid methionine and shunting of splanchnic blood from the portal into the system circulation (portosystemic shunting).

eponym.name: fifth disease
eponym.desc: Erythema infectiosum, associated with parvovirus B19 infection, characterized by "slapped cheeks" and erythematous lacy eruption on the trunk and extremities.

eponym.name: Filatov-Dukes's disease
eponym.desc: Fourth disease, historically felt to be a separate form of rubella and then felt to be a non-entity but perhaps now is Staph scarlet fever Lancet 357:299 (2001); alternatively misdiagnosed cases of rubella or scarlet fever.

eponym.name: Finkelstein's test
eponym.desc: In de Quervain's tenosynovitis, dorsal thumb pain when the wrist is deviated in an ulnar fashion and the thumb is flexed across the palm.

eponym.name: first disease
eponym.desc: Measles, also known as rubeola, caused by paramyxovirus, described in 1627.

eponym.name: Fisher's syndrome
eponym.desc: See Miller Fisher syndrome.

eponym.name: Fitzgerald factor
eponym.desc: High molecular weight kininogen; in intrinsic phase of coagulation, part of complex between factor XII, prekallikrein, and subendothelial collagen; facilitates conversion of XII to XIIa. Deficiency not associated with bleeding.

eponym.name: Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome
eponym.desc: Associated with spread of gonococci or chlamydia: perihepatitis manifested by right upper quadrant or bilateral upper abdominal pain, tenderness, and occasionally by a hepatic friction rib.

eponym.name: Flatbush diabetes
eponym.desc: GAD antibody negative diabetes in adult black patients with diabetic ketoacidosis and increased frequency of human leukocyte antigen DR3 and DR4.

eponym.name: Fletcher factor
eponym.desc: Prekallikrein. In intrinsic phase of coagulation, converts XII to XIIa. Deficiency results in elevated PTT but with no clinical bleeding .

eponym.name: Foix-Alajouanine disease
eponym.desc: Angiodysgenetic necrotizing myelopathy, venous angiomatous malformation of the spinal cord and overlying meninges associated with ischemic damage and worsening neurologic symptoms in lumbosacral cord.

eponym.name: Foley catheter
eponym.desc: A catheter with a balloon at the tip; inflated balloon aids in retention of catheter in e.g. bladder. Developed by Frederic Foley (1891-1966) in the 1930s.

eponym.name: Følling's disease
eponym.desc: Phenylketonuria. Følling, a Norwegian physician who described PKU in 1934.

eponym.name: Fontan procedure
eponym.desc: For treating tricuspid atresia, pulmonary atresia, or hypoplastic left heart syndrome, procedure developed in 1968 whereby IVC is connected to pulmonary artery; long term complications include arrhythmias and protein losing enteropathy because of edema in liver and small bowel.

eponym.name: Forbes disease
eponym.desc: Glycogen storage disease type III; see Cori's disease.

eponym.name: Forbes-Albright syndrome
eponym.desc: Galactorrhea-amenorrhea caused by a pituitary adenoma.

eponym.name: Fordyce's spots
eponym.desc: Ectopic sebaceous glands seen in healthy mouth; may be confused with Koplik's spots which has an erythematous halo by comparison.

eponym.name: Forrester classification
eponym.desc: In myocardial infarction, class I, PWP<18 and CI>2.2 L/min/m2, 2% mortality; class II, PWP>18 and CI>2.2, 10% mortality; class III, CI<2.2 and PWP<18, 12% mortality; class IV, PWP>18 and CI<2.2, 54% mortality.

eponym.name: Forscheimer spots
eponym.desc: In 20% of rubella, small, red macules on the soft palate that may later expand and coalesce; not pathognomonic since they may also appear in scarlet fever, roseola, mono.

eponym.name: Forsmann antibodies
eponym.desc: Antibody that may be found in normal individuals and can cause false positive heterophile antibody test; guinea pig kidney cells contain Forsmann antigens; see Paul-Bunnell-Davidsohn test.

eponym.name: Foster Kennedy syndrome
eponym.desc: Optic atrophy, contralateral papilledema, and anosmia; may be associated with olfactory groove meningioma. Described by Robert Foster Kennedy, though first described by Gowers.

eponym.name: Fothergill's sign
eponym.desc: In rectus sheath hematomas, tender mass that does not cross the midline and remains palpable when patient tenses the rectus muscle (bluish discoloration not usually seen until 3 or 4 days).

eponym.name: Fournier's gangrene
eponym.desc: Necrotizing infection of the perineal and genital fascia.

eponym.name: fourth disease
eponym.desc: Filatov-Dukes's disease, also known as Staphylococcal scarlet fever, caused by Staph. aureus epidermolytic toxin, described in 1900.

eponym.name: Foville's syndrome
eponym.desc: Dorsal pontine injury giving rise to lateral gaze palsy, ipsilateral facial palsy, contralateral hemiparesis.

eponym.name: Fowler's syndrome
eponym.desc: Idiopathic voiding dysfunction and urinary retention.

eponym.name: Fox-Fordyce disease
eponym.desc: Chronic, pruritic, papular eruption occurring in areas with apocrine glands, affecting mainly women.

eponym.name: Fox's sign
eponym.desc: In hemorrhagic pancreatitis, ecchymosis of the inguinal ligament due to blood tracking from the retroperitoneum and collecting at the inguinal ligament.

eponym.name: Fränkel's sign
eponym.desc: In scurvy, dense zone of provisional calcification at the margins of the growth plate (white line); see also Trummerfeld zone.

eponym.name: Franklin's disease
eponym.desc: Gamma heavy chain disease, a rare B cell lymphoproliferative disease characterized by lymphadenopathy, fever, anemia, malaise, hepatosplenomegaly, and weakness, most distinctive symptom palatal edema.

eponym.name: Frank's sign
eponym.desc: Earlobe crease, associated with coronary artery disease (N Engl J Med. 1973;289:327-8).

eponym.name: Frasier syndrome
eponym.desc: Female external genitalia in 46 XY patients, late renal failure, streak gonads, and high risk of gonadoblastoma; associated with mutation in WT1 gene.

eponym.name: Fregoli syndrome
eponym.desc: Delusional belief that a single person can assume the identity of different people through disguise; after Italian actor Fregoli; see also Capgras syndrome.

eponym.name: Freiberg disease
eponym.desc: Osteochondrosis of second metatarsal head; associated with avascular necrosis of metatarsal head; most patients are female.

eponym.name: Frey syndrome
eponym.desc: Gustatory sweating or auriculotemporal syndrome seen in the context of parotid surgery; ipsilateral forehead becoming drenched with sweat. Attributed to aberrant neuronal regeneration resulting in parasympathetic cholinergic innervation of cutaneous sympathetic receptors.

eponym.name: Friedman curve
eponym.desc: Graph of dilatation of cervix v. fetal descent during active labor.

eponym.name: Friedreich's ataxia
eponym.desc: A spinocerebellar degeneration, autosomal recessive form manifesting at around 11 years, less common autosomal dominant form around 20 years. Initial symptoms: gait ataxia, hand clumsiness, dysarthria, deep tendon reflexes absent (extensor plantar present), joint position and vibratory sense impaired, sometimes loss of pain and temperature, paralysis over course of 20 years. High incidence of diabetes and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (dilated less common) and arrhythmias.

eponym.name: Friedreich's foot
eponym.desc: Seen in Friedreich's ataxia, pes cavus with hammer toe.

eponym.name: Friedreich's sign
eponym.desc: Exaggerated y descent in patients with increased venous pressure, associated with an S3; also associated with constrictive pericarditis.

eponym.name: Froin's syndrome
eponym.desc: Spinal block from tumor or inflammatory conditions, etc. causing increased protein in CSF, resulting in xanthochromia and increased coagulability in CSF. Described by Georges Froin, a French physician born 1874.

eponym.name: Froment's sign
eponym.desc: For diagnosis of ulnar nerve lesion; caused by flexor pollicus longus (median nerve) which comes into action when the patient attempts to grip a flat object between the thumb and the hand and causes flexion at the interphalangeal joint (rather than extension, as would be seen with normal use of the adductor pollicus).

eponym.name: Fukuyama congenital muscular dystrophy
eponym.desc: Congenital muscular dystrophy in combination with cortical dysgenesis (micropolygyria); autosomal recessive disorder, more common in Japan. Due to mutation in fukutin.

eponym.name: Gaisböck's syndrome
eponym.desc: Stress polycythemia, combination of modest elevation in hematocrit and normal red cell mass; unknown etiology, tends to be seen in middle-aged males, who smoke and are overweight and hypertensive. Described in 1905.

eponym.name: Galeazzi fracture
eponym.desc: Fracture of the radius at the junction of the middle and distal thirds accompanied by disruption of the distal radioulnar joint.

eponym.name: Galen, great vein of
eponym.desc: Great cerebral vein.

eponym.name: Gallavardin dissociation
eponym.desc: In aortic stenosis, high-velocity jet within the aortic root resulting in radiation of murmur upward to 2nd right intercostal space (in older patients, becomes harsh, noisy, and impure), whereas the murmur over apex is pure and often musical, mimicking mitral regurgitation.

eponym.name: Galloway-Mowat syndrome
eponym.desc: Autosomal recessive disorder characterized by early onset nephrotic syndrome, microcephaly, and hiatal hernia.

eponym.name: gamekeeper's thumb
eponym.desc: Injury to ulnar collateral ligament of the thumb.

eponym.name: Gandy-Gamna nodules
eponym.desc: In congestive splenomegaly, organization of focal hemorrhages giving rise to foci of fibrosis containing deposits of iron and calcium salts encrusted on connective tissue and elastic fibers.

eponym.name: Ganser syndrome
eponym.desc: A dissociative disorder characterized by giving nonsensical or approximate answers to questions; syndrome occurs most frequently in prisoners where it may represent an effort to obtain leniency. Described in 1898 by German psychiatrist Sigbert Ganser.

eponym.name: Garcin syndrome
eponym.desc: Extensive unilateral cranial palsies associated with malignancy in nasopharynx or skull base.

eponym.name: Gardner-Diamond syndrome
eponym.desc: Also known as psychogenic purpura; painful ecchymoses at site of trauma followed by progressive edema and erythema; associated with psychiatric disorders. Lesions have been likened to "religious stigmata." Initial mechanism felt to be autoerythrocyte sensitization with purpura following intradermal injection of patient's own RBC stroma. Initially described in 1955.

eponym.name: Gardner's syndrome
eponym.desc: Familial adenomatous polyposis with extraintestinal manifestations: 1. sebaceous cysts, 2. osteomas (particularly of the mandible, skull, and long bones), 3. desmoid tumors; mutation in adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) gene in 5q. Increasingly appreciated that FAP patients generally have extraintestinal manifestations.

eponym.name: Gardos channel
eponym.desc: Potassium-selective channel controlled by cytosolic calcium concentrations, one of two channels involved in red cell shrinkage playing a role in sickling; local tissue acidosis and deoxygenation-induced influx of calcium activate the Gardos channel resulting in shrinkage; clotrimazole potent blocker of this channel.

eponym.name: Garland's triad
eponym.desc: In sarcoidosis, triad of bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, right paratracheal lymphadenopathy on chest radiograph.

eponym.name: Garré, sclerosing osteomyelitis of
eponym.desc: A chronic type of osteomyelitis where there is extensive new bone formation that obscures much of the underlying osseous structure; most commonly seen in the jaw in response to e.g. a dental infection.

eponym.name: gastrinoma triangle
eponym.desc: A triangle where more than 90% of extrapancreatic gastrinomas are located bordered by 1. 3rd portion of duodenum, 2. cystic duct, 3. pancreatic neck.

eponym.name: Gaucher's disease
eponym.desc: Most common lysosomal storage disease, autosomal recessive sphingolipidosis, from mutations in glucocerebrosidase gene on 1q21 (also known as acid beta-glucosidase). Enzyme cleaves glucose residue from ceramide. Type I, chronic non-neuropathic form, splenic and skeletal involvement; can be treated with infusions of macrophage-targeted human placental glucocerebrosidase, alglucerase (Ceredase), use described in 1991. Type II, acute infantile, most children die by age 2. Type III, chronic neuropathic form.

eponym.name: Gelineau's disease
eponym.desc: Narcolepsy.

eponym.name: Geraldi, fossa of
eponym.desc: Name of the fossa between the testicle and epididymis.

eponym.name: Gerbode defect
eponym.desc: Ventricular septal defect communicating directly between the left ventricle and right atrium.

eponym.name: Gerhardt's sign
eponym.desc: In aortic regurgitation, pulsation of the spleen in the presence of splenomegaly; see also Sailer's sign.

eponym.name: German measles
eponym.desc: Rubella.

eponym.name: Gerota's fascia
eponym.desc: Fascia surrounding the kidney.

eponym.name: Gerstmann syndrome
eponym.desc: Finger agnosia, agraphia, right-left disorientation, and dyscalculia. Associated with lesions in the dominant, parietal lobe.

eponym.name: Gerstmann-Straussler-Scheinker syndrome
eponym.desc: Slowly progressive cerebellar ataxia, beginning in 50-60s; due to mutation in prion gene.

eponym.name: Geschwind syndrome
eponym.desc: Personality syndrome in temporal lobe epilepsy characterized by viscosity, circumstantiality, hypergraphia (writing and drawing), and hyperreligiosity (Arch Gen Psychiatry 1975;32:1580).

eponym.name: Ghon lesion
eponym.desc: Primary area of tuberculosis infection.

eponym.name: Gianotti-Crosti syndrome
eponym.desc: Reactive exanthem, first described in association with hepatitis B infection (papular acrodermatitis of childhood, papular eruption on face and limbs); also associated with EBV, CMV infection.

eponym.name: Gibbs-Donnan effect
eponym.desc: Effect of charged particles on one side of a membrane on the distribution of other charged particles, when the former cannot diffuse through the membrane but the latter can.

eponym.name: Gilbert's syndrome
eponym.desc: With the exception of hemolytic anemias, most common cause of mild unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia from mild decrease in glucoronyltransferase activity, responds to phenobarbital, affects up to 7% of population.

eponym.name: Girdlestone procedure
eponym.desc: Femoral head ostectomy, resulting in fusion of hip in straight leg position. Used for treatment of septic hip arthritis and osteomyelitis, e.g. historically from tuberculosis.

eponym.name: Gitelman's syndrome
eponym.desc: Variant of Bartter's syndrome where patients have hypomagnesemia and hypocalciuria due to mutations in thiazide-sensitive sodium-chloride transporter.

eponym.name: Glanzmann's thrombasthenia
eponym.desc: Inherited disorder of platelet function where Gp IIb/IIIa receptor for fibrinogen missing.

eponym.name: Glauber's salt
eponym.desc: Sodium sulfate, laxative.

eponym.name: Gleason score
eponym.desc: Prostate cancers stratified into 5 grades on basis of glandular patterns and degree of differentiation; grade 1 most differentiated and grade 5 no glandular differentiation; primary score and secondary score (for second most common histology) added together for score; therefore most differentiated tumor score of 2.

eponym.name: Gleich syndrome
eponym.desc: Episodic angioedema with eosinophilia characterized by recurrent episodes of angioedema, urticaria, pruritus, fever, weight gain, elevated IgM, leukocytosis, and marked eosinophilia; blood eosinophilia parallels disease activity (N Engl J Med 1984;310:1621); no end-organ involvement or cardiac damage unlike other eosinophilc syndromes.

eponym.name: Glenn shunt
eponym.desc: For treatment of hypoplastic left heart syndrome. Unidirectional: SVC to right pulmonary artery anastomosis with ligation of the proximal RPA and cardiac end of the SVC. Bidirectional: SVC to right pulmonary artery anastomosis with flow to both the RPA and LPA.

eponym.name: Glisson's capsule
eponym.desc: Liver capsule.

eponym.name: Goetz sign
eponym.desc: In patent ductus arteriosus, jet of unopacified blood from aorta into opacified blood of pulmonary artery.

eponym.name: Goldblatt kidney
eponym.desc: Atrophic kidney from vasoconstriction of renal artery; results in hypertension.

eponym.name: Goldenhar syndrome
eponym.desc: Hemifacial microsomia or oculoauriculovertebral dysplasia, characterized by unilateral deformity of the external ear and small ipsilateral half of the face with epibulbar lipodermoid and vertebral abnormalities; autosomal dominant.

eponym.name: Goldie-Coldman hypothesis
eponym.desc: Malignant cells likely to acquire spontaneous resistance to cytotoxic drugs as they progressively grow and divide, even without any exposure to those drugs.

eponym.name: Golgi apparatus
eponym.desc: Membranous cell structure that processes proteins synthesized in the endoplasmic reticulum.

eponym.name: Goltz syndrome
eponym.desc: Focal dermal hypoplasia, X-linked dominant disease characterized by patchy dermal hypoplasia, herniation of fat into the dermis, dystrophic nails, sparse, brittle hair; due to mutation in PORCN, which affect regulation of Wnt signaling.

eponym.name: Gonda's maneuver
eponym.desc: Extensor plantar response by flicking the little toe suggesting upper motor neuron defect.

eponym.name: Goodell's sign
eponym.desc: Softening of cervix associated with pregnancy that occurs at around 8th week.

eponym.name: Goodpasture's syndrome
eponym.desc: Glomerulonephritis characterized by linear deposits of antibody along the glomerular basement membrane, antibodies interact with alveolar wall, leading to pulmonary hemorrhage and pulmonary fibrosis. Goodpasture antigen resides in the noncollagenous portion of the alpha3 chain of collagen type IV; high prevalence of DRW15/DQW6, also see iron-deficiency anemia.

eponym.name: Good's syndrome
eponym.desc: Immunodeficiency, hypogammaglobulinemia associated with thymoma (mainly thymoma of spindle cell type); associated with recurrent pulmonary infections; described by Good in 1954.

eponym.name: Goodsall's rule
eponym.desc: Anal fistulae course in a straight path anteriorly and take a curved path posteriorly.

eponym.name: Gordon's maneuver
eponym.desc: Extensor plantar response by squeezing the calf muscle suggesting upper motor neuron defect.

eponym.name: Gordon's syndrome
eponym.desc: Type 2 pseudohypoaldosteronism associated with volume expansion, hypertension, and otherwise normal renal function; felt be to be due to enhanced distal chloride reabsorption.

eponym.name: Gorham-Stout disease
eponym.desc: Non-malignant osteolysis from intraosseous proliferation of vascular tissue; also known as vanishing or disappearing bone disease; IL-6 v. PDGF signaling felt to have pathogenic role.

eponym.name: Gorlin-Goltz syndrome
eponym.desc: Focal dermal hypoplasia characterized by widespread lesions of dermal hypoplasia with herniation of adipose tissue, streaks of pigmentary disturbance following lines of Blaschko, and severe absence deformities of bone, mental retardation, defects of optic nerve.

eponym.name: Gorlin's syndrome
eponym.desc: Increased incidence of basal cell carcinoma, medulloblastoma, and rhabdomyosarcoma; attributed to heterozygous mutation in Patched, a negatively acting component of the Hedgehog receptor.

eponym.name: Gottron's papules
eponym.desc: In dermatomyositis, scaling erythematous eruption or dark red patches over the knuckles, elbows, knees; may mimic psoriasis.

eponym.name: Gower's maneuver
eponym.desc: In Duchenne's muscular dystrophy, patient using hands to help himself get up.

eponym.name: Graafian follicle
eponym.desc: Small fluid-filled sac in ovary containing maturing egg; described by Regnier de Graaf (1641-1673), Dutch physician.

eponym.name: Gradenigo's syndrome
eponym.desc: Thrombosis of inferior petrosal sinus producing ipsilateral facial pain, lateral rectus muscle weakness.

eponym.name: Grafenberg spot
eponym.desc: Erogenous area in anterior vaginal wall.

eponym.name: Graham patch
eponym.desc: Piece of omentum used for repairing perforations.

eponym.name: Graham Steell murmur
eponym.desc: Early diastolic murmur of pulmonic regurgitation secondary to pulmonary hypertension, best heard in left 2nd interspace, may be indistinguishable from murmur of aortic regurgitation; occurs in 12% of patients with tricuspid regurgitation; described by Graham Steell.

eponym.name: Graham-Little syndrome
eponym.desc: End-stage lichen planus of the scalp resulting in scarring alopecia of the scalp.

eponym.name: Graves's disease
eponym.desc: Hyperthyroidism with diffuse goiter, ophthalmopathy, dermopathy from thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin.

eponym.name: Grawitz tumor
eponym.desc: Renal cell carcinoma.

eponym.name: Gregg effect
eponym.desc: Augmentation of left ventricular systolic performance with increase in coronary flow and perfusion pressure.

eponym.name: Greig cephalopolydactyly syndrome
eponym.desc: Rare autosomal dominant developmental disorder characterized by craniofacial abnormalities and post-axial and pre-axial polydactyly as well as syndactyly of hands and feet from mutation in GLI3. See also Pallister-Hall syndrome.

eponym.name: Grey Turner's sign
eponym.desc: Blue-black discoloration around the flanks, e.g. in acute hemorrhagic pancreatitis (1-2%) and other causes of retroperitoneal hemorrhage. Named after English surgeon George Grey Turner. See also Cullen's sign.

eponym.name: Griffith's point
eponym.desc: Watershed area in splenic flexure; see also Sudeck's point.

eponym.name: Griffith's sign
eponym.desc: In thyrotoxicosis, lag of the lower lids during elevation of the globes.

eponym.name: Griscelli syndrome
eponym.desc: Primary immunodeficiency syndrome associated with partial "albinism"; presents similarly to Chédiak-Higashi syndrome but without the giant intracytoplasmic inclusions. From defect in exocytosis of cytolytic granules; due to mutation in RAB27A, a member of the RabGTPase family or mutation in myosin-Va.

eponym.name: Grover's disease
eponym.desc: Transient acantholytic dermatosis; most common in males over 40, sudden onset of pruritus across trunk, neck, and proximal limbs; a polymorphic, pruritic, papulovesicular dermatosis characterized histologically by acantholysis.

eponym.name: Guam disease
eponym.desc: Guam amyotrophic lateral sclerosis-parkinsonism-dementia linked to a plant excitant neurotoxin found in cycad plant eaten by Chamorro people, toxin believed to be excitotoxin beta-N-methylamino-L-alanine, a low-potency convulsant (Science 1987;237:517-22).

eponym.name: Guillain-Barré syndrome
eponym.desc: Acute idiopathic polyneuropathy that may follow minor infective illnesses, inoculations, or surgical procedures (suggested association with C. jejuni) resulting in immunologically-mediated demyelination and progressive weakness.

eponym.name: Gull's disease
eponym.desc: Myxedema.

eponym.name: Gunn's sign
eponym.desc: Tapering of veins on either side of AV crossing in hypertensive retinopathy (grade 3); see also Salus's sign and Bonnet's sign.

eponym.name: Gunther's disease
eponym.desc: Autosomal recessive congenital erythropoietic porphyria from decreased URO synthase activity, hemolytic anemia, cutaneous lesions characterized by mutilating photodermatitis.

eponym.name: Guthrie test
eponym.desc: For diagnosis of phenylketonuria, a bacterial assay for presence of high levels of phenylalanine in patient's serum; high phenylalanine allows for growth of bacteria in the presence of an inhibitor. Developed by Guthrie in 1962.

eponym.name: Guyon's tunnel
eponym.desc: Ulnar tunnel.

eponym.name: Haab's striae
eponym.desc: Lines in Desçemet's membrane; associated with congenital glaucoma.

eponym.name: Haff disease
eponym.desc: Unexplained rhabdomyolysis in people who have eaten fish in the 24 hours before onset of symptoms; first described in the summer and fall of 1924 when physicians near the Haff shores along the Baltic coast recognized an outbreak; attributed to an unidentified toxin.

eponym.name: Hageman factor
eponym.desc: Factor XII, named after patient John Hageman. Interestingly, patient died of a pulmonary embolism after traumatic left hip fracture. Deficiency not associated with bleeding, but may increase risk of thrombosis.

eponym.name: Hailey-Hailey disease
eponym.desc: Familial benign pemphigus; described by Hailey brothers in 1939. From mutation in calcium pump, ATP2C1.

eponym.name: Hajdu-Cheney syndrome
eponym.desc: Extremely rare syndrome with excessive bone resorption, leading to osteoporosis; affects the outermost bones of the fingers and toes.

eponym.name: Hakim-Adams syndrome
eponym.desc: Normal pressure hydrocephalus.

eponym.name: Haldane effect
eponym.desc: Deoxygenated hemoglobin having a greater affinity for CO2 than oxygenated hemoglobin.

eponym.name: Hallermann-Streiff syndrome
eponym.desc: Autosomal recessive syndrome with bird-like facies with hypoplastic mandible and beaked nose, proportionate dwarfism, hypotrichosis, microphthalmia, and congenital cataract.

eponym.name: Hallervorden-Spatz disease
eponym.desc: Autosomal recessive juvenile-onset generalized neuroaxonal dystrophy characterized by progressive movement alterations such as dystonia, tardive dyskinesia, rigidity, choreoathetosis, pyramidal signs, mental retardation, and iron accumulation in the brain; associated with mutation in pantothenate kinase 2. Hallervorden, Nazi pathologist involved in Aktion T-4 adult euthanasia program.

eponym.name: Hamburger shift
eponym.desc: In red blood cells, the conversion of carbon dioxide ultimately to bicarbonate, which diffuses out in exchange for chloride ions diffusing in.

eponym.name: Hamman-Rich syndrome
eponym.desc: Acute interstitial pneumonia, a rare fulminant form of lung injury that presents acutely (days to weeks from onset of symptoms). Most commonly occurs in previously healthy individuals, characterized by a temporally uniform lesion which reflects an episode of acute lung injury at a single point in time (different from usual interstitial pneumonia where lesions are different age); path shows diffuse alveolar damage (a nonspecific reaction pattern).

eponym.name: Hamman's sign
eponym.desc: Mediastinal crunch or precordial crackles synchronous with the heart beat, not with respiration. Best heard in the left lateral position. Associated with mediastinal emphysema (pseudomediastinum), seen with Boerhaave's syndrome.

eponym.name: Hampton's hump
eponym.desc: In pulmonary embolism or infarction, a wedge-shaped infiltrate that abuts the pleura; often associated with a small pleura effusion that is usually exudative and may be hemorrhagic; not specific.

eponym.name: Hampton's line
eponym.desc: Radiolucent collar of granulation tissue across the base of a gastric ulcer.

eponym.name: Ham's test
eponym.desc: For diagnosing paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria, increased sensitivity of PNH-affected RBCs to lysis by complement; introduced in late 1930s.

eponym.name: Hand-Schüller-Christian triad
eponym.desc: In multifocal Langerhans' cell histiocytosis, triad of calvarial bone defects, diabetes insipidus, and exophthalmos.

eponym.name: hangman's fracture
eponym.desc: Fracture of pars interarticularis of C2 vertebra, often from hyperextension injury.

eponym.name: Hannington-Kiff sign
eponym.desc: Ipsilateral loss of the adductor reflex with preservation of patellar reflex in strangulated obturator hernia.

eponym.name: Hansel's stain
eponym.desc: Special stain used to detect eosinophiluria in the urine sediment.

eponym.name: Hansen's disease
eponym.desc: Leprosy.

eponym.name: Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium
eponym.desc: p^2 + 2pq + q^2 for describing the frequency of these genotypes; sexual reproduction doesn't cause a constant reduction in genetic variation in each generation but remains constant.

eponym.name: harlequin syndrome
eponym.desc: Localized autonomic syndrome of heat or exercised-induced flushing and sweating limited to one side of the face with impairment of sweating and flushing on the contralateral side; possible link with Holmes-Adie syndrome.

eponym.name: Harrison's groove
eponym.desc: Site at lower margin of thorax where diaphragm attaches to the ribs. Groove more prominent in rickets due to lack of calcium necessary to harden site of attachment.

eponym.name: Hartmann's procedure
eponym.desc: Proximal colostomy followed by stapled-off colon or rectum that is left in the peritoneal cavity.

eponym.name: Hartnup disease
eponym.desc: An autosomal recessive disorder in which there is a reduction of small-intestinal and renal transport of certain neutral amino acids, including (Trp, a precursor of niacin), causing elevated amino acid excretion in urine and feces; characterized by failure to thrive, photosensitivity, ataxia; from mutation in SLC6A19.

eponym.name: Hashimoto-Pritzker disease
eponym.desc: Pure cutaneous form of Langerhans cell histiocytosis.

eponym.name: Hashimoto's encephalopathy
eponym.desc: Neurologic complication of Hashimoto's thyroiditis, mainly in people euthyroid, associated with a vasculitic condition with stroke-like episodes and cognitive impairment and diffuse progressive picture with dementia, seizures, movement disorders, psychosis, and sometimes delirium.

eponym.name: Hashimoto's thyroiditis
eponym.desc: Goitrous chronic autoimmune thyroiditis; in areas with sufficient iodine, elevated TSH is often viewed as evidence of chronic autoimmune thyroiditis as well as antithyroid antibodies; antithyroglobulin antibodies in 60% of patients and antithyroid microsomal antibodies in 95%. Described in 1920.

eponym.name: Hassall's corpuscles
eponym.desc: Spherical or ovoid bodies found in the medulla of the thymus, composed of concentric arrays of epithelial cells around central area of degenerated cells. Numbers increase until puberty, then decreases.

eponym.name: Hatchcock's sign
eponym.desc: Upward pressure applied to the angle of the mandible (ramus) produces tenderness with mumps but no tenderness with adenitis.

eponym.name: Haw River syndrome
eponym.desc: Variant of dentalorubral-pallidoluysian atrophy (DRPLA) (ataxia and rigidity accompanied by choreoathetosis, myoclonic epilepsy, and dementia) but without the myoclonic epilepsy; described in ancestors born in Haw River, North Carolina; caused by same expanded CTG-B37 repeat as in DRPLA.

eponym.name: Hawkin's sign
eponym.desc: In shoulder impingement, with the arm in a throwing position and flexed forward about 30 degress, forcibly internally rotate the humerus; pain suggests impingement of the supraspinatus tendon against the coracoacromial ligament.

eponym.name: Hawthorne effect
eponym.desc: The effect (usually positive or beneficial) of being under study upon the persons being studied; their knowledge of the study often influences behavior. Named after city in Illinois; site of a Western Electric plant.

eponym.name: Heberden's nodes
eponym.desc: Characteristic in women, but not in men, represent prominent osteophytes at the distal interphalangeal joints in osteoarthritis (enlargements of tubercles at the articular extremities of the distal phalanges).

eponym.name: Hecht-Beals syndrome
eponym.desc: Trismus-pseudocamptodactyly syndrome, inability to open mouth fully and problems with wrist dorsiflexion, producing involuntary flexion contracture of distal and proximal interphalangeal joints. Associated with mutation in MYH8.

eponym.name: Heck's disease
eponym.desc: Oral focal epithelial hyperplasia associated with HPV 13, 32 infection.

eponym.name: Heerfordt-Waldenström syndrome
eponym.desc: Sarcoidosis associated with fever, parotid enlargement, anterior uveitis, and facial nerve palsy.

eponym.name: Hegar's sign
eponym.desc: Softening of the uterus at the junction between the cervix and the fundus during the first trimester of pregnancy.

eponym.name: Heimlich maneuver
eponym.desc: Abdominal thrust maneuver for clearing airway (blocked by foreign object, e.g. food) described in 1974 by Henry Heimlich .

eponym.name: Heineke-Mikulicz pyloroplasty
eponym.desc: Longitudinal incision through all layers of the pylorus, sewed closed in a transverse direction to make the pylorus nonfunctional (used after truncal vagotomy).

eponym.name: Heiner syndrome
eponym.desc: Cow milk allergy associated with pulmonary infiltrates, pulmonary hemosiderosis, anemia, recurrent pneumonia and failure to thrive.

eponym.name: Heinz bodies
eponym.desc: Seen in unstable hemoglobin and oxidant stress; precipitates of denatured hemoglobin on red blood cells; only visible when blood is supravital stained (crystal violet); not seen on routine blood smears.

eponym.name: Heister, spiral valves of
eponym.desc: Found in the neck of the gallbladder, where tiny folds of mucosal epithelium coalesce to form these valves, may assist in retaining bile between meals.

eponym.name: HELLP syndrome
eponym.desc: Hemolysis, elevated liver function tests, and low platelets; microangiopathic process seen in third trimester of pregnancy; seen in 20% of preeclampsia.

eponym.name: hemoglobin Bart's
eponym.desc: Four gamma globin chains, seen in hydrops fetalis (alpha thalassemia), very high oxygen affinity.

eponym.name: hemoglobin Constant Spring
eponym.desc: Particularly common structural variant with alpha thalassemia in Asia, contains mutation which abolishes normal translation termination codon, so extra 31 residues read until another in-frame termination codon comes up.

eponym.name: hemoglobin Gower
eponym.desc: Embryonic, primitive hemoglobin. Gower 1, zeta2 episilon2; Gower 2, alpha2 epsilon2.

eponym.name: hemoglobin Lepore
eponym.desc: No beta chain; delta chain by delta-beta hybrid.

eponym.name: hemoglobin Portland
eponym.desc: Zeta2gamma2, primitive embryonic hemoglobin, can be seen more prominently in e.g. hemoglobin Bart hydrops fetalis.

eponym.name: HEMPAS
eponym.desc: Hereditary Erythrocyte Multinuclearity and Positive Acidified Serum test, also known as congenital dyserythropoietic anemia type II. A congenital anemia characterized by multinucleated red cell precursors and hemolysis of red blood cells of the patient with autologous serum during Ham's test.

eponym.name: Henle, loop of
eponym.desc: Section of nephron between proximal and distal tubule located in the medulla and involved in reabsorbing 25-35% of filtered NaCl and reaborbing NaCl in excess of water.

eponym.name: Henle's layer
eponym.desc: The outer layer of cells of the inner root sheath of a hair follicle, lying between the outer root sheath and Huxley's layer.

eponym.name: Henoch-Schönlein purpura
eponym.desc: Systemic vasculitis with deposition of immune complexes containing IgA in skin and kidney, occurring mainly in in young children. Characterized by purpuric rash, colicky abdominal pain (presumably due to focal hemorrhages into the GI tract), polyarthralgia, and acute glomerulonephritis. May occur following infection with group A streptococci, viral infections; majority of cases, unknown cause.

eponym.name: Hering, canals of
eponym.desc: At the fringes of the portal tract, from the joining of bile canaliculi.

eponym.name: Hering-Breuer reflex
eponym.desc: Reflex mediated by stretch receptor in smooth muscle of airways responsible for apnea, i.e. decreased breathing frequency, as a result of lung inflation.

eponym.name: Hering's nerve
eponym.desc: Carotid sinus nerve, CN IX, carries information to the vasomotor center in the brainstem.

eponym.name: Herlitz syndrome
eponym.desc: Epidermolysis bullosa lethalis; mutation that prevents the folding of laminin 5. Described by Gillis Herlitz, Swedish pediatrician, born 1902.

eponym.name: Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome
eponym.desc: Autosomal recessive syndrome from defect in AP-3 adaptor complex beta3A subunit or HPS1; characterized by idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, oculocutaneous albinism, a platelet storage pool deficiency, and ceroid lipofuscinosis from defects of multiple cytoplasmic organelles: melanosomes, platelet dense granules and lysosomes.

eponym.name: Herring bodies
eponym.desc: Neurosecretory granules consisting of either vasopressin or oxytocin in neurohypophysis.

eponym.name: Hers disease
eponym.desc: Type VI glycogen storage disease, deficiency in liver phosphorylase; presents as hepatomegaly and growth retardation; hypoglycemic, hyperlipidemia, and hyperketosis usually mild if present; hepatomegaly and growth retardation improve with age and usually disppear at puberty.

eponym.name: Heschl's gyrus
eponym.desc: Primary auditory cerebral cortex, transverse temporal gyrus.

eponym.name: Hess test
eponym.desc: See Rumpel-Leede sign; a test for capillary fragility by applying pressure with blood pressure cuff and counting petechiae; noticed phenomenon while treating children with scurvy.

eponym.name: Hesselbach's triangle
eponym.desc: Where direct inguinal hernias occur, bound by the inguinal ligament, inferior epigastric artery, and rectus abdominus muscle.

eponym.name: Heyde's syndrome
eponym.desc: Association between bleeding from gastrointestinal angiodysplasia and severe aortic stenosis which may resolve with aortic valve replacement. May also be explained by acquired type IIA von Willebrand's disease. First described by Heyde in N Engl J Med 1958;259:196.

eponym.name: Hibernian fever, familial
eponym.desc: TNF Receptor-1 Associated Periodic Syndrome (TRAPS), autosomal dominant. From mutation in TNFR1. Characterized by recurrent fevers, myalgias, conjunctivitis, periorbital edema, abdominal pain, arthritis, rash (single or multiple erythematous patches that spread distally down an extremity).

eponym.name: Hickam's dictum
eponym.desc: A "patient can have as many diseases as they damn well please", attributed to John Hickam, a faculty member at Duke University in the 1950's, and was later chairman of medicine at Indiana University; see also Occam's razor.

eponym.name: Hickey-Hare test
eponym.desc: In evaluating hypernatremia, 5% NaCl infused at a rate of 0.05 mL/kg/min followed by measurements of urine volume and urine osmolality.

eponym.name: Hill's sign
eponym.desc: In aortic regurgitation, refers to popliteal cuff systolic pressure exceeding brachial cuff pressure by more than 60 mm Hg.

eponym.name: Hill-Sachs lesion
eponym.desc: Posterolateral humeral head indentation fracture from anterior shoulder dislocation; from humeral head impinging against glenoid of shoulder joint.

eponym.name: Hinton test
eponym.desc: Test for diagnosing syphilis using a precipitin of glycerol, cholesterol, and beef heart extract; developed in 1927.

eponym.name: Hippocratic fingers
eponym.desc: Clubbing.

eponym.name: Hippocratica, facies
eponym.desc: The mask of death following peritonitis, i.e. as a result of vomiting and hypotension, anxious face with hollow cheeks and dim eyes.

eponym.name: Hirano bodies
eponym.desc: In Alzheimer's disease, intracytoplasmic proximal dendritic eosinophilic inclusions consisting of actin.

eponym.name: Hirata disease
eponym.desc: Insulin autoimmune syndrome with hypoglycemia associated with insulin autoantibodies. Third leading cause of spontaneous hypoglycemia in Japan; rare in Western countries.

eponym.name: Hirschberg test
eponym.desc: Corneal light reflex test.

eponym.name: Hirschsprung's disease
eponym.desc: Congenital aganglionic megacolon; colonic dilatation proximal to an aganglionic, contracted distal colon and rectum; caused by gestational failure of neural crest cells to migrate to distal colon. Autosomal dominant form associated with mutations of the RET gene, autosomal recessive form associated with mutations of the endothelin-B-receptor gene.

eponym.name: Hitzig zones
eponym.desc: In tabes dorsalis from syphilis, regions of reduced sensation found in central face, nipples, ulnar forearms, and peroneal legs, leading to painless ulcers and joint damage.

eponym.name: Hodgkin's disease
eponym.desc: Lymphoma characterized by arising in a single node or chain of nodes, spreading in anatomically contiguous nodes. Reed-Sternberg cells are one hallmark.

eponym.name: Hoesch test
eponym.desc: Diagnostic test for urinary porphobilinogen for porphyria; see also Watson-Schwartz reaction.

eponym.name: Hoffmann's sign
eponym.desc: Involuntary flexion of the digits when tapping or striking over the palmar digital aspects of the 2nd, 3rd, and 4th digits in upper motor neuron defect.

eponym.name: Hoffman's syndrome
eponym.desc: In hypothyroidism, diffuse muscle hypertrophy, accompanied by stiffness, weakness, painful muscle cramps, associated with elevated muscle enzymes.

eponym.name: Hoigne reaction
eponym.desc: Pseudoanaphylactic reaction, complication associated with intramuscular procaine penicillin, occurs in 1/1000 patients; characterized by tachycardia, elevated blood pressure, fear of imminent death, violent combativeness, unusual taste sensation, auditory or visual disturbances; rarely lasts longer than 30 min. Felt to be due to inadvertent intracapillary infusion of the procaine component resulting in microembolization.

eponym.name: Hollenhorst plaques
eponym.desc: Cholesterol emboli visible as small bright flecks lodged in arterial bifurcations in retina.

eponym.name: Holmes tremor
eponym.desc: Symptomatic tremor caused by lesions in the brainstem, cerebellum, or thalamus; postural and/or action in nature and worsen during movement and markedly increase during goal-directed movements; affect predominantly proximal limbs, low frequency;. Also known as rubral or midbrain tremor.

eponym.name: Holmes-Adie syndrome
eponym.desc: Most frequently occurs in young women, large, often irregular pupils, unilateral at onset as well as segmental palsy and segmental spontaneous movement of the iris, delayed constriction in response to near vision, delayed redilation after near vision, impaired accommodation, absent light reflex, and absent deep tendon reflexes. May be caused by degeneration of ciliary ganglion from viral or bacterial infection, followed by aberrant reinnervation of the pupilloconstrictor muscles.

eponym.name: Holmes's heart
eponym.desc: Single ventricle with normally-related great arteries.

eponym.name: Holter monitor
eponym.desc: Continuous ambulatory EKG monitoring; first described by Montana physician Normal Holter in 1949 (Science 1961;134:1214-1220).

eponym.name: Holt-Oram syndrome
eponym.desc: Autosomal dominant syndrome, dysplasia of the upper limbs and atrial septal defect, reduction anomalies of the upper limbs, heart-hand syndrome from mutation in TBX5.

eponym.name: Homans's sign
eponym.desc: In deep venous thrombosis, pain and tenderness on compression of the calf muscles (by either squeezing the calf muscles or forced dorsiflexion of the foot).

eponym.name: Homer-Wright pseudorosettes
eponym.desc: In neuroblastoma, tumor cells arranged about a central space filled with fibrillar extensions of the cells.

eponym.name: honeymooner's palsy
eponym.desc: Radial nerve palsy from compression of nerve between middle third of the humerus between the brachoradialis and forearm extensor muscles.

eponym.name: Hoover's sign
eponym.desc: A modification in the movement of the costal margins during respiration, caused by a flattening of the diaphragm; suggestive of empyema or other intrathoracic condition causing a change in the contour of the diaphragm.

eponym.name: Hoover's sign
eponym.desc: In hysterical, non-organic weakness, patient does not push down into your hand with contralateral extremity when you ask patient to lift weak extremity.

eponym.name: Hopkins syndrome
eponym.desc: Poliomyelitis-like illness associated with acute asthma in childhood.

eponym.name: Horner's syndrome
eponym.desc: Enophthalmos, ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis, unilateral from lesion affecting sympathetic innervation of eye. If present since infancy, the ipsilateral iris is lighter and blue (heterochromia iridis); topical 4% cocaine will dilate normal pupil but not a desympathectomized pupil. Associated with Pancoast tumor, due to involvement of paravertebral sympathetic chain and the inferior cervical ganglion.

eponym.name: Horton's cephalalgia
eponym.desc: Cluster headache; also known as histaminic cephalalgia.

eponym.name: Horton's disease
eponym.desc: Temporal arteritis.

eponym.name: Hounsfield unit
eponym.desc: Scale named after inventor of computed tomography and Nobel prize winner, Sir Godfrey N. Hounsfield (1919-2004), water 0 H, -1024 H for air to 3000-4000 H for bone, relative scale.

eponym.name: Houston, valve of
eponym.desc: Rectal valves: superior, middle, and inferior.

eponym.name: Howell-Evans syndrome
eponym.desc: Inherited tylosis (keratoderma of palms and soles), strongly associated with esophageal squamous cell carcinoma.

eponym.name: Howell-Jolly body
eponym.desc: In asplenia or malfunctional spleen, nuclear remnants on red blood cells as small, round, darkly-stained nuclear fragments; no special stains necessary; larger than Pappenheimer bodies.

eponym.name: Howship-Romberg sign
eponym.desc: Pain along the inner aspect of the thigh; seen with an obturator hernia due to nerve compression.

eponym.name: Howship's lacunae
eponym.desc: Resorption pits on bone formed by osteoclasts.

eponym.name: Hughes syndrome
eponym.desc: Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome; described in 1983 by Graham Hughes (Clin Exp Dermatol 1984;9:535).

eponym.name: Hughes-Stovin syndrome
eponym.desc: Multiple pulmonary artery aneurysms with peripheral venous thrombosis.

eponym.name: Humphrey's ligament
eponym.desc: Anterior meniscofemoral ligament.

eponym.name: Hunner's ulcer
eponym.desc: In 10% of interstitial cystitis, lesions that involve all layers of the bladder wall and appear as brownish-red patches on the bladder mucosa.

eponym.name: Hunter's ligament
eponym.desc: Round ligament of uterus.

eponym.name: Hunter's syndrome
eponym.desc: Mucopolysaccharidosis (II), iduronate sulfatase deficiency, X-linked, affecting degradation of dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate, resulting in physical deformity and mental retardation, no corneal clouding.

eponym.name: Huntington's disease
eponym.desc: Autosomal dominant neurodegenerative disease from expanded CAG trinucleotide repeat 4p16.3 associated with chorea initially as restlessness, psychiatric symptoms, and dementia; Westphal variant, atypical variant where there is progressive rigidity and akinesia with little or no chorea.

eponym.name: Hurler's syndrome
eponym.desc: Autosomal recessive mucopolysaccharidosis type I caused by deficiency of alpha-L-iduronidase, with consequent accumulations of the mucopolysaccharides heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate in the heart, brain, liver, and other organs; progressive deterioration, hepatosplenomegaly, dwarfism, gargoyle-like facies, stubby fingers, corneal clouding, progressive mental retardation, and death by age 10.

eponym.name: Hurler-Scheie syndrome
eponym.desc: Mucopolysaccharidosis I caused by deficiency of alpha-L-iduronidase (severe form is Hurler's syndrome), have same problems as Hurler's syndrome but progression is lower, mild or no mental retardation, and death in teens or 20s.

eponym.name: Hurst's disease
eponym.desc: Acute hemorrhagic leukoencephalitis, a fulminant form of acute disseminated encephalomyelitis.

eponym.name: Hürthle cells
eponym.desc: In Hashimoto's thyroiditis, deeply stained colloid or clusters of cells having an abundant, brightly eosinophilic granular cytoplasm, thought to represent a degenerated state of the follicular epithelium.

eponym.name: Hutchinson freckle
eponym.desc: Lentigo maligna, a nonfamilial precursor to lentigo maligna melanoma.

eponym.name: Hutchinson pupil
eponym.desc: Dilated and unreactive pupil on side of intracranial lesion, from compression of ipsilateral oculomotor nerve; also seen in uncal herniation. Named after Sir Jonathan Hutchinson (1828-1913).

eponym.name: Hutchinson-Gilford syndrome
eponym.desc: Also known as progeria, a condition where there is normal development in the first year followed by gross retardation of growth, with a senile appearance characterized by dry wrinkled skin, total alopecia, and bird-like facies; genetics unclear.

eponym.name: Hutchinson's sign
eponym.desc: In herpes zoster ophthalmicus, vesicular rash at nasal tip indicating involvement of the external nasal branch of CN V; associated with increased incidence of ocular involvement.

eponym.name: Hutchinson's sign
eponym.desc: Pigment in the paronychial area suggesting melanoma.

eponym.name: Hutchinson's teeth
eponym.desc: A sign of congenital syphilis, teeth that are smaller and more widely spaced than normal; notched biting surfaces.

eponym.name: Hutchinson's triad
eponym.desc: Congenital syphilis manifesting late at around 2 years old with triad of interstitial keratitis, notched incisors, and eighth nerve deafness.

eponym.name: Huxley's layer
eponym.desc: A layer of the inner root sheath of a hair follicle, lying between Henle's layer and the inner sheath cuticle.

eponym.name: I-cell disease
eponym.desc: Lysosomal storage disorder, from deficiency of ability to phosphorylate mannose, causing an incorrect targeting of potential lysosomal enzymes to extracellular sites instead of lysosomes, characterized by skeletal abnormalities, restricted joint movement, coarse facial features, severe pscyhomotor impairment, death by 8 y.o.

eponym.name: Imerslund-Grasbeck syndrome
eponym.desc: Juvenile megaloblastic anemia, an autosomal recessive condition involving mutation in cubulin, receptor that binds IF-B12 complex; also associated with proteinuria.

eponym.name: Irish's node
eponym.desc: Left axillary adenopathy associated with metastatic disease, e.g. gastric cancer.

eponym.name: Isaacs's syndrome
eponym.desc: Neuromyotonia; continuous muscle stiffness, rippling muscle movements (myokymia), delayed relaxation following muscle contraction believed to be due to autoantibodies to presynaptic potassium channels.

eponym.name: Ishihara plates
eponym.desc: Pseudoisochromatic plates (plates with color dots for numbers) for testing color vision. Described by Shinobu Ishihara, Japanese ophthalmologist (1879-1963).

eponym.name: Ishikawa's sign
eponym.desc: In cystic adventitial disease of the popliteal artery, disappearance of foot pulses on knee flexion or after exercise in patients.

eponym.name: itai-itai disease
eponym.desc: Bone disease from cadmium toxicity, characterized by multiple fractures, mixed pattern of osteoporosis and osteomalacia, and renal damage. Means "ouch-ouch" in Japanese, cadmium toxicity noted in exposed individuals living in Jinzu river basin in Japan who used river water contaminated with cadmium for irrigating rice fields.

eponym.name: Ito cells
eponym.desc: Vitamin A fat-storage cells, of mesenchymal origin found in the space of Disse; during development of cirrhosis, they become activated, transform into fibroblast-like cells.

eponym.name: Ivor Lewis procedure
eponym.desc: Esophagectomy through right thoracotomy and intrathoracic esophagogastric anastomosis; described in 1946 by Ivor Lewis.

eponym.name: Jaccoud's arthritis
eponym.desc: In systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), ulnar deviation of the fingers, swan neck deformities, and subluxations, initially reversible since not joint problem per se but can become fixed over time.

eponym.name: jacksonian march
eponym.desc: In simple partial seizures, clonic movements of a single muscle group spreading to involve contiguous regions of the motor cortex.

eponym.name: Jackson-Weiss syndrome
eponym.desc: Craniosynostoses as well as limb defects, broad great toes. Due to mutations in FGFR2.

eponym.name: Jacobsen syndrome
eponym.desc: Congenital condition from deletion in 11q (especially FLI1 gene), characterized by learning disabilities, heart defects, and thrombocytopenia; see also Paris-Trousseau syndrome.

eponym.name: Jadassohn, nevus sebaceus of
eponym.desc: Circumscribed hamartoma involving skin with a preponderance of sebaceous glands. Usually seen at birth or in early childhood. Described by Jadassohn in 1895.

eponym.name: Jamaican vomiting sickness
eponym.desc: Poisoning from hypoglycin A in unripe ackee fruit. Hypoglycin A is potent hypoglycemic agent that decreases rate of fatty-acid beta oxidation probably by inhibition of acyl dehydrogenase flavin-dependent oxidation. Causes liver damage indistinguishable from Reye's syndrome.

eponym.name: James fibers
eponym.desc: Tracts of atrial tissue running from the atria and inserting into the low AV node; functional significance not well established, controversial if associated with abnormal AV conduction.

eponym.name: Janeway lesions
eponym.desc: In infective endocarditis, nonpainful, small, erythematous or hemorrhagic macules or nodules of palms or soles. More common in acute bacterial endocarditis, but may occur in subacute bacterial endocarditis.

eponym.name: Jansen metaphyseal chondrodysplasia
eponym.desc: An autosomal dominant form of dwarfism resulting from an activating mutation in the parathyroid hormone receptor, premature ossification from acceleration of the transition from proliferative to hypertrophic chondrocytes.

eponym.name: Jansky-Bielschowsky disease
eponym.desc: Late infantile neuronal ceroid lipofuscinosis, CLN2 disorder generally characterized by visual loss, epilepsy, and psychomotor deterioration. Due to mutation in TPP1 gene.

eponym.name: Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction
eponym.desc: Sudden fevers, rigors, and persistent hypotension following antimicrobial treatment of louse-borne relapsing fever (spirochete Borrelia recurrentis infection) or syphilis; treatment with anti-TNF-alpha Fab before penicillin suppresses this reaction (NEJM 335:311).

eponym.name: Jatene's arterial switch
eponym.desc: For treating transposition of great vessels, pulmonary artery and aorta are transected above valves and switched, and coronary arteries are moved from old aortic root to new aorta (former pulmonary root).

eponym.name: Jefferson fracture
