eponym.desc: Fracture of C1 at more than one site; rarely associated with neurological deficits because of size of spinal canal at this level.

eponym.name: Jendrassik maneuver
eponym.desc: For increasing sensitivity of deep tendon reflexes, have patient clasp hands together or grab wrists tightly while checking reflexes. Described by Hungarian physician Erno Jendrassik (1858-1921).

eponym.name: Jerusalem syndrome
eponym.desc: Psychosis affecting visitors to Jerusalem whereby afflicted develop psychotic religious delusions; affects a handful of visitors each year.

eponym.name: Jervell-Lange-Nielsen syndrome
eponym.desc: Long QT syndrome with congenital deafness, autosomal recessive.

eponym.name: Job's syndrome
eponym.desc: Hyperimmunoglobulin E syndrome. Immune deficiency where neutrophils fail to respond to chemotactic stimuli, associated with high levels of IgE; patients susceptible to cold staphylococcal abscesses. Associated with mutation in STAT3 in autosomal dominant version.

eponym.name: Jod-Basedow phenomenon
eponym.desc: Thyroid hyperfunction induced by excess iodine ingestion in patients with various thyroid disorders; "jod" is German for iodine; K. A. Von Basedow.

eponym.name: Joffroy sign
eponym.desc: In thyrotoxicosis, absence of forehead wrinkling with upward gaze and head tilted down, in setting of exophthalmos. Also, disorder of the arithmetic faculty in the early stages of organic brain disease.

eponym.name: Johanson-Blizzard syndrome
eponym.desc: Syndrome of nasal alar hypoplasia, hypothyroidism, pancreatic achylia, and congenital deafness; due to defect in UBR1 gene.

eponym.name: John Thomas sign
eponym.desc: Positive sign when penis inclined to side of the disorder radiographically (e.g., fractured hip); 70% sens 67% specific for John Thomas sign in hip fracture, Med J. Aust. 1998;169:670. Also known as Throckmorton sign.

eponym.name: Johnson-McMillin syndrome
eponym.desc: Autosomal dominant neuroectodermal syndrome characterized by anosmia, hypogonadotropic hypogonadism associated with conductive deafness, alopecia, congenital heart defects.

eponym.name: Jolly test
eponym.desc: In myasthenia gravis, a sequence of repetitive nerve stimulation (RNS) studies specifically designed to look for neuromuscular junction disease. A positive test is a >10% decremental response with 3 Hz repetitive stimulation, 50-80% sensitive. After Friedrich Jolly, German neurologist, 1844-1904.

eponym.name: Jones criteria
eponym.desc: For diagnosing rheumatic fever, major criteria: carditis, polyarthritis, chorea, erythema marginatum, and subcutaneous nodules. minor criteria: arthralgia, fever, elevated ESR, CRP, prolonged PR. In setting of antecedent group A streptococcal infection, two major or one major and 2 minor suggests RF. Throat cultures negative by the time rheumatic fever appears. Described by Jones in 1944.

eponym.name: Jones's fracture
eponym.desc: Fracture at the base of the fifth metatarsal diaphysis.

eponym.name: Joubert syndrome
eponym.desc: Autosomal recessive disorder consisting of cerebellar hypoplasia, hypotonia, developmental delay, abnormal respiratory patterns, and abnormal eye movements. On brain imaging, see "molar tooth" sign.

eponym.name: Jumping Frenchmen of Maine syndrome
eponym.desc: Unusually extreme startle reaction that occurs in selected populations with reactions including echolalia, echopraxia; first described in French Canadian lumberjacks in the Moosehead Lake Region of Maine in the late 19th century; also described as latah in Malaysia.

eponym.name: kabuki syndrome
eponym.desc: Congenital mental retardation syndrome; postnatal dwarfism, a peculiar facies with long palpebral fissures, eversion of lateral third of the lower eyelids (reminiscent of the make-up of actors of Kabuki, a Japanese theatrical form), a broad and depressed nasal tip, large earlobes, a cleft or high-arched palate, scoliosis, short fifth finger, persistence of fingerpads, radiographic abnormalities of the vertebrae, hands, and hip joints, and recurrent otitis media in infancy; also known as Niikawa-Kuroki syndrome.

eponym.name: Kahler's disease
eponym.desc: Multiple myeloma.

eponym.name: Kallmann's syndrome
eponym.desc: Anosmia and hypogonadotropic hypogonadism stemming from failure of LHRH-expressing neurons to migrate.

eponym.name: Kanavel's sign
eponym.desc: Four signs of tenosynovitis: 1. affected finger held in slight flexion; 2. pain over volar aspect of affected finger tendon upon palpation; 3. swelling of affected finger; 4. pain on passive extension of affected finger.

eponym.name: Kandinsky-Clerambault's syndrome
eponym.desc: Alienation from or loss of one's own mental processes which are attributed to somebody else, combined with delusions of external influences, such as stealing or insertion of thoughts, described independently by Russian psychiatrist Victor Khrisanfovich Kandinsky (18491889) and French psychiatrist Gaëtan Gatian de Clerambault (18721934) .

eponym.name: Kaplan-Meier curve
eponym.desc: Curve that estimates the probability of survival of a defined group at a designated time interval (conditional probability) based on a non-parametric survival function.

eponym.name: Kaposi's sarcoma
eponym.desc: Low-grade vascular tumor associated with HHV-8, four forms, classic (older men of Mediterranean or Jewish extraction), African, organ transplant-associated, and AIDS; differential for skin lesions includes bacillary angiomatosis from Bartonella.

eponym.name: Kartagener's syndrome
eponym.desc: A triad of sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and situs inversus; also associated with ciliary dysfunction; Manes Kartagener, Swiss physician, 1897-1975.

eponym.name: Kasabach-Merritt syndrome
eponym.desc: Capillary hemangioma or hemangioendothelioma associated with thrombocytopenic purpura and extensive and progressively enlarging vascular malformations which may involve large portions of their extremities; bleeding commonly develops in the first year of life, secondary to chronic DIC triggered by stagnant blood flow through the tortuous abnormal vessels; anemia caused by red cell damage as blood passes through deformed vessels of the tumor.

eponym.name: Kasai procedure
eponym.desc: For treating biliary atresia, hepatoportoenterostomy, with biliary drainage created from small intestine.

eponym.name: Kashin-Beck disease
eponym.desc: Deforming arthritis associated with selenium deficiency, identified in an area of China and Tibet where soil is extremely low in selenium; iodine deficiency risk factor.

eponym.name: Katayama fever
eponym.desc: Acute schistosomiasis, after Katayama valley in Japan where S. japonicum endemic; seen in travelers but not in native people because of exposure in utero. Symptoms of prostration, fever, sweats, myalgia, and diarrhea.

eponym.name: Kawasaki's disease
eponym.desc: Acute febrile illness of infants and children, characterized by cutaneous and mucosal erythema and edema with subsequent desquamation, cervical lymphadenitis, and complicated by coronary artery aneurysms (20%); associated with antiendothelial antibodies.

eponym.name: Kayser-Fleischer rings
eponym.desc: A greenish yellow pigmented ring encircling the cornea just within the corneoscleral margin, seen in hepatolenticular degeneration, due to copper deposited in Desçemet's membrane (posterior limiting layer of cornea); seen in Wilson's disease (with neurologic involvement) and other cholestatic hepatic diseases.

eponym.name: Kearns-Sayre syndrome
eponym.desc: A mitochondrial disease with progressive ophthalmoplegia, retinal pigmentation degeneration, heart block; caused by various mitochondrial DNA mutations.

eponym.name: Kegel exercises
eponym.desc: Exercises for strengthening pelvic muscles in order to increase urethral closure mechanism in urinary incontinence.

eponym.name: Kehr's sign
eponym.desc: Pain in the left shoulder associated with splenic rupture.

eponym.name: Kell blood group system
eponym.desc: Red blood cell antigen, named after Mrs. Kelleher, pregnant woman in whom anti-K was discovered by Coombs in 1946; function of antigens in this system are unknown.

eponym.name: Kellgren's arthritis
eponym.desc: Severe form of primary osteoarthritis, erosive osteoarthritis, associated with severe osteoporosis of hands.

eponym.name: Kelly's sign
eponym.desc: Visible peristalsis of the ureter in response to squeezing or retraction; used to identify the ureter during surgery.

eponym.name: Kennedy syndrome
eponym.desc: X-linked spinobulbar muscular atrophy; from CAG repeat expansion encoding androgen receptor; leads to distal limb amyotrophy, bulbar signs, fasiculations prominent, androgen insensitivity with gynecomastia, testicular atrophy, and oligospermia.

eponym.name: Kenny-Caffey syndrome
eponym.desc: Skeletal disorder with osteosclerosis and recurrent bacterial infections. Associated with mutation in tubulin-specific chaperone E. Mutation in same gene associated with Sanjad-Sakati syndrome.

eponym.name: Kent, bundle of
eponym.desc: AV bypass accessory tract in Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome that directly connects atrial and ventricular myocardium.

eponym.name: Kerandel's hyperesthesia
eponym.desc: In African trypanosomiasis, excruciating pain after minor soft-tissue injury, e.g. in palms and ulnar region.

eponym.name: Kerckring's valves
eponym.desc: Plicae circulares, found in lining of small intestine.

eponym.name: Kerley A lines
eponym.desc: In pulmonary edema, thin nonbranching lines several inches in length, radiating from hila, and not following the course of vessels or airways, attributed to thickening of connective tissue sheets which contain communicating perivenous and bronchoarterial lymphatics.

eponym.name: Kerley B lines
eponym.desc: In pulmonary edema, transverse lines 1-3 cm in length and 1-2 mm in width, arranged in a horizontal stepladder pattern, 0.5-1 cm apart along the lower lateral lung margins, extending to the pleura; lines visible in this area because pulmonary lobules are well-developed in this area and lines reflect thickening of, or fluid in, lymphatic vessels in interlobular septa; also seen in lymphangitic spread of malignancies.

eponym.name: Kerley C lines
eponym.desc: In pulmonary edema, fine interlacing lines throughout the lung base producing a spider web appearance; controversial if unique lines v. crossing lines.

eponym.name: Kernig sign
eponym.desc: In meningeal irritation (as in meningitis), flexion of patient's leg at both hip and knee and then straightening of knee associated with pain and increased resistance to extending knee.

eponym.name: Kernohan notch
eponym.desc: Focal impression against the cerebral peduncle; pressure against notch seen in uncal herniation.

eponym.name: Kerr incision
eponym.desc: Low transverse uterine incision for caesarian section.

eponym.name: Keshan disease
eponym.desc: Endemic cardiomyopathy in China associated with selenium deficiency.

eponym.name: Keutel syndrome
eponym.desc: Malformation syndrome characterized by multiple pulmonary stenoses, neural hearing loss, short terminal phalanges, and calcifications and/or ossification of the cartilage in ears, nose larynx, trachea, and ribs; due to mutation in gene encoding human matrix Gla protein.

eponym.name: Kew Gardens spotted fever
eponym.desc: Rickettsialpox due to Rickettsia akari, from Kew Gardens, New York.

eponym.name: Kidd blood group system
eponym.desc: Named after Mrs. Kidd, pregnant woman in whom anti-Jka was discovered by Allen in 1951; antigens in this system are located on a red cell urea transporter.

eponym.name: Kienböck disease
eponym.desc: Osteonecrosis of the carpal lunate that most commonly affects men between ages 20-40; sometimes history of trauma; may lead to end-stage arthritis of wrist with progression.

eponym.name: Kiesselbach's plexus
eponym.desc: Vascular plexus on the anterior nasal septum, bleeding from this plexus associated with most common form of epistaxis.

eponym.name: Kikuchi's disease
eponym.desc: Histiocytic necrotizing lymphadenitis, characterized by cervical lymphadenopathy with tenderness, fever, and night sweats; tends to occur in young women; histology can be confused with lymphoma.

eponym.name: Killian-Jamieson area
eponym.desc: Region between oblique and transvere fibers of the cricopharyngeus muscle; potential area for muscular dehisence and Zenker's diverticulum.

eponym.name: Killip class
eponym.desc: Described in 1967, in myocardial infarction, class I, no heart failure, 0.5% mortality; class II, S3 and/or basal lung crepitations, 2.2% mortality; class III, acute pulmonary edema, 19.2% mortality; class IV, cardiogenic shock, 61.3% mortality (mortality rates current).

eponym.name: Kimmelstiel-Wilson disease
eponym.desc: Intercapillary glomerulosclerosis from diabetes; lesion is PAS-positive material deposited at periphery of glomerular tufts.

eponym.name: Kimura's disease
eponym.desc: Chronic inflammatory condition with large subcutaneous masses on head or neck of Asian males associated with eosinophilia.

eponym.name: Klatskin tumors
eponym.desc: Tumors arising from the part of the common bile duct between the cystic duct junction and the confluence of the right and left hepatic ducts at the liver hilus; notable for their slow growing behavior, marked sclerosing characteristics, and the infrequent occurrence of distal metastases.

eponym.name: Kleihauer-Betke test
eponym.desc: Testing for the presence of fetal blood cells in maternal circulation.

eponym.name: Kleine-Levin syndrome
eponym.desc: A rare form of periodic hypersomnia, occurring in males aged 10 to 25 years, characterized by periods of ravenous binge eating alternating with prolonged sleep (as long as 18 hours), along with behavioral disturbances, impaired thought processes, and hallucinations; acute illness or fatigue may precede an episode, which may occur as often as several times a year; thought to be a disorder of hypothalamically mediated satiety.

eponym.name: Klein-Waardenburg syndrome
eponym.desc: See Waardenburg's syndrome type III.

eponym.name: Klinefelter syndrome
eponym.desc: XXY, first described in 1942 as constellation of enlarged breasts, sparse facial and body hair, small testes, long bone abnormality, and an inability to produce sperm; occurs in 1/500 to 1/1000 births.

eponym.name: Klinger disease
eponym.desc: Wegener's granulomatosis; first described by Heinz Klinger in 1931 as a medical student and then described by Friederic Wegener in 1936.

eponym.name: Klippel-Feil syndrome
eponym.desc: Congenital fusion of two or more cervical vertebrae, producing a low posterior hairline, decreased movement, and a short neck that displaces the head anteriorly and inferiorly.

eponym.name: Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome
eponym.desc: Congenital condition characterized by port-wine stain (cutaneous capillary hemangiomas), soft tissue and bony hypertrophy, and venous malformations and lymphatic abnormalities, usually limited to one limb.

eponym.name: Klippel-Trenaunay-Weber syndrome
eponym.desc: Association of Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome with AV fistula; affects Casey Martin, golfer in disability case brought to U.S. Supreme Court 2001 against PGA.

eponym.name: Klumpke's palsy
eponym.desc: Lower plexus palsy affecting C8-T1 nerve roots; may occur during birth trauma.

eponym.name: Klüver-Bucy syndrome
eponym.desc: Behavioral disorder from bilateral temporal lobe dysfunction, characterized by a flattening of emotions, increased oral tendencies, hypersexuality, compulsive tendency to react to every object, failed to recognize familiar objects. Observed in 1937 following experimental bilateral removal of temporal lobe (including amygdala and hippocampal formation) in monkeys.

eponym.name: Kniest dysplasia
eponym.desc: Autosomal dominant metatropic dwarfism associated with mutation in COL2A1.

eponym.name: Kobberling's syndrome
eponym.desc: Familial partial lipodystrophy affecting adipose tissue in extremities and normal adipose tissue elsewhere.

eponym.name: Kocher's incision
eponym.desc: Right subcostal incision for open cholecystectomy.

eponym.name: Kocher's maneuver
eponym.desc: Dissection of the duodenum from the right-sided peritoneal attachment to allow mobilization and visualization of the back of the duodenum and pancreas.

eponym.name: Kocher's maneuver
eponym.desc: For closed reduction of anterior shoulder dislocation, traction to the elbow with external rotation of the humerus and adduction of elbow towards chest; however not generally recommended because of association with neurovascular complications and proximal humerus fractures.

eponym.name: Kocher's test
eponym.desc: Compression of lateral lobes of thyroid causing stridor; associated with thyroid carcinoma, goiter, or thyroiditis.

eponym.name: Koch's bacillus
eponym.desc: Tuberculosis bacillus.

eponym.name: Koch's postulates
eponym.desc: Criteria for linking a specific microorganism to a disease 1. organism must be found in lesion of disease; 2. organism can be isolated in single colonies on a single medium; 3. inoculation of culture causes lesion in experimental animals; 4. organism can be recovered from lesions in these animals.

eponym.name: Koebner's phenomenon
eponym.desc: Referring to physical trauma (rubbing or scratching) as a major factor in eliciting psoriasis lesions; also depigmented, sharply demarcated papules in vitiligo following minor trauma; may also be seen in lichen planus.

eponym.name: Koeppe's nodules
eponym.desc: Projections into the pupil seen in sarcoidosis, tuberculosis, and other uveitides.

eponym.name: Köhler's disease
eponym.desc: Aseptic necrosis or osteochondrosis of the navicular bone.

eponym.name: Kohn, pores of
eponym.desc: Connections between lung alveoli.

eponym.name: Kojewnikoff syndrome
eponym.desc: Epilepsia partialis continua (simple partial status epilepticus).

eponym.name: Kommerell diverticulum
eponym.desc: Anomaly where left subclavian artery arises from this diverticulum on the aortic arch as the 4th branch and passes behind the esophagus to the left arm; can be rarely associated with dysphagia.

eponym.name: Koplik's spots
eponym.desc: Small, white spots (often on an reddened background) that occur on the inside of the cheeks early in the course of measles; considered to be pathognomonic exanthem in measles. See also Fordyce's spots.

eponym.name: Korotkoff sounds
eponym.desc: Sounds heard in between systolic and diastolic pressure; origin related to the spurt of blood passing under the cuff and meeting a static column of blood; I, first appearance of low-frequency tapping sounds; II, softer and longer sounds; III, crisper and louder sounds; IV, muffled and softer sounds; V, complete disappearance of sounds.

eponym.name: Korsakoff's syndrome
eponym.desc: From thiamine deficiency accompanying alcoholism, profound memory loss; mammillary bodies as well as portions of medial thalamus believed to be destroyed.

eponym.name: Kostmann syndrome
eponym.desc: Severe congenital neutropenia, associated with mutation in ELA2 (elastase). Characterized typically by a granulopoeisis impairment at the promyelocyte stage; risk of evolution to MDS or AML, responds to G-CSF.

eponym.name: Kounis syndrome
eponym.desc: Allergic or hypersensitivity reaction associated with acute coronary syndrome.

eponym.name: Krabbe's disease
eponym.desc: Autosomal recessive sphingolipidosis (sulfatidose), from beta-galactosidase deficiency, resulting in increased galactocerebrosides, mental retardation, blindness, deafness, paralysis, convulsions, total absence of myelin, globoid bodies in white matter of brain, fatal in early life.

eponym.name: Kraissl's lines
eponym.desc: Lines of skin tension, defined in living individuals (and e.g. correlate with wrinkle lines in face). Wounds made parallel to Kraissl's line are felt to heal better. See also Langer's lines. Described by Kraissl in 1951 (Plast Reconst Surg 8:1).

eponym.name: Krause's end-bulbs
eponym.desc: Sensory receptors for cold.

eponym.name: Krebs cycle
eponym.desc: Citric acid cycle or tricarboxylic acid cycle; central metabolic pathway that takes place in mitochondria involved in catabolism of carbohydrates and fat and generation of ATP; after Sir Krebs who proposed pathway in 1937.

eponym.name: Krukenberg's tumor
eponym.desc: Ovarian metastasis of stomach cancer; characterized by signet ring cancer cells. May also seen in malignancies from colon, breast, and other mucin-gland organs.

eponym.name: Kübler-Ross dying stages
eponym.desc: (1) Denial and isolation, (2) anger, (3) bargaining, (4) depression, (5) acceptance; described in 1969 by Elisabeth Kübler-Ross.

eponym.name: Kufs disease
eponym.desc: Adult neuronal ceroid lipofuscinosis, CLN4.

eponym.name: Kugelberg-Welander disease
eponym.desc: See under Wohlfart-Kugelberg-Welander disease.

eponym.name: Kulchitsky's cells
eponym.desc: Neuroendocrine argentaffin cells present along the bronchial epithelium, particularly in the fetus and neonate; small cell carcinoma has granules similar to Kulchitsky's cells; felt to be origin of carcinoid tumors.

eponym.name: Kupffer cells
eponym.desc: Phagocytic cells of the mononuclear phagocyte series found on the luminal surface of endothelial cells in hepatic sinusoids; they metabolize old red blood cells, digest hemoglobin.

eponym.name: Kussmaul-Maier disease
eponym.desc: Former name for polyarteritis nodosa.

eponym.name: Kussmaul's respiration
eponym.desc: Hyperpnea, associated with acidosis, especially diabetic ketoacidosis, but may also be seen in uremia.

eponym.name: Kussmaul's sign
eponym.desc: Jugular vein distension during inspiration (reversal of normal pattern of decreasing jugular venous pressure during inspiration); classically seen in constrictive pericarditis because of normal increase in venous return with increased abdominal pressure from diaphragmatic contraction leading to increase in right atrial pressure from non-complaint right ventricle. Most common contemporary cause is severe right-sided heart failure (JAMA 1996: 275:632). Sign absent generally in cardiac tamponade.

eponym.name: Kveim antigen
eponym.desc: Saline suspension of human sarcoid tissue prepared from spleen (or liver or lymph node) of an individual with active sarcoidosis; used in Kveim-Sitzbach test.

eponym.name: Kveim-Siltzbach test
eponym.desc: An intradermal test for the detection of sarcoidosis, done by injecting Kveim antigen and examining skin biopsies after 3 and 6 weeks; positive test, a noncaseating granulomatous reaction; sensitivity 35-88%, specificity 75-99% Morton A. Kveim, Norwegian dermatologist, born 1892.

eponym.name: Kyrle disease
eponym.desc: Chronic generalized dermatosis, formation of large papules with central keratin plugs; associated with diabetes mellitus and renal failure.

eponym.name: La Crosse encephalitis
eponym.desc: Transmitted by tree hole mosquito, Aedes trisereiatus and causes most common arboviral infection in children in N. America; hyponatremia and fever associated with worse outcome. Discovered in La Crosse, Wisconsin in 1963.

eponym.name: Lachman maneuver
eponym.desc: For diagnosing anterior cruciate ligament tear, pull on tibia in anterior direction with knee flexed at 20-25 degrees (if tibia slides anteriorly >2 mm, positive).

eponym.name: Ladin's sign
eponym.desc: A sign of pregnancy, an area of elasticity on the anterior face of the uterus just above the cervix; felt on palpation through the vagina as early as the 5th or 6th week of pregnancy.

eponym.name: Lady Windermere syndrome
eponym.desc: Mycobacterium avium complex pulmonary disease described in fastidious elderly women in the dependent portion of the lingula or the right middle lobe due to proposed habitual voluntary suppression of cough leading to the development of nonspecific inflammatory processes in these poorly draining lung regions. Chest 1992;101:1605-9.

eponym.name: Laennec's cirrhosis
eponym.desc: In alcoholic cirrhosis, residual parenchymal nodules that protrude like "hobnails" from the surface of the liver.

eponym.name: Lafora's disease
eponym.desc: Progressive myoclonus epilepsy, autosomal recessive, onset teenage years, characterized by seizures and cumulative neurological deterioration, death usually within ten years of first symptoms; associated with intracellular inclusions (Lafora bodies); associated with mutation in gene EPM2A.

eponym.name: Laimer triangle
eponym.desc: Area defined by cricopharyngeus muscle and esophageal muscles.

eponym.name: Laki-Lorand factor
eponym.desc: Factor XIII.

eponym.name: Lambert, canals of
eponym.desc: Direct accessory bronchioalveolar connections.

eponym.name: Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome
eponym.desc: Disease of neuromuscular junction associated with paraneoplastic process with proximal muscle weakness that improves with repetitive stimulation; associated with P/Q type presynaptic voltage-gated calcium channel antibodies; 70% have malignancy, usually small cell cancer.

eponym.name: Lambl's excrescences
eponym.desc: Small filiform or lamellar lesions on aortic valve leaflets, first described in 1856 .

eponym.name: Lance-Adams syndrome
eponym.desc: Post hypoxic monoclonus.

eponym.name: Lancisi's sign
eponym.desc: Giant V waves in tricuspid regurgitation.

eponym.name: Landau-Kleffner syndrome
eponym.desc: Acquired epileptic aphasia; childhood disorder characterized by auditory verbal agnosia, aphasia, and seizures.

eponym.name: Landolfi's sign
eponym.desc: In aortic regurgitation, systolic contraction and diastolic dilation of the pupil.

eponym.name: Landsteiner-Weiner blood group system
eponym.desc: After Landsteiner and Weiner who discovered this antigen system; injected Rhesus monkey red blood cells into guinea pigs producing an antibody thought to recognize the antigen D described by Levine in 1939. Later discovered that these antibodies did not recognize D but rather an antigen that is strongly expressed on Rh positive red cells and weakly expressed on Rh negative red blood cells; antigens located on an intercellular adhesion molecule for CD11/CD18.

eponym.name: Langerhans cell
eponym.desc: Member of class of bone marrow-derived dendritic cells; antigen-presenting cell; differs from other histiocytes by being CD1a-positive.

eponym.name: Langerhans cell histiocytosis
eponym.desc: Encompasses histiocytosis-X, eosinophilic granuloma, Letterer-Siwe disease, and Hand-Schüller-Christian triad.

eponym.name: Langerhans granules
eponym.desc: See Birbeck granules.

eponym.name: Langer's lines
eponym.desc: Lines used for elective incisions, developed by Karl Langer, an anatomy professor, from cadavers in rigor mortis. Incisions made parallel to Langer's lines felt to heal better with less scarring. Believed to lie parallel to collagen fibers. By contrast, see Kraissl's lines.

eponym.name: Laplace's law
eponym.desc: Wall tension = pressure x radius. Explains colon perforation preferentially at the cecum because of the increased radius and resultant increased wall tension.

eponym.name: Laron dwarfism
eponym.desc: Autosomal recessive, dwarfism from growth hormone receptor defect leading to failure to produce IGF-1.

eponym.name: Lasègue's sign
eponym.desc: In lumbar root or sciatic nerve irritation, when patient is supine with hip flexed, dorsiflexion of ankle causing pain or muscle spasm in the posterior thigh.

eponym.name: Lassa fever
eponym.desc: Hemorrhagic fever caused by Lassa virus, first isolated in 1969 in Lassa, Nigeria, an arenavirus, spread through contact with secretions (e.g., urine) from infected rats; fatality 15-20% of hospitalized patients; can be treated with ribavirin.

eponym.name: Laterjet, nerve of
eponym.desc: Branch of vagus nerve thought to carry nerves specifically to antrum of stomach.

eponym.name: Laurence-Moon syndrome
eponym.desc: Mental retardation, pigmentary retinopathy, hypogenitalism, and spastic paraplegia; distinct from Bardet-Biedl syndrome.

eponym.name: Lawrence-Seip syndrome
eponym.desc: Two forms: congenital lipodystrophy and acquired generalized lipodystrophy; general disappearance after birth (generally during childhood and may occur following infections); associated with acanthosis nigricans, excess body hair, enlargement of genitalia, diabetes.

eponym.name: Leber hereditary optic neuropathy
eponym.desc: Mitochondrial DNA disease, progressive bilateral loss of central vision, presents 15-35 y.o, associated with cardiac conduction defects and minor neurological manifestations.

eponym.name: Leeuwenhoek syndrome
eponym.desc: Respiratory myoclonus characterized by intermittent fits of involuntary spasms of the diaphragm and accessory muscles of respiration. Differentiated from hiccups because in hiccups the glottis is closed, while in respiratory myoclonus it is open causing air to rush in with each diaphragmatic contraction. Described by the microscopist Leeuwenhoek in 1723.

eponym.name: LeFort I fracture
eponym.desc: Transverse maxillary fracture above dental apices, which also traverses pterygoid plate; nasal complex stable.

eponym.name: LeFort II fracture
eponym.desc: Fracture through frontal process of maxilla, through orbital floor, and pterygoid plate; midface is mobile.

eponym.name: LeFort III fracture
eponym.desc: Complete craniofacial separation; different from LeFort II in that it extends through the nasofrontal suture and frontozygomatic sutures.

eponym.name: Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease
eponym.desc: Self-limiting hip disorder of children, 4-8 y.o. (M:F 8:1) involving vascular compromise of the capital femoral epiphysis and leading to aseptic necrosis. Also can affect small dogs.

eponym.name: Legionnaire's disease
eponym.desc: Pneumonia caused by Legionella species, aerobic gram-negative bacilli that do not grow on routine bacteriologic media; first identified in 1976 during outbreak at American Legion Convention in Philadelphia.

eponym.name: Leigh's disease
eponym.desc: Autosomal recessive disorder from defects in mitochondrial pathway for converting pyruvate to ATP, leading to lactic acidemia, developmental problems, seizures, involvement of periaqueductal gray area, extraocular palsies, weakness, hypotonia, death within 1 to 2 years.

eponym.name: Leiner's disease
eponym.desc: Seborrheic erythroderma associated with diarrhea and failure to thrive and to generate C5a chemotactic factor.

eponym.name: Lemierre's syndrome
eponym.desc: Oropharyngeal infection (usually by anaerobe Fusobacterium necrophorum) complicated by internal jugular vein thrombosis and metastatic abscesses in lung, characterized by spiking fevers, tenderness of sternocleidomastoids. See ring enhancement with central lucency in internal jugular vein on CT.

eponym.name: Lenègre's disease
eponym.desc: Sclerodegenerative disease of conduction system, particularly of right bundle branch and left anterior fasicle in people over 50; associated with slow progression to complete heart block. Also known as Lev's disease.

eponym.name: Lenk's triad
eponym.desc: In retroperitoneal hemorrhage, flank pain, a palpable tender mass, and signs of internal bleeding (e.g. hematuria).

eponym.name: Lennox-Gastaut syndrome
eponym.desc: Childhood seizure disorder associated with multiple seizure types (including drop attacks, atypical absences general tonic clonic seizures, and myoclonus), slow generalized spike-and-slow-wave EEG, mental retardation, and resistant to standard anti-epileptic medications.

eponym.name: Leopold's maneuver
eponym.desc: At 28 weeks, four sequential palpations of gravid abdomen to determine the position of the fetus.

eponym.name: leprechaunism
eponym.desc: 1 in 4 million births, associated with elfin-like facies, decreased subcutaneous. adipose tissue, acanthosis nigricans, and growth retardation, failure to thrive, and early death, insulin resistance. From defect in insulin receptor. Also known as Donohue syndrome.

eponym.name: Leriche's syndrome
eponym.desc: Aortoiliac occlusive disease producing distal ischemic symptoms and signs, e.g. pulseless femoral artery: (1) claudication of buttocks, (2) impotence, (3) atrophy of buttocks (seen with iliac occlusive disease).

eponym.name: Leri-Weill syndrome
eponym.desc: Dyschondrosteosis; a short stature syndrome characterized by mesomelic shortening of the forearms and lower legs and by bilateral Madelung deformity of the wrists.

eponym.name: Lesch-Nyhan syndrome
eponym.desc: X-linked disorder leading to absence of hypoxanthine guanine phosphoribosyl transferase (HGPRT, involved in salvage pathway in purine synthesis), associated with hyperuricemia, severe neurologic deficits with mental retardation, self-mutilation, and in some cases gouty arthritis.

eponym.name: Leser-Trélat sign
eponym.desc: Sudden appearance and rapid increase in the number and size of seborrheic keratoses with pruritus; associated with internal malignancy.

eponym.name: Letterer-Siwe disease
eponym.desc: Acute disseminated Langerhans cell histocytosis; associated with development of cutaneous lesions that resemble a seborrheic eruption secondary to infiltrations of Langerhans' histiocytes over the front and back of the trunk and on the scalp; concurrent hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, pulmonary lesions, and eventually destructive osteolytic bone lesions.

eponym.name: LeVeen shunt
eponym.desc: For treating refractory ascites, peritoneovenous shunt connecting peritoneum and central venous system, compare with Denver shunt; LeVeen shunt uses disc valve in firm polypropylene casing.

eponym.name: Levine's sign
eponym.desc: When describing angina, use of clenched fist over sternum; described by Samuel A. Levine, U.S. cardiologist, 1891-1966. Levine sign itself 14% sensitive for cardiac pain (BMJ 1995;311:1660).

eponym.name: Levinthal paradox
eponym.desc: Magnitude of conformational search problem in protein folding; an unbiased search for all possible protein conformations would take a lifetime, yet proteins fold in microseconds to minutes.

eponym.name: Lev's disease
eponym.desc: Complete heart block from fibrosis or calcification extending from cardiac fibrous structures into the conduction system. Also known as Lenègre's disease.

eponym.name: Lewis blood group system
eponym.desc: Named after Mrs. Lewis, pregnant woman in whom anti-Lea was discovered by Mourant in 1946; function of antigens in this system are unknown.

eponym.name: Lewy bodies
eponym.desc: Eosinophilic intracytoplasmic bodies of alpha synuclein in neurons of substantia nigra and locus ceruleus present in Parkinson's disease.

eponym.name: Lewy body dementia
eponym.desc: Most common dementia associated with Parkinson's disease characterized by Lewy bodies found in brain stem and cortex. Visual hallucinations may be exacerbated by the treatment for parkinsonism.

eponym.name: Leydig cell tumors
eponym.desc: Testicular tumor derived from the stroma, may find Reinke crystals.

eponym.name: Lhermitte-Duclos disease
eponym.desc: Dysplastic cerebellar gangliocytoma; associated with germ line PTEN mutations; felt to be a part of multiple hamartoma syndrome or Cowden's syndrome.

eponym.name: Lhermitte's sign
eponym.desc: Sudden electric-like shocks extending down the spine on flexing the head; may result from posterior column lesion, toxic effects of radiation. Seen in 3% of multiple sclerosis. Also may be found in vitamin B6 toxicity, vitamin B12 deficiency.

eponym.name: Libman-Sacks disease
eponym.desc: In systemic lupus erythematosus, intense mitral and tricuspid valvulitis with development of small, sterile vegetations.

eponym.name: Lichtenberg's figures
eponym.desc: Branching pattern of cutaneous marks pathognomonic for lightning injury.

eponym.name: Liddle's syndrome
eponym.desc: Severe low renin hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis that mimics hyperaldosteronism but found to have low aldosterone levels; due to constitutively activating autosomal dominant mutation in beta subunit of epithelial sodium channel.

eponym.name: Lieberkühn, crypts of
eponym.desc: Intestinal glands found between villi.

eponym.name: Li-Fraumeni syndrome
eponym.desc: Cancer predisposition syndrome from mutant p53 allele, predisposition toward breast carcinomas, sarcomas, leukemia, brain tumors, and adrenocortical carcinoma; half have tumors before age 30, 70% before age 90. Autosomal dominant.

eponym.name: Light's criteria
eponym.desc: For distinguishing transudate v. exudate in pleural fluid: if at least one of the criteria is present, fluid virtually always an exudate: (1) pleural fluid/serum protein ratio > 0.5; (2) pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH ratio > 0.6; (3) pleural fluid LDH > 2/3 upper limit of normal serum LDH. Ann Intern Med 1972; 77:507.

eponym.name: Likoff's syndrome
eponym.desc: In young women (30s-50s), presence of chest pain with abnormal EKG but with normal coronary angiograms (N Engl J Med1967;276:1063).

eponym.name: Linton test
eponym.desc: Modification of Perthes test, elevation of leg with patient supine and tourniquet in place; if veins fail to drain, implies venous obstruction.

eponym.name: Lipschultz ulcer
eponym.desc: Vulvar ulcer.

eponym.name: Lisch nodules
eponym.desc: In type I neurofibromatosis, pigmented iris hamartomas.

eponym.name: Lisfranc fracture
eponym.desc: Fracture and dislocation involving the joints of the midfoot. Named after French surgeon Jacques Lisfranc de St. Martin, in Napoleon's army, for the amputation at this location.

eponym.name: Lisfranc joint
eponym.desc: Joint located just above the arch of the foot, between the tarsal and metatarsal bones.

eponym.name: Lisker's sign
eponym.desc: In thrombophlebitis or deep vein thrombosis, tenderness to percussion of the medial anterior tibial surface.

eponym.name: Lissauer's tract
eponym.desc: Small diameter primary sensory axons (presumably mediating pain and temperature senses) on their way into the dorsal horn.

eponym.name: Litten's sign
eponym.desc: Diaphragmatic movement seen on one side but not the other side in unilateral phrenic nerve palsy.

eponym.name: Little's disease
eponym.desc: Cerebral palsy; specifically congenital spastic diplegia; described by English surgeon Little in 1843.

eponym.name: Littre's hernia
eponym.desc: Hernia involving a Meckel's diverticulum. Compare with Amyand's hernia, De Garengoet's hernia.

eponym.name: Loeys-Dietz syndrome
eponym.desc: Classic triad of craniofacial abnormalities, aortic aneurysm, and bifid uvula; autosomal dominant syndrome associated with high risk for aortic dissection at an early age; due to mutation in TGFBR1 (type 1) or TGFBR2 (type 2); see also Marfan syndrome.

eponym.name: Löffler's cardiomyopathy
eponym.desc: A form of restrictive cardiomyopathy, associated with eosinophilia; endocarditis parietalis fibroplastica.

eponym.name: Löffler's syndrome
eponym.desc: Simple pulmonary eosinophilia, characterized by transient pulmonary lesions, eosinophilia in the blood, and a benign clinical course. Lungs show alveoli with thickened septa from infiltrate composed of eosinophils and occasional interspersed giant cells, but no vasculitis, fibrosis, or necrosis. Associated with ascaris and strongyloides.

eponym.name: Löfgren's syndrome
eponym.desc: Sarcoidosis associated with triad of erythema nodosum, bilateral hilar adenopathy, and polyarthritis; 10-15% of sarcoidosis present this way.

eponym.name: Looser's zones
eponym.desc: In osteomalacia, radiolucent narrow lines that lie either at right angles or obliquely to the cortical outlines of bones and often transect them; bilateral and symmetric, found at the axillary margins of the scapula, lower ribs, neck of the proximal femurs, and posterior regions of the proximal ulnas; related either to stress fractures or to mechanical erosion by penetrating nutrient arteries; also known as Milkman's fractures.

eponym.name: Lorenzo's oil
eponym.desc: After Lorenzo Odone, diagnosed with adrenoleukodystrophy in 1984, a formulation of triglycerides of monounsaturated oleic acid and erucic acid 4:1, felt to reduce very long chain fatty acids to normal levels in ALD.

eponym.name: Lou Gehrig's disease
eponym.desc: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (in France, known as Charcot's disease).

eponym.name: Louis, angle of
eponym.desc: Sternal angle.

eponym.name: Louvel's sign
eponym.desc: In deep vein thrombosis, venous pain induced by coughing, prevented by pressing over proximal end of vein.

eponym.name: Lovibond's angle
eponym.desc: The angle made by the proximal nail fold and the nail plate.

eponym.name: Lowenberg's sign
eponym.desc: In deep vein thrombosis, two calves are wrapped with cuffs to see if there is asymetry in tolerance to pressure of 180 mm Hg.

eponym.name: Löwenstein-Jensen's medium
eponym.desc: For growing out M. tuberculosis; contains malachite green, a triphenlyamine die like crystal violent, inhibits growth of unwanted organisms during 6 week incubation period as well as complex nutrients.

eponym.name: Lowe's syndrome
eponym.desc: X-linked, oculocerebrorenal syndrome characterized by congenital cataracts, mental retardation, renal tubular acidosis type 2; from defect in lipid phosphatase, phosphatidylinositol 4,5 bisphosphate [PtdIns(4,5)P2]5-phosphatase, which localizes to the Golgi apparatus and is suspected to play a role in Golgi vesicular transport.

eponym.name: Lown-Ganong-Levine syndrome
eponym.desc: Cardiac preexcitation syndrome with enhanced AV node pathways, <0.12 s, no QRS widening, no delta waves.

eponym.name: Ludwig's angina
eponym.desc: Aggressive infectious process of the submandibular, sublingual, and submental fascial spaces frequently occurring as a result of infection from 2nd and 3rd lower molar; 54% mortality in preantibiotic era, now 4%. Described in 1836 by Wilhelm Frederick von Ludwig.

eponym.name: Lugol's solution
eponym.desc: 5% iodine and 10% KI, a dose of 6.3 mg of I per drop, for giving iodine.

eponym.name: Lundberg A wave
eponym.desc: In ICP monitoring, waves that have a duration of 5-20 minutes and an amplitude of 50 mm Hg over the baseline ICP, after which ICP is reset to a higher baseline level; sign of severely compromised intracranial compliance and can result in significant decrease in cerebral perfusion pressure and herniation.

eponym.name: Lund's node
eponym.desc: Lymph node found in Calot's triangle, aka Calot's node.

eponym.name: Luria's law
eponym.desc: Three antibiotics = 1 fungal infection.

eponym.name: Luschka, ducts of
eponym.desc: Small tubular channels found buried within the gallbladder wall adjacent to the liver, communicates with the biliary tree; rarely patent accessory bile secretory ducts.

eponym.name: Luschka, foramina of
eponym.desc: Two laterally placed foramens exiting out of fourth ventricle of the brain.

eponym.name: Lutembacher's syndrome
eponym.desc: Atrial septal defect with mitral stenosis. Congenital condition, though mitral stenosis may be acquired from rheumatic fever.

eponym.name: Lutheran blood group system
eponym.desc: Named after Mrs. Luteran, pregnant woman in whom anti-Lua was discovered by Cutbush in 1945; Cutbush assumed that the name on the sample had been misspelled, hence "Lutheran" instead of "Luteran"; function of antigens in this system unknown.

eponym.name: Lyell's syndrome
eponym.desc: Toxic epidermal necrolysis.

eponym.name: Lyme disease
eponym.desc: Inflammatory disease caused by spirochete Borrelia burgdorferi, spread by Ixodes tick, characterized by early local disease with erythema migrans, myalgias, followed by early disseminated disease with carditis, neurologic findings (lymphocytic meningitis, cranial nerve palsies, also see Bannwarth's syndrome), and late disease characterized by arthralgias and arthritis. Full syndrome recognized as Lyme diseased based on patients identified in Lyme, CT in 1975.

eponym.name: Lynch syndrome I
eponym.desc: Cancer family syndrome with multiple colon cancers 2 to 3 decades earlier, predilection for proximal colon; Lynch syndromes most common forms of familial colon cancer, 5-10% of all cases of colon cancer; better prognosis than sporadic colon cancer. Due to deficiency in mismatch repair genes in 85% of Lynch syndromes; autosomal dominant.

eponym.name: Lynch syndrome II
eponym.desc: Cancer family syndrome, all features of Lynch I with early onset of carcinoma at other sites including endometrium, ovaries, and stomach, also upper tract TCC.

eponym.name: Lyon hypothesis
eponym.desc: Only one of two X chromosomes is genetically active.

eponym.name: MacCallum's plaques
eponym.desc: Irregular thickenings, usually in the left atrium, from subendocardial lesions, usually exacerbated by regurgitant jets.

eponym.name: MacConkey medium
eponym.desc: Medium for growing nonfastidious Gram-negative rods.

eponym.name: Macewen's sign
eponym.desc: In hydrocephalus before closure of sutures, cracked pot sound when percussing over dilated ventricles.

eponym.name: Machado-Joseph disease
eponym.desc: Spinocerebellar ataxia 3, named for affected families of Azorean origin, autosomal dominant disorder caused by a CAG expansion in gene on 14q, onset after age 40, associated with diabetes.

eponym.name: Mackler triad
eponym.desc: In esophageal rupture, triad of vomiting, chest pain, and subcutaneous emphysema.

eponym.name: Macleod's syndrome
eponym.desc: Unilateral hyperlucent lung, see Swyer-James syndrome.

eponym.name: Maddrey discriminant function
eponym.desc: For predicting mortality in patients with alcoholic hepatitis, Maddrey DF = 4.6 x (PT-control PT) + serum bilirubin; DF > 32 associated with high short-term mortality, 1 month mort 35% in absence of encephalopathy and 45% if encephalopathy present.

eponym.name: Madelung deformity
eponym.desc: Growth disturbance in the volar-ulnar distal radius that results in bowing of the distal end of the radius, resulting in radius shorter than the ulna; presents mainly in adolescent females; also associated with variant of dwarfism, dyschondrosteosis.

eponym.name: Madelung's disease
eponym.desc: Benign symmetric lipomatosis; characterized by numerous, symmetrically distributed, non tender, poorly demarcated, fatty tumors; distributed mainly in vicinity of neck, sub-occipital region, proximal extremities, and upper part of trunk; can result in "horse-collar appearance."

eponym.name: Madura foot
eponym.desc: Actinomycetoma of the foot; chronic bacterial infection of subcutaneous tissue often due to traumatic injury (e.g. from walking barefoot). Nocardia usual organism. Madura is a city in southern India.

eponym.name: Maffucci's syndrome
eponym.desc: Enchondromatosis associated with soft tissue hemangiomas; associated with ovarian carcinomas and brain gliomas; essentially Ollier's disease with hemangiomas.

eponym.name: Magendie, foramen of
eponym.desc: Midline foramen exiting out of fourth ventricle of the brain.

eponym.name: Maisonneuve fracture
eponym.desc: Spiral fracture of the proximal third of the fibula associated with ankle fracture (rupture of the distal tibiofibular syndesmosis associated with fracture of the tibia and rupture of the deltoid ligament); usually from ankle eversion injury.

eponym.name: Majocchi granuloma
eponym.desc: Infection of hair follicle from dermatophyte; foreign body granuloma most commonly due to Trichophyton rubrum infection, e.g. in young women who frequently shave their legs.

eponym.name: Majocchi's disease
eponym.desc: Purpura annularis telangiectodes.

eponym.name: Mallory body
eponym.desc: "Alcoholic hyalin", an eosinophilic intracytoplasmic inclusion in liver cells that is characteristic of alcoholic liver disease but also seen in e.g., primary biliary cirrhosis, Wilson's disease, chronic cholestatic syndromes, focal nodular hyperplasia, and hepatocellular carcinoma. Inclusions composed largely of intermediate filaments of prekeratin.

eponym.name: Mallory-Weiss tears
eponym.desc: Small defects in gastroesophageal junction, from violent retching; originally described in the context of alcoholic gastritis, can lead to severe bleeding, 87% occur below gastroesophageal junction; bleeding stops 90% without intervention.

eponym.name: Malone procedure
eponym.desc: Creation of a continent appendicostomy or neoappendix as a conduit for irrigation of the colon as treatment for fecal incontinence due to pediatric anorectal malformations, spina bifida, chronic constipation, etc. as an alternative to rectal enemas.

eponym.name: Malta fever
eponym.desc: Brucellosis. Also known as Bang's disease.

eponym.name: Maltese cross
eponym.desc: Fat droplets in urine.

eponym.name: Mantoux test
eponym.desc: Test for tuberculosis with intradermal injection of purified protein derivative of tuberculin, 0.1 mL of 5 tuberculin units.

eponym.name: maple syrup urine disease
eponym.desc: Deficiency in branched-chain alpha ketoacid dehydrogenase resulting in increased levels of branched chain alpha amino acids and alpha-keto analogs in plasma and urine, 1:200,000, high mortality. Urine has characteristic maple syrup smell.

eponym.name: Marburg's disease
eponym.desc: Acute form of multiple sclerosis, fulminant and progressive.

eponym.name: Marchiafava-Bignami syndrome
eponym.desc: Seen in malnourished alcoholics, necrosis of corpus callosum and subcortical white matter leading acutely to chronically to dementia, spasticity, dysarthria, gait disorder, and coma.

eponym.name: Marcus Gunn pupil
eponym.desc: Afferent pupillary defect, pupil dilates instead of constricts because of optic nerve defect; named after Scottish ophthalmologist Robert Marcus Gunn.

eponym.name: Marfan's syndrome
eponym.desc: Autosomal dominant, 1/10,000-1/20,000, from mutation in fibrillin-1 gene, associated with long limbs, dislocated lenses, and aortic root dilatation; 50% of children have dilatation of aorta; see also Loeys-Dietz syndrome.

eponym.name: Marie's sign
eponym.desc: Fine tremor in hyperthyroidism.

eponym.name: Marie-Strümpell disease
eponym.desc: Refers to ankylosing spondylitis in Europe.

eponym.name: Marine-Lenhart disease
eponym.desc: Co-existence of TSH-dependent nodules and Graves's disease.

eponym.name: Marion's disease
eponym.desc: Congenital obstruction of the posterior urethra.

eponym.name: Marjolin's ulcer
eponym.desc: Squamous cell carcinoma ulceration overlying chronic osteomyelitis or burn scar.

eponym.name: Markesbery distal myopathy
eponym.desc: Distal myopathy associated with rimmed vacuoles.

eponym.name: Markle sign
eponym.desc: Jar tenderness in abdomen from heel drop as a localizing sign of peritoneal irritation; described in 1973.

eponym.name: Maroni sign
eponym.desc: Erythema of the skin overlying thyroid in hyperthyroidism.

eponym.name: Maroteaux-Lamy syndrome
eponym.desc: Mucopolysaccharidosis (VI) from arylsulfatase B deficiency leading to accumulation of dermatan sulfate characterized by skeletal dysplasia, corneal clouding, coarse facies, valvular heart disease.

eponym.name: Marshall syndrome
eponym.desc: Pediatric condition characterized by periodic fever, aphthous stomatitis, pharyngitis, cervical adenitis (PFAPA); origins of syndrome unknown.

eponym.name: Marshall syndrome
eponym.desc: Dominantly inherited chondrodysplasias characterized by midfacial hypoplasia, high myopia, and sensorineural hearing deficit, from mutation in COL11A1; similar to Stickler syndrome.

eponym.name: Marshall, vein of
eponym.desc: Oblique vein of left atrium.

eponym.name: Marshall-Smith syndrome
eponym.desc: Accelerated skeletal maturation, failure to thrive, and dysmorphic facial features with death in early infancy or childhood from pulmonary infections.

eponym.name: Martin-Gruber anastomosis
eponym.desc: Anatomic anomaly where there is a branch from the median to ulnar nerve in the forearm, innervating 1st dorsal interosseus, adductor pollicis, and abductor digiti minimi, seen in 10-44% of population.

eponym.name: Martin-Lewis agar
eponym.desc: Variant of chocolate agar medium for growing Neisseria.

eponym.name: Martorell's ulcer
eponym.desc: Punched out ulcers found on anterior external aspect of leg between middle and lower third of limb. Sharply demarcated, with surrounding halo of erythema, very painful, often crusted, relieved by placing leg in dependent position, . Associated with poorly controlled hypertension.

eponym.name: Mary Walker effect
eponym.desc: Effect of physostigmine reversing the effects of myasthenia gravis; described in 1934; Mary Walker, an assistant medical officer at St. Alfege's Hospital in Greenwich England 1920-1936.

eponym.name: Masson body
eponym.desc: Granulation tissue plug found in lumen of small airways in bronchiolitis obliterans obstructive pneumonia (BOOP).

eponym.name: Mattox maneuver
eponym.desc: For gaining access to the retroperitoneal structures (including aorta), left medium visceral rotation.

eponym.name: Matuhasi-Ogata phenomenon
eponym.desc: Non-specific binding of IgG to red blood cells due to the presence of other antibodies binding RBC surface.

eponym.name: Maurer's dots
eponym.desc: Seen in P. falcipirum, stippling of erythrocytes.

eponym.name: Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser syndrome
eponym.desc: Absence of vagina from abnormality of müllerian development.

eponym.name: Mayer's reflex
eponym.desc: Basal joint reflex; adduction of the thumb in response to flexion of the metacarpophalngeal joint of the ring finger in a person with a relaxed hand, a normal finding, a normal finding, but may be absent in pyramidal lesions.

eponym.name: May-Hegglin anomaly
eponym.desc: Neutrophils with large pale blue inclusions resembling Döhle bodies, giant platelets (30-80 fL v. 7-10 normally), variable thrombocytopenia; rare autosomal dominant asymptomatic trait.

eponym.name: Mayne's sign
eponym.desc: In aortic regurgitation, decrease in diastolic pressure of 15 mm Hg when arm is held above the head; of questionable utility since observed in 65% of normal people.

eponym.name: Mayo, veins of
eponym.desc: Vein overlying pylorus.

eponym.name: May-Thurner syndromne
eponym.desc: Iliofemoral deep vein thrombosis from impaired venous return due to compression of the left common iliac vein by overlying right common iliac artery.

eponym.name: Mazzotti reaction
eponym.desc: Reaction to proteins released by dying onchocerca, including fevers, rashes, ocular damage, joint and muscle pain, and lymphangitis as well as hypotension, pyrexia, respiratory distress, and prostration.

eponym.name: McArdle's syndrome
eponym.desc: glycogen storage disease V, deficiency in muscle phosphorylase, with consequent glycogen accumulation in skeletal muscle, produces painful muscle cramps and muscle weakness following exercise.

eponym.name: McBurney's point
eponym.desc: One-third the distance from the anterior superior iliac spine to the umbilicus. This location corresponds to the most common location of the base of the appendix.

eponym.name: McBurney's sign
eponym.desc: In appendicitis, tenderness at McBurney's point.

eponym.name: McConnell's sign
eponym.desc: In acute pulmonary embolism, distinct regional pattern of RV dysfunction, with akinesia of the mid-free wall but normal motion at the apex, 77% sensitive, 94% specific for PE.

eponym.name: McCune-Albright syndrome
eponym.desc: Triad of irregular café au lait spots, fibrous dysplasia of long bones with cysts, and precocious puberty; from activating mutation in GNAS1 gene.

eponym.name: McDonald's sign
eponym.desc: In pregnancy, uterine corpus and cervix can be easily flexed on each other due to Hegar's sign.

eponym.name: McGinn-White sign
eponym.desc: S1Q3T3 pattern in pulmonary embolism; described in 1935.

eponym.name: McLeod phenotype
eponym.desc: Occurs from the absence of the Kx red blood cell antigen; characterized by acanthocytes; compensated hemolytic anemia; decreased Kell system antigens; increased CKMM isoenzymes; and progressive neurologic changes including areflexia, choreiform movements, dysarthria, wasting of muscles, and cardiomyopathy; may be associated with X-linked chronic granulomatous disease.

eponym.name: McMurray test
eponym.desc: For diagnosing meniscal tear, passively flex hip and knee until heel touches buttock, steady the knee with one hand, externally rotate foot, then extend the knee to 90 degrees, return to the beginning and then internally rotate the foot, then passively extend the knee to 90 degrees, feeling for clicks, PPV 83% for tears.

eponym.name: McRoberts's maneuver
eponym.desc: Flexion of mother's legs onto abdomen for shoulder dystocia, causing a significant cephalad rotation of the symphysis pubis and subsequent flattening of the sacrum.

eponym.name: Means-Lerman scratch
eponym.desc: In hyperdynamic heart (as in hyperthyroidism), a systolic scratch occasionally heard in the second left intercostal space during expiration, presumed to be secondary to rubbing together of normal pleural and pericardial surfaces.

eponym.name: Meckel scan
eponym.desc: 99Tc pertechnetate scan that selectively tags acid secreting cells (gastric mucosa); it is used most often for unexplained bleeding in infants and young adults.

eponym.name: Meckel-Gruber syndrome
eponym.desc: Sloping forehead, posterior encephalocele, polydactyly, and polycystic kidneys.

eponym.name: Meckel's cartilage
eponym.desc: Branchial arch 1.

eponym.name: Meckel's cave
eponym.desc: Located in skull base, site of trigeminal ganglion and its divisions. Described by Johann Meckel, the Elder; his grandson described Meckel's diverticulum.

eponym.name: Meckel's diverticulum
eponym.desc: Persistence of vitelline duct, contains all 3 layers of bowel (mucosa, submucosa, muscularis propria), antimesenteric, present in 2% of population, usually within 30 cm of ileocecal valve. See also the "five 2s": 2 inches long, 2 feet from ileocecal valve, 2% of population, commonly persists in first 2 years of life, may have 2 types of epithelia.

eponym.name: Mediterranean anemia
eponym.desc: Beta thalassemia.

eponym.name: Mediterranean fever, familial
eponym.desc: Autosomal recessive disorder characterized by sporadic, paroxysmal attacks of fever and serositis (e.g. abdominal pain). recurrent attacks can be prevented by colchicine. Tends to affect group of people around the Mediterranean Sea. Due to mutation in MEFV gene encoding pyrin.

eponym.name: Mediterranean thromboctyopenia
eponym.desc: In Southern Europe, inherited, mild thrombocytopenia with large platelets from mutation in GPIbalpha; genotype and phenotype similar to Bernard-Soulier disease.

eponym.name: Mees's lines
eponym.desc: Horizontal white bands of the nails seen in chronic arsenic poisoning, and occasionally in leprosy; usually appears 6 weeks after exposue to arsenic; R. A. Mees, 20th century Dutch physician.

eponym.name: Meige's disease
eponym.desc: Lymphedema praecox (in contrast to Milroy's disease).

eponym.name: Meige's syndrome
eponym.desc: Blepharospasm with facial dystonia and lip smacking. Described by French neurologist Henri Meige in 1910.

eponym.name: Meigs's syndrome
eponym.desc: Unusual combination of hydrothorax, ascites, and ovarian fibroma.

eponym.name: Meissner's corpuscle
eponym.desc: Mechanoreceptor in the skin, sensitive to light touch, asymmetrical, lamellated.

eponym.name: Meissner's plexus
eponym.desc: Submucous plexus; innervates glandular epithelium, muscularis mucosa, intestinal endocrine cells, and submucosal blood vessels.

eponym.name: MELAS
eponym.desc: Mitochondrial EncephaLopathy with Acidosis and Stroke, onset in childhood, stroke-like episodes with hemiparesis, hemianopia, or cortical blindness; full expression of the disease leads to death often before age 20; 80-90% have point mutation in leucine tRNA in mtDNA.

eponym.name: Meleney's ulcer
eponym.desc: Necrotizing fascitis.

eponym.name: Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome
eponym.desc: Triad of recurrent facial paralysis, recurrent and eventually permanent facial, especially labial edema, and plication of the tongue; etiology unknown; see also Miescher's cheilitis. Onset in childhood or adolescence.

eponym.name: Meltzer's traid
eponym.desc: In cryoglobulinemia, triad of palpable purpura, arthralgia and myalgia.

eponym.name: Mendelson's syndrome
eponym.desc: Chemical pneumonitis after aspiration of gastric contents.

eponym.name: Ménétrier's disease
eponym.desc: Giant cerebriform enlargement of the rugal folds of the gastric mucosa, results from profound hyperplasia of the surface mucous cells with accompanying glandular atrophy, most often encountered in men (3:1), 40s-60s, sometimes in children. May produce epigastric discomfort, weight loss, and sometimes bleeding related to superficial rugal erosions, gastric secretions mostly mucous, little HCl, may cause sufficient protein loss to produce hypoalbuminemia.

eponym.name: Ménière's disease
eponym.desc: Disorder of the inner ear with four classic symptoms: (1) fluctuating sensorineural loss, classically involving low frequencies; (2) vertiginous episodes; (3) aural pressure; (4) tinnitus (frequently roaring); pathologic changes consist of dilation of the endolymphatic system that leads to degeneration of vestibular and cochlear hair cells.

eponym.name: Menkes's disease
eponym.desc: X-linked, problem in distribution of copper in the body, amount of copper and ceruloplasmin in serum reduced, excess of copper in intestinal mucosa, muscle, spleen, and kidney, associated with brittle hair; usually fatal by age 3. Believed to be due to defect in copper-transporting-ATPase (ATP7A).

eponym.name: Mentzer index
eponym.desc: MCV/RBC ratio; >13 iron def, <13 thalassemia (Lancet 1973 Apr 21;1:882).

eponym.name: Merkel cell
eponym.desc: Nerve ending cells located in the skin associated with sensory neurites in the dermal papillae, which are the mechanoreceptors of the skin; speculated to be the cell of origin of Merkel cell carcinoma.

eponym.name: Merkel cell carcinoma
eponym.desc: Rare aggressive neuroendocrine tumor involving the skin, predominantly affects elderly Caucasians with a propensity for local recurrence and regional lymph node metastases.

eponym.name: MERRF
eponym.desc: Myoclonic Epilepsy and Ragged Red Fibers, syndrome of mitochondrial myopathy, myoclonus, generalized seizures, intellectual deficits, ataxia, and hearing loss; extraocular movements normal; associated with point mutations in lysine tRNA in mtDNA.

eponym.name: Meyer's loop
eponym.desc: A portion of the optic radiations subserving vision from the superior field coursing rostrally within the temporal lobe before heading caudally to the primary visual cortex; lesions produce contralateral upper quadrantanopia (pie in the sky).

eponym.name: Meynert, basal nucleus of
eponym.desc: Group of nerve cells in the basal forebrain that are rich in acetylcholine. These cells degenerate in Alzheimer's disease.

eponym.name: Mibelli, porokeratosis of
eponym.desc: Classic porokeratosis, localized, chronically progressive, hyperkeratotic, irregular plaques with central atrophy and prominent peripheral keratotic ridge; characterized pathologically by presence of cornoid lamella.

eponym.name: Michaelis-Guttmann bodies
eponym.desc: Urinary tract basophilic inclusions. Felt to represent phagosomes mineralized by calcium and iron. Seen in malakoplakia, an inflammatory condition in immunocompromised patients involving urinary tract (rarely skin) with plaques or nodules.

eponym.name: Michel deformity
eponym.desc: Congenital absence of the inner ear or labyrinthe aplasia.

eponym.name: Middlebrook media
eponym.desc: Medium used for growing mycobacterium.

eponym.name: Miescher's cheilitis
eponym.desc: Chelitis granulomatosa; recurrent labial edema on one or both lips; considered a monosymptomatic form of Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome.

eponym.name: Mikulicz's syndrome
eponym.desc: Bilateral inflammatory enlargement of the parotid, submaxillary, and sublingual, and lacrimal glands and xerostomia, secondary to sarcoidosis, leukemia, lymphoma, etc.

eponym.name: Milkman's fractures
eponym.desc: In osteomalacia, radiolucent narrow lines that lie either at right angles or obliquely to the cortical outlines of bones and often transect them; bilateral and symmetric, found at the axillary margins of the scapula, lower ribs, neck of the proximal femurs, and posterior regions of the proximal ulnas; related either to stress fractures or to mechanical erosion by penetrating nutrient arteries; also known as Looser's zones. Described by Milkman in 1930.

eponym.name: Millard-Gubler syndrome
eponym.desc: Ventral pontine injury causing symptoms similar to Foville's syndrome except lateral rectus weakness only, instead of gaze palsy.

eponym.name: Miller Fisher syndrome
eponym.desc: Variant of Guillain-Barré where cranial nerves are affected, leading to triad of ataxia, areflexia and ophthalmoplegia; cross-reacting antibodies to GQ1b ganglioside have been found; triggered by certain strains of C. jejuni. Described by neurologist, Charles Miller Fisher.

eponym.name: Miller Fisher test
eponym.desc: For testing for normal pressure hydrocephalus, objective gait assessment before and after 30 cc CSF removed, reflecting prognosis for shunting (i.e. improvement after CSF removal). Described by Charles Miller Fisher.

eponym.name: Milroy's disease
eponym.desc: Congenital lymphedema with swelling present from time of birth (in contrast to Meige's disease), mainly below the waist, associated with mutation in VEGF C/D receptor (VEGFR-3).

eponym.name: Milwaukee brace
eponym.desc: Brace used for treating scoliosis of the back.

eponym.name: Milwaukee shoulder
eponym.desc: Basic calcium phosphate disease associated with large joint destructive arthropathy (especially shoulder) and rotator cuff tears.

eponym.name: Mirizzi's syndrome
eponym.desc: Extrinsic obstruction of the common bile duct from a cystic duct gallstone.

eponym.name: Mississippi mud
eponym.desc: Refers to vancomycin's brownish, muddy appearance in early preparations.

eponym.name: Mitchell disease
eponym.desc: Erythromelalgia, or vasodilation and burning pain of lower extremities. Primary erythromelalgia due to mutation in SCN9A, a voltage-gated sodium channel.

eponym.name: mitral facies
eponym.desc: Malar flush with pinched and blue facies in mitral stenosis.

eponym.name: Mittelschmerz
eponym.desc: Lower abdominal or pelvic pain during ovulation; occurs roughly halfway of menstrual cycle. From German for "middle pain."

eponym.name: Mobitz type I AV block
eponym.desc: Wenckebach pattern, second degree block with intermittent conduction failure resulting in progressive PR prolongation before dropped beat; may be seen in ischemic heart disease, digitalis, beta blockers, calcium channel blockers, inferior wall myocardial infarction.

eponym.name: Mobitz type II AV block
eponym.desc: Second degree block with intermittent conduction failure with sudden non-conducted sinus P wave without progressive prolongation of PR interval; not seen with digitalis excess or inferior wall myocardial infarction generally but may be seen with anterior wall MI.

eponym.name: Möbius syndrome
eponym.desc: Congenital facial paralysis with or without limb defects associated with maternal misoprostol use.

eponym.name: Möbius's sign
eponym.desc: In Graves's ophthalmopathy, failure of ocular convergence following close accommodation at a distance of 5 inches.

eponym.name: Modigliani syndrome
eponym.desc: Thyroid in normal position, but with enhanced prominence and palpability, especially in individuals with long curving necks.

eponym.name: Moersch-Woltmann syndrome
eponym.desc: Stiff-man syndrome; associated with antibodies to glutamic acid decarboxylase (GAD).

eponym.name: Mohs's surgery
eponym.desc: Surgery involving microscopic examination of tissue being removed; generally used for skin cancers; developed by Frederic Mohs in the 1930s.

eponym.name: Mollaret's meningitis
eponym.desc: Benign recurrent aseptic meningitis characterized by large monocytic cells in CSF; significant percentage due to HSV-2.

eponym.name: Mönckeberg's arteriosclerosis
eponym.desc: Ring-like calcifications within the media of medium-sized to small muscular arteries (femoral, tibial, radial, and ulnar arteries, genital arteries), occurs almost exclusively in individuals over 50 years old; does not narrow lumen, distinct from atherosclerosis.

eponym.name: Mondini malformation
eponym.desc: Cause of sensorineural hearing loss due to developmental anomaly of otic capsules with developmental arrest of cochlea in seventh fetal week; increased risk of developing recurrent meningitis or perilymphatic fistula.

eponym.name: Mondor's disease
eponym.desc: Thrombophlebitis of superficial breast veins.

eponym.name: Monge's disease
eponym.desc: Chronic mountain sickness, loss of high altitude tolerance after prolonged exposure, characterized by extreme polycythemia, exaggerated hypoxemia, and reduced mental and physical capacity; relieved by descent.

eponym.name: Monod's sign
eponym.desc: In aspergillomas, radiolucent crescent seen around solitary 3-5 cm lesion on chest X-ray.

eponym.name: Monro, foramina of
eponym.desc: Connects each of the lateral ventricles with the third ventricle in the brain.

eponym.name: Monro-Kellie doctrine
eponym.desc: Cranial cavity is a closed rigid box, change in the amount of intracranial blood can occur only through changes in CSF quantity.

eponym.name: Monsel's solution
eponym.desc: Ferric subsulfate, solution used for its styptic properties, i.e. stopping bleeding.

eponym.name: Monteggia fracture
eponym.desc: Fracture of the proximal third of the ulna with a dislocation of radial head.

eponym.name: Montgomery, glands of
eponym.desc: Sebaceous glands of areola.

eponym.name: Montreal platelet syndrome
eponym.desc: Hereditary thrombocytopenia associated with mucocutaneous bleeding, giant platelets, and spontaneous platelet clumping in vitro; associated with type 2B VWD and the V1316M mutation.

eponym.name: Mooren corneal ulcers
eponym.desc: Chronic, painful ulcers, involves circumference of peripheral cornea and may progress to vision loss. Most cases are idiopathic, some are associated with hepatitis C.

eponym.name: Morgagni, hydatids of
eponym.desc: Fallopian tube cysts found near the fimbriated end or in the broad ligaments.

eponym.name: Morgagni's hernia
eponym.desc: A form of congenital diaphragmatic hernia, anterior parasternal diaphragmatic hernia, right more common than left. Compare to Bochdalek hernia.

eponym.name: Morquio's syndrome
eponym.desc: Mucopolysaccharidosis (IV) from N-acetylglucosamine-6-sulfate sulfatase deficiency leading to accumulation of keratan sulfate and chondroitin-6 sulfate, characterized by distinctive skeletal deformity, corneal clouding, odontoid hypoplasia, and aortic valve disease. Normal intelligence.

eponym.name: Morrison's pouch
eponym.desc: Hepatorenal recess; the most posterior cavity in the peritoneal cavity.

eponym.name: Morton's neuroma
eponym.desc: Interdigitial palmar neuroma.

eponym.name: Morvan's syndrome
eponym.desc: Fibrillary chorea; neuromyotonia, pain, weight loss, severe insomnia and hallucinations, excess secretions (sweating, lacrimation, and salivation); associated with voltage-gated potassium channel antibodies.

eponym.name: Moschowitz syndrome
eponym.desc: Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura, described in 1924.

eponym.name: Moses's sign
eponym.desc: See Bancroft's sign.

eponym.name: Mott cells
eponym.desc: Cytologic variant of plasma cells with globular cytoplasmic inclusions that contain immunoglobulin proteins (blue, grapelike cytoplasmic droplets); seen in multiple myeloma and trypanosomiasis.

eponym.name: Mounier-Kuhn syndrome
eponym.desc: Tracheomegaly, tracheobronchomegaly associated with recurrent pneumonia, copious purulent sputum production, hoarseness, load cough; presents in 30s-40s, more common in males; tracheal lumen increases with Valsalva; autosomal recessive.

eponym.name: moyamoya disease
eponym.desc: Occlusive disease involving large intracranial arteries, especially the distal ICA and stem of the MCA and ACA; "puff of smoke" (in Japanese, moya moya) appearance on angiography from lenticulostriate arteries developing rich collateral circulation around the middle cerebral occlusion that; anticoagulation challenging because of occurrence of SAH from rupture of the transdural anastomotic channels.

eponym.name: Mucha-Habermann disease
eponym.desc: Pityriasis lichenoides et varioliformis acuta, scattered necrotic papules and vesicles that can resemble insect bites but usually are more generalized and symmetric.

eponym.name: Muckle-Wells syndrome
eponym.desc: Syndrome of urticaria, progressive perceptive deafness, and amyloidosis; from mutation in cryopyrin; autosomal dominant. Of note familial cold autoinflammatory syndrome, commonly known as familial cold urticaria, characterized by intermittent episodes of rash, arthralgia, fever and conjunctivitis after generalized exposure to cold is also associated with mutations in cryopyrin.

eponym.name: Muehrcke's nails
eponym.desc: Paired narrow horizontal white bands that are immobile as nail grows; seen in hypoalbuminemia, nephrotic syndrome.

eponym.name: Muenke syndrome
eponym.desc: Nonsyndromic coronal craniosynostosis, associated with a specific mutation of the fibroblast growth factor receptor-3 gene (FGFR3), Pro250 to Arg.

eponym.name: Muir-Torre syndrome
eponym.desc: Combination of hereditary nonpolyposis colon cancer (HNPCC) with benign or malignant sebaceous skin tumors (often basal cell or squamous cell). Originally described in 1967.

eponym.name: Mulder's sign
eponym.desc: Palpable click in Morton's neuroma when compressing the forefoot and pushing up in the distal third intermetatarsal space.

eponym.name: Mullerian duct
eponym.desc: In female embryonic development, duct that gives rise to fallopian tubes, uterus, and upper vagina.

eponym.name: Mullerian inhibiting substance
eponym.desc: In embryonic development, gonadal peptide hormone that initiates regression of Mullerian duct during male sexual development.

eponym.name: Müller-Lyer illusion
eponym.desc: Visual illusion involving two horizontal lines with arrows where line with inward facing arrows appears shorter than line with outward facing arrows.

eponym.name: Müller's maneuver
eponym.desc: Reverse Valsalva maneuver.

eponym.name: Müller's sign
eponym.desc: In aortic regurgitation, systolic pulsations of the uvula.

eponym.name: Munchausen's syndrome
eponym.desc: Factitious disorder, eponym given by Asher in 1951 after Baron Karl Munchausen (1720-1797), retired German cavalry officer with a reputation for preposterous stories about his activities as a soldier, hunter.

eponym.name: Munro's microabscesses
eponym.desc: In psoriasis, when neutrophils form small aggregates within the parakeratotic stratum corneum.

eponym.name: Murphy drip
eponym.desc: Saline infusion in the rectum for treating peritonitis; also refers to continuous irrigation of the bladder; after John Benjmain Murphy surgeon (1896-1982) of Murphy's sign.

eponym.name: Murphy eye
eponym.desc: Small hole in the side of the endotracheal tube that allows for ventilation if the distal end becomes occluded.

eponym.name: Murphy's punch sign
eponym.desc: Tenderness over costovertebral angle suggesting pyelonephritis.

eponym.name: Murphy's sign
eponym.desc: A sharp increase in tenderness with a sudden stop in inspiratory effort, sign of acute cholecystitis; 27-97.2% sensitive, 48.3% specific.

eponym.name: Mustard procedure
eponym.desc: For treating transposition of great vessels, now rarely used; an atrial inversion procedure which connects RA to LV, which pumps out to pulmonary arteries, and connects LA to RV, which becomes systemic pump to aorta; variant uses pericardial or prosthetic intraatrial baffles.

eponym.name: Myerson's sign
eponym.desc: Repetitive tapping (about twice per second) over the bridge of the nose producing a sustained blink response in parkinsonism and as a frontal release sign; also known as glabellar reflex. Normal response is to resist blinking.

eponym.name: Naclerio, V sign of
eponym.desc: In esophageal rupture, V-shaped collection of air along mediastinum and diaphragm.

eponym.name: Nagayama spots
eponym.desc: In roseola, erythematous papules on the soft palate and uvula.

eponym.name: Nägele's rule
eponym.desc: Method for estimating date of delivery by counting back 3 months from the first day of the last menstrual period and adding seven days; full term 38 weeks after fertilization, 40 weeks after last menstrual period.

eponym.name: Nardi test
eponym.desc: In relapsing pancreatitis, narcotic-induced stimulation or spasm reproducing abdominal pain and amylase elevation (for inferring sphincteric disease in any pancreatic or biliary ductal system without a gallbladder), presumably accurate in the diagnosis of perisphincteric disease.

eponym.name: Natowicz syndrome
eponym.desc: Mucopolysaccharidosis type IX, from hyaluronidase deficiency. Characterized by short stature and multiple soft tissue masses around joints. Described by Natowicz in 1996.

eponym.name: Naxos disease
eponym.desc: Initially described on Greek island of Naxos, syndrome of arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy, non-epidermolytic palmoplantar keratoderma, and woolly hair, due to deletion in plakoglobin, protein in adherens and desmosomal junctions.

eponym.name: Neer sign
eponym.desc: In shoulder impingement, forcibly flexing the arm to an overhead position to produce pain from impingement of humerus against coracoacromial arch.

eponym.name: Negri bodies
eponym.desc: In rabies virus-infected brain neurons, eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions.

eponym.name: Nelson's syndrome
eponym.desc: Enlargement of a pituitary adenoma in a patient with Cushing's disease whose adrenals have been removed; from loss of feedback inhibition of cortisol.

eponym.name: Neu-Laxova syndrome
eponym.desc: Autosomal recessive syndrome characterized by severe intrauterine growth retardation, microcephaly, abnormal brain development, edema, and icthyosis. First reported in 1971 by Neu et al. (Pediatrics 47;610-612).

eponym.name: Nezelof syndrome
eponym.desc: Congenital immunodeficiency syndrome, autosomal recessive, due to thymic dysplasia.

eponym.name: Nicolau's syndrome
eponym.desc: Livedo-like dermatitis from acute arterial thrombosis occurring immediately after intravascular injection of an insoluble drug substance.

eponym.name: Niemann-Pick disease
eponym.desc: A sphingolipidosis where there is lysosomal accumulation of sphingomyelin and cholesterol, type A and B (deficiency of sphingomyelin-cleaving enzyme sphingomyelinase) and type C and D (enzyme normal or nearly normal, defect in esterification and transport); type A, 75-80% of all cases, extensive neurologic involvement, marked visceral accumulations of sphingomyelin, and progressive wasting and early death within the first 3 years of life); half have cherry red spot in macula as in Tay-Sachs disease.

eponym.name: Niikawa-Kuroki syndrome
eponym.desc: See kabuki syndrome.

eponym.name: Nijmegen breakage syndrome
eponym.desc: Primary immunodeficiency autosomal recessive disorder that presents as microcephaly, a distinctive "bird-like" facies, growth retardation, recurrent pulmonary infections, chromosomal instability, radiation hypersensitivity, and increased incidence of malignancies, especially lymphomas from mutation in nibrin protein, a protein involved in DNA repair; cellular defect similar to ataxia-telangiectasia.

eponym.name: Nikaidoh procedure
eponym.desc: Procedure for patients born with a combination of transposition of the great arteries, ventricular septal defect, and pulmonary stenosis. In contrast with the Rastelli procedure, the Nikaidoh procedure creates a more "anatomically correct" left ventricular outflow tract.
