Also known as aortic translocation and biventricular outflow tract reconstruction.

eponym.name: Nikolsky's sign
eponym.desc: Associated with pemphigus vulgaris; apparently normal epidermis next to blister may be separated at the basal layer and rubbed off when pressed with a sliding motion. See also Asboe-Hansen sign.

eponym.name: Nissen fundoplication
eponym.desc: For treating gastroesophageal reflux disease, surrounding lower end of esophagus with cuff of gastric fundal muscle to increase lower esophageal sphincter competence.

eponym.name: Nissl bodies
eponym.desc: In neurons, rough endoplasmic reticulum.

eponym.name: Nissl stain
eponym.desc: Stains for cell bodies; dye binds to acid groups, in particular the RNAs of the ribosomes located within the cell body. Described by Franz Nissl, German medical student at time.

eponym.name: Noonan's syndrome
eponym.desc: Turner's phenotypic characteristics without any sex chromosome abnormalities, males or females with congenital heart defect (usually pulmonic stenosis and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy), pectus carinatum, short stature, mild mental retardation, hypertelorism, and webbed neck; autosomal dominant; associated with mutation in nonreceptor protein tyrosine phosphatase SHP2 (PTPN11). Most common non-chromosomal cause of congenital heart disease.

eponym.name: Norman-Landing disease
eponym.desc: GM1 gangliosidosis, a lysosomal storage disorder.

eponym.name: Norrie disease
eponym.desc: X-linked disorder associated with very early childhood blindness due to degenerative changes of the retina; associated with mental retardation and psychotic-like features; due to mutation in gene encoding norrin.

eponym.name: Norwalk virus
eponym.desc: Calcivirus associated with gastroenteritis; named after outbreak in a school in Norwalk, Ohio in 1969.

eponym.name: Norwegian scabies
eponym.desc: Crusted scabies, highly contagious, psoriaform dermatosis of the hands and feet with dystrophy of the nails and an erythematous scaling eruption that may be generalized; itching minimal; seen in institutionalized patients, mentally retarded, and in patients with HIV, HTLV-1, or adult T cell leukemia. Initially described in Norwegian patients with leprosy in 1840s.

eponym.name: Norwood procedure
eponym.desc: For treating hypoplastic left heart syndrome, anastomosis of proximal main pulmonary artery to aorta, with aortic arch reconstruction and transection and patch closure of distal main pulmonary artery; modified right Blalock-Taussig shunt (subclavian artery to right PA) to provide pulmonary blood flow. ASD created to allow for adequate left to right flow. See also Glenn shunt and Fontan procedure as subsequent stages.

eponym.name: Nothnagel's syndrome
eponym.desc: Injury to superior cerebellar peduncle causing ipsilateral oculomotor palsy and contralateral cerebellar ataxia.

eponym.name: Ober's test
eponym.desc: Provocative test for iliotibial band syndrome: patient lies on unaffected side and affected leg is abducted while knee is flexed to 90 degrees and leg is then released; positive for iliotibial band syndrome when thigh is released and thigh remains abducted.

eponym.name: Occam's razor
eponym.desc: Described in 14th century, "plurality must not be posited without necessity", in other words, parsimony in diagnosis; by contrast, see Hickam's dictum.

eponym.name: Oddi, sphincter of
eponym.desc: Sphincter around opening of common bile duct into the duodenum; Oddi, Italian anatomist and surgeon (1864-1913).

eponym.name: Ogilvie's syndrome
eponym.desc: Massive idiopathic non-obstructive dilatation of the colon, can be sen in ill patients.

eponym.name: Oguchi disease
eponym.desc: Congenital night blindness; asymptomatic during day; found to be due to mutations in arrestin (in Japanese Oguchi disease) and rhodopsin kinase (in European Oguchi disease).

eponym.name: Okihiro syndrome
eponym.desc: Association of forearm malformations with Duane syndrome of eye retraction; associated with mutations in SALL4.

eponym.name: Oliver's sign
eponym.desc: In aortic aneurysm, pulsation of aorta felt through cricoid cartilage when chin is elevated.

eponym.name: Ollier's disease
eponym.desc: Syndrome of multiple enchondromas. Increased risk of sarcoma. No known genetic component.

eponym.name: Omenn's syndrome
eponym.desc: Combined immunodeficiency associated with hypereosinophilia, erythroderma, hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, alopecia; autosomal recessive; associated with mutations in Rag-1 and Rag-2 proteins and decreased V(D)J recombination efficiency. Also associated with mutation in ARTEMIS protein (involved in opening coding end hairpins).

eponym.name: Ommaya reservoir
eponym.desc: Device implanted under the scalp that communicates with the CSF and allows intrathecal delivery of therapeutic agents (e.g., chemotherapy).

eponym.name: Ondine's curse
eponym.desc: Failure of the automatic control of ventilation, named after mythological tale in which the suitor of Neptune's daughter was cursed to lose automatic control over all bodily functions; associated with mutation in ret proto-oncogene; associated with Hirschsprung's disease.

eponym.name: Onufrowicz, nucleus of
eponym.desc: Parasympathetic neurons in the sacral spinal cord that innervate the sphincters of the bowel and bladder.

eponym.name: Opitz syndrome
eponym.desc: Also known as Opitz GBBB syndrome. Hypospadias-dysphagia syndrome or telecanthus with associated abnormalities; associated with midline abnormalities such as cleft lip, laryngeal cleft, heart defects, hypospadias, and agenesis of the corpus callosum.

eponym.name: Oppenheim's sign
eponym.desc: Involuntary dorsiflexion of the toes when stroking the medial/anterior tibial surface superiorly to inferiorly, indicating upper motor neuron defect.

eponym.name: Ormond's disease
eponym.desc: Retroperitoneal fibrosis.

eponym.name: Oroya fever
eponym.desc: From Bartonella bacilliformis (transmitted by sandfly vector Phlebotomus found in valleys of the Andes mountains, 600-2500 m): profound intravascular hemolytic anemia of a few weeks duration, associated with lesions called verruga peruana resembling Kaposi's sarcoma; also known as Carrión's disease.

eponym.name: Ortner's syndrome
eponym.desc: Hoarseness from compression of left recurrent laryngeal nerve by a dilated left atrium (e.g., in mitral stenosis), enlarged tracheobronchial lymph nodes, and dilated pulmonary artery.

eponym.name: Ortolani's sign
eponym.desc: In congenital hip dislocation, rotate hip with patient in supine position and hip abducted; a "clunk" or "click" represents congenitally dislocated hip.

eponym.name: Osborn wave
eponym.desc: EKG with distinctive convex "hump" at J point associated with hypothermia and temperature around 32C.

eponym.name: Osgood-Schlatter's disease
eponym.desc: Epiphysitis of tibial tubercle resulting from repeated powerful contractions of the quadriceps; seen in adolescents with open physis.

eponym.name: Osler's nodes
eponym.desc: In endocarditis, tender to painful, purplish, split pea-sized, subcutaneous nodules in the pulp of the fingers and/or toes and thenar and hypothenar eminences; transient, disappearing within several days (5% of patients). In acute bacterial endocarditis, associated with minute infective emboli. In subacute bacterial endocarditis, associated with immune complexes and small-vessel arteritis of skin.

eponym.name: Osler's sign
eponym.desc: Palpable brachial or radial artery when cuff pressure greater than systolic pressure.

eponym.name: Osler-Weber-Rendu disease
eponym.desc: Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia, larger lesions can be a source of chronic blood loss, systemic emboli, hypoxemia, hepatic dysfunction, and a high-output cardiac failure. Important risk factor for brain abscess, especially in affected patients with clubbing, cyanosis, and/or polycythemia. Can be treated with aminocaproic acid (an antifibrinolytic agent.

eponym.name: Ota, nevus of
eponym.desc: Pigmentation mostly involving the skin and mucous membranes innervated by the first and second branches of the trigeminal nerve.

eponym.name: Ottawa ankle rules
eponym.desc: Decision guide for managing acute ankle injury and ordering ankle and foot x-ray series. Ankle x-ray series required only if there is any pain in the malleolar zone and any of these findings: bony tenderness at posterior edge or tip of lateral malleolus, base of fifth metatarsal, or inability to bear weight both immediately and in emergency department. Foot x-ray is required only if there is any pain in the midfoot zone and any of these findings: bone tenderness at base of fifth metatarsal, bone tenderness at navicular, or inability to bear weight both immediately and in emergency department.

eponym.name: Ouchterlony reaction
eponym.desc: Test based on the precipitin reaction where antigen and antibody are placed in separate wells cut in agar; precipitate forms a band between wells at the optimal concentration; described by Ouchterlony in 1948.

eponym.name: Owren's disease
eponym.desc: Factor V deficiency; also known as parahemophilia.

eponym.name: Pacinian corpuscles
eponym.desc: Mechanoreceptor nerve ending located in skin, sensitive for vibration and touch; symmetrical, lamellated.

eponym.name: Paget's disease of bone
eponym.desc: Osteitis deformans, characterized by initial osteolytic stage followed by a mixed osteoclastic-osteoblastic stage, which ends with osteoblastic activity and evolves into a burnt-out osteosclerotic stage. Increased alkaline phosphatase and increased urine hydroxyproline observed.

eponym.name: Paget's disease of breast
eponym.desc: Breast cancer involving nipple and areola, appears as eczematous rash over breast with crusting, scaling, or erosion.

eponym.name: Paget's disease of vulva
eponym.desc: Intraepithelial adenocarcinoma, less than 1% of all vulva malignancies.

eponym.name: Paget-Schroetter syndrome
eponym.desc: Deep vein thrombosis of subclavian or axillary vein. May be spontaneous or may occur after activity.

eponym.name: Palla's sign
eponym.desc: In pulmonary embolism, enlarged right descending pulmonary artery.

eponym.name: Pallister-Hall syndrome
eponym.desc: Disorder associated with polydactyly and cutaneous syndactyly. Hypothalamic hamartoma characteristic, bifid epiglottis. Autosomal dominant, due to mutation in GLI3, involved in hedgehog pathway. See also Greig syndrome, which is also due to mutation in GLI3.

eponym.name: Panayiotopoulos syndrome
eponym.desc: Benign childhood partial seizure characterized by vomiting, deviation of the eyes, and seizures lasting for more than 30 min (without permanent injury).

eponym.name: Pancoast's tumor
eponym.desc: Apical lung cancers in the superior pulmonary sulcus which invade neural structures around the trachea, including the cervical sympathetic plexus, leading to severe pain in distribution of the ulnar nerve and Horner's syndrome on same side of the lesion.

eponym.name: PANDAS
eponym.desc: Pediatric Autoimmune Neuropsychiatric Disorders Associated with Streptococcal infections. Consists of tics, movement disorders, emotional-lability, and obsessive-compulsive behavior associated with streptococcal infection. Caused by IgG antibodies which recognize group A streptococcal cell wall proteins as well as neuronal cytoplasmic antigens of the basal ganglia. Related to Sydenham's chorea.

eponym.name: Paneth cells
eponym.desc: In small intestine crypts, cells with apically-oriented bright eosinophilic granules and which appear to play a role in the mucosal immune system.

eponym.name: Panner disease
eponym.desc: Avascular necrosis or osteochondrosis of the capitellum (head of humerus).

eponym.name: Pap smear
eponym.desc: Smear of cervical cells developed by Papanicolaou, reported in 1941, used for screening and prevention of cervical cancer.

eponym.name: Papez circuit
eponym.desc: Pathway from subiculum to the mamillary body and back to the cingulate gyrus believed to play a role in emotion (initially) and memory.

eponym.name: Papillon-Lefevre disease
eponym.desc: Early development of severe periodontal disease, palmoplantar keratosis; autosomal recessive; associated with mutation in cathepsin C gene.

eponym.name: Pappenheimer bodies
eponym.desc: Small dark blue irregularly shaped iron-containing granules often in clusters found in red blood cells. Smaller than Howell-Jolly body, commonly seen in sideroblastic anemias, thalassemias, megaloblastic anemias, and in post-splenectomy states.

eponym.name: Pardee waves
eponym.desc: Symmetrically inverted T waves in myocardial ischemia or infarction.

eponym.name: Parinaud's oculoglandular syndrome
eponym.desc: Preauricular node enlargement associated with chronic granulomatous conjunctivitis; an atypical form of cat scratch disease from inoculation near eye.

eponym.name: Parinaud's syndrome
eponym.desc: Dorsal midbrain syndrome with supranuclear vertical gaze disorder from damage to posterior commissure with loss of upgaze, convergence-retraction nystagmus, downward ocular deviation, lid retraction, due to hydrocephalus from aqueductal stenosis, pineal region tumors.

eponym.name: Paris-Trousseau syndrome
eponym.desc: A variant of Jacobsen's disease, mild hemorrhagic tendency associated with 11q deletion, thrombocytopenia, attributed to deletion of FLI1.

eponym.name: Parkinson's disease
eponym.desc: Degenerative disorder of central nervous system due to degeneration of dopaminergic neurons of the substantia nigra which project to the striatum; characterized by tremor, rigidity, akinesia, and gait disturbance. Described by James Parkinson in 1817.

eponym.name: Parkland formula
eponym.desc: For calculating amount of intravenous fluids to give in burn patients: total body surface area % burned x kg x 4; 1/2 in first 8 hours, second 1/2 given next 16 hours.

eponym.name: Parry-Romberg syndrome
eponym.desc: Acquired progressive hemifacial atrophy of the lower face, typically without significant cutaneous involvement; a variant of morphea/scleroderma.

eponym.name: Parsonage-Turner syndrome
eponym.desc: Acute brachial neuritis or neuralgic amyotrophy; classically severe pain followed by weakness in the brachial plexus, associated with winging of the scapula.

eponym.name: Passy-Muir valve
eponym.desc: Speaking valve for patients with tracheostomy developed by Patricia Passy and David Muir.

eponym.name: Pastia's sign
eponym.desc: Associated with scarlet fever (group A streptococcus or S. aureus rarely); confluent, finely punctate erythema (scarlatiniform) on the lower trunk and thighs with petechiae having a linear configuration in the inguinal regions .

eponym.name: Patau's syndrome
eponym.desc: Trisomy 13, 1/15,000 births, mental retardation, microcephaly, microphthalmia, brain abnormalities, cleft lip and palate, polydactyly, rocker-bottom feet, and congenital heart disease. Extra chromosome 13 described by Klaus Patau in 1960.

eponym.name: Patrick sign
eponym.desc: Hip pain on external rotation of the hip in hip joint disease that may refer pain to back and thighs.

eponym.name: Patterson-Brown-Kelly syndrome
eponym.desc: Plummer-Vinson syndrome.

eponym.name: Paul-Bunnell test
eponym.desc: Agglutination of sheep red blood cells by heterophile antibodies.

eponym.name: Paul-Bunnell-Davidsohn test
eponym.desc: Extension of classic Paul-Bunnell test for heterophile antibody; uses guinea pig kidney cells to first absorb Forsmann antibodies found in normal individuals, followed by test for sheep erythrocyte agglutination.

eponym.name: Pautrier's microabscesses
eponym.desc: See Sézary-Lutzner cells.

eponym.name: Pearson syndrome
eponym.desc: Refractory sideroblastic anemia with vacuolization of marrow precursors and exocrine pancreatic dysfunction from mitochondrial DNA mutation.

eponym.name: Pedro Pons sign
eponym.desc: In spondylitis from brucellosis, erosion antero-superior corner of lumbar vertebrae and marked osteophytosis.

eponym.name: Pel-Ebstein fever
eponym.desc: In Hodgkin's disease, unusual systemic manifestation of a periodic fever that is present for some days, remits, and then returns.

eponym.name: Pelger-Hüet anomaly
eponym.desc: Dumbbell-shaped, hypolobated nuclei in neutrophils seen in blood of acute myelogenous leukemia (e.g., M2) or myelodysplastic syndromes. May be inherited as autosomal dominant trait from mutation in laminin B receptor.

eponym.name: Pelizaeus-Merzbacher disease
eponym.desc: Mutation in proteolipid protein on X chromosome, a major protein in CNS myelin; results in hypomyelination confined to the CNS, widespread white matter dysfunction, leading to seizures, mental retardation, and death in childhood; see "tigroid" appearance on tissue sections stained for myelin.

eponym.name: Pellegrini-Stieda syndrome
eponym.desc: Calcification of medial collateral ligament at its femoral insertion; usually due to trauma.

eponym.name: Pemberton's sign
eponym.desc: In SVC (superior vena cava) obstruction, development of facial plethora, inspiratory stridor, and non-pulsatile elevation of the JVP when patient lifts arms over head.

eponym.name: Pendred's syndrome
eponym.desc: Autosomal recessive goiter and congenital sensorineural deafness from mutation in pendrin, a transport protein that affects organification of thyroglobulin; also see malformations of cochlea and hypothyroidism (40%); pendrin involved in transport of chloride and iodide.

eponym.name: Percheron, artery of
eponym.desc: Anatomic variant where artery arises from posterior communicating artery and then gives rise to bilateral medial thalamic perforators; occlusion results in bilateral paramedian thalamic infraction. An example where cerebral vessel supplies structures on both sides of the midline.

eponym.name: Perlia's nucleus
eponym.desc: Cell group located between motor neuron groups innervating left and right medical rectus muscles; felt to be involved in ocular convergence.

eponym.name: Perl's stain
eponym.desc: Stain for iron; tissue section treated with hydrochloric acid to release ferric ions from binding proteins; section then treated with potassium ferrocyanide to produce an insoluble blue compound (the Prussian blue reaction).

eponym.name: Perthes test
eponym.desc: Testing for competence of deep femoral veins; tourniquet is applied at mid-thigh with patient standing and patient then walks for 5 min with tourniquet pin place; reduction in size of veins indicates patent valves and lumens.

eponym.name: Petersen's hernia
eponym.desc: Hernia involving the space between the mesentery of the Roux limb and the transverse colon; can occur following gastric bypass surgery.

eponym.name: Peutz-Jeghers syndrome
eponym.desc: Rare autosomal dominant syndrome characterized by multiple hamartomatous polyps scattered throughout the GI tract and melanotic mucosal and cutaneous pigmentation around the lips, oral mucosa, face, genitalia, and palmar surfaces; patients have increased risk of carcinomas of pancreas, breast, lung, ovary, uterus, and malignant transformation in small bowel polyps, colon cancer, sex cord tumors with annular tubules of the ovary; associated with mutation in STK11/LKB1 gene and dysregulation of mTOR.

eponym.name: Peyrone's salt
eponym.desc: Cisplatin; first synthesized by Peyrone in 1845.

eponym.name: Peyronie's disease
eponym.desc: Penile fibromatosis, a palpable induration or mass appears on the dorsolateral aspect of the penis. It may cause eventually abnormal curvature of the shaft or constriction of the urethra, or both.

eponym.name: Pfannenstiel's incision
eponym.desc: Low transverse abdominal incision with retraction of the rectus muscles laterally, used in ob/gyn procedures.

eponym.name: Pfeiffer bacterium
eponym.desc: H. influenza, found in respiratory tracts of people ill with flu in 1890.

eponym.name: Pfeiffer syndrome
eponym.desc: Craniosynostoses as well as limb defects, broad thumbs, broad great toes. Due to mutations in FGFR1, autosomal dominant inheritance.

eponym.name: Phalen's maneuver
eponym.desc: In carpal tunnel syndrome, palmar flexion of the wrist to 90 degrees for 1 minute exacerbates or reproduces symptoms, paresthesias; 75% sensitive 47% specific.

eponym.name: Phemister's triad
eponym.desc: In arthritis from tuberculosis, radiographic triad of periarticular osteoporosis, peripherally located osseous erosions, and gradual narrowing of the joint space.

eponym.name: Philadelphia chromosome
eponym.desc: Seen in 95% of chronic myelogenous leukemia (210 kD tyrosine kinase), 2-5% childhood ALL (180 kD TK), higher percent in adult. Reciprocal and balanced translocation between chr22 (bcr, breakpoint cluster region) and chr9 (c-abl); c-abl-bcr encodes a chimeric protein with tyrosine kinase activity; genomic imprinting, chr9 paternal and chr22 maternal.

eponym.name: Pick bodies
eponym.desc: In neurons, cytoplasmic, round to oval, filamentous inclusions that strongly stain with silver, weakly eosinophilic; composed of neurofilaments, vesiculated endoplasmic reticulum, and paired helical filaments that are immunocytochemically similar to those found in Alzheimer's disease. Associated with Pick's disease.

eponym.name: Pick cells
eponym.desc: Characteristic swelling of neurons in Pick's disease.

eponym.name: Pick's disease
eponym.desc: Subtype of frontal lobe dementia, characterized by language abnormalities such as logorrhea, echolalia, and palilalia (compulsive repetition of phrases), with Pick bodies; occurs 1-5% as often as Alzheimer's disease.

eponym.name: Pickwickian syndrome
eponym.desc: Obesity hypoventilation syndrome defined by extreme obesity and alveolar hypoventilation during wakefulness, characterized by hypersomnolence, dyspnea, hypoxemia (cyanosis, polycythemia, and plethora), and pulmonary hypertension leading to RV failure and edema; based upon Charles Dickens' book The Posthumous Papers of the Pickwick Club and the character Joe who was a "wonderfully fat boy, standing upright with his eyes closed."

eponym.name: Pierre Robin syndrome
eponym.desc: Micrognathia and abnormal smallness of the tongue, often with cleft palate, severe myopia, congenital glaucoma, and retinal detachment; described by French dental surgeon Pierre Robin, 1867-1950.

eponym.name: pink disease
eponym.desc: Acrodynia, occurs from exposure to high concentrations of mercury vapor, characterized by a body rash, swelling and irritation of palms and feet followed by skin desquamation, irritability, photophobia, fever, insomnia and profuse sweating. May also follow oral exposure to mercury compounds.

eponym.name: Pisa syndrome
eponym.desc: Pleurothotonus, rare side-effect of classic neuroleptic medication, characterized by dystonia with flexion of body and head to one side and axial rotation of the trunk; has been seen in cholinesterase inhibitors as well; originally described in 1972. After leaning tower of Pisa.

eponym.name: Piskacek's sign
eponym.desc: Early sign of pregnancy where there is asymmetry of the uterus with a well-defined soft prominence of the cornu, due to implantation near one of the cornua; also known as von Braun-Fernwald's sign.

eponym.name: Pittsburgh pneumonia agent
eponym.desc: Legionella micdadei.

eponym.name: Plummer's disease
eponym.desc: Toxic multinodular goiter.

eponym.name: Plummer's nail
eponym.desc: Onycholysis as a sign of hyperthyroidism, especially when it affects the ring finger.

eponym.name: Plummer-Vinson syndrome
eponym.desc: Classic triad of dysphagia, iron deficiency anemia, and esophageal webs. Associated with atrophic glossitis and koilonychia. Associated with increased risk of squamous cell cancer of the pharynx and esophagus. Also known as Patterson-Brown-Kelly syndrome.

eponym.name: POEMS syndrome
eponym.desc: Polyneuropathy, Organomegaly, Endocrinopathy, M protein, and Skin changes which may be seen in plasma cell dyscrasias; also known as Crow-Fukase syndrome in Japan.

eponym.name: Pohl-Pinkus constriction
eponym.desc: Along hair shaft, area of decreased diameter, usually due to systemic stress, e.g. from chemotherapy, resulting in vulnerability to breaks. First described by Pohl in 1894, who later apparently changed his name to Pinkus. See also Beau's lines.

eponym.name: Poiseuille's law
eponym.desc: Flow proportional to fourth power of radius, inversely proportional to length.

eponym.name: Poland syndrome
eponym.desc: Amastia associated with hypoplasia of ipsilateral musculature (microsyndactyly or lack of one hand) and chest wall (atrophy of the ipsilateral pectoralis major) and GU abnormalities; 10% have dextrocardia or dextroversion.

eponym.name: Polle syndrome
eponym.desc: Munchausen's syndrome by proxy; after daughter Polle from second marriage of Munchausen to 17 y.o. Bernhardine at age 74, daughter died 1 year later (though paternity apparently suspect) (Lancet 1977;2:456); but daughter Polle apparently doesn't exist but name of town where Bernhardine came from (Pediatrics 1984;74:554).

eponym.name: Pompe's disease
eponym.desc: Type II glycogen storage disease, deficiency in alpha-1,4-glucosidase (lysosomal enzyme) with consequent accumulation of glycogen, especially in the liver, heart, and skeletal muscle, characterized by cardiomegaly, muscle hypotonia, and splenomegaly, death from cardiorespiratory failure before age 3.

eponym.name: Poncet's disease
eponym.desc: In acute tuberculosis infection, aseptic inflammatory polyarthritis.

eponym.name: Pontiac fever
eponym.desc: Nonpneumonic legionellosis. Named after July 1968 outbreak in Pontiac, Michigan.

eponym.name: Porter-Silber test
eponym.desc: Measurement of urinary 17-OH corticosteroid.

eponym.name: Posner-Schlossman syndrome
eponym.desc: Glaucomatocyclitic crisis; recurrent episodes of markedly elevated intraocular pressure with mild idiopathic anterior chamber inflammation.

eponym.name: Potocki-Lupski syndrome
eponym.desc: Syndrome characterized by mild mental retardation, attention-deficit, hyperactivity, and autism, short stature, and dental abnormalities such as malocclusion and crowded teeth. Associated with duplication of 17p11.2. Compare with Smith-Magenis syndrome, which is associated with deletino of 17p11.2.

eponym.name: Potter's sequence
eponym.desc: From oligohydramnios (from e.g. renal agenesis, amniotic leak) leading to amnion nodosum, fetal compression which leads to pulmonary hypoplasia, altered facies, positioning defects of feet, hands, and breech presentation.

eponym.name: Pott's disease
eponym.desc: Involvement of the spine with tuberculosis; occurs in about 2% of TB cases.

eponym.name: Pott's fracture
eponym.desc: Fracture of distal fibula.

eponym.name: Pott's puffy tumors
eponym.desc: Extension of frontal sinusitis anteriorly into frontal bone causing a distinct swelling.

eponym.name: Potts shunt
eponym.desc: For treating tetralogy of Fallot, anastomosis of direct descending aorta to left pulmonary artery; now rarely performed.

eponym.name: Poupart's ligament
eponym.desc: Inguinal ligament.

eponym.name: Prader-Willi syndrome
eponym.desc: Deletion of 15q11-q13 with paternal imprinting. Characterized by uncontrollable hyperphagia after 12 months, associated with short stature, hypogonadism, and mild mental retardation.

eponym.name: Pratt's sign
eponym.desc: In deep vein thrombosis, presence of three dilated veins or sentinel veins over the tibia; dilatation persists when legs are elevated to 45 degrees.

eponym.name: Prausnitz-Küstner reaction
eponym.desc: Passive transfer of cutaneous anaphylaxis; transferring serum of affected patient intradermally into a recipient and then challenging recipient with antigen 24 hours later at the same site and checking for wheal and flare; known since 1920s.

eponym.name: Prehn's sign
eponym.desc: Elevation of painful testicle decreases pain of epididymitis.

eponym.name: Preiser disease
eponym.desc: Spontaneous, non-traumatic osteonecrosis of the scaphoid bone.

eponym.name: Pringle maneuver
eponym.desc: Clamping of porta hepatis to control hemorrhage.

eponym.name: Prinzmetal's angina
eponym.desc: Variant angina occurring at rest, manifesting on EKG as episodic ST segment elevations, caused by coronary artery spasms with or without superimposed coronary artery disease; patients more likely to develop ventricular arrhythmias.

eponym.name: Probst bundle
eponym.desc: Callosal longitudinal bundle, seen in agenesis of the corpus callosum from fibers from the hemispheres failing to cross the midline and instead forming thick bundles.

eponym.name: Proteus syndrome
eponym.desc: Congenital condition characterized by generalized, unilateral, or localized overgrowth of any tissue type, hemihypertrophy, lymphangiomas, lipomas, hemangiomata macrocephaly; thought that Joseph Merrick, the "Elephant Man" may have had this condition rather than neurofibromatosis; associated with mutation in PTEN. Named after Greek sea-god, Proteus, who could change his appearance.

eponym.name: psammoma bodies
eponym.desc: Round collection of calcium seen in papillary thyroid cancer, renal cell carcinoma, etc.; from the Greek for "sand."

eponym.name: psoas sign
eponym.desc: Pain elicited by extending the hip with the knee in full extension, seen with appendicitis and psoas inflammation.

eponym.name: Puestow procedure
eponym.desc: For chronic pancreatitis, side-to-side anastomosis of the pancreas and jejunum for decompressing dilated main pancreatic duct and providing pain relief.

eponym.name: Pulfrich phenomenon
eponym.desc: Misperception of trajectory of moving objects (an optical illusion that can be elicited in normal subjects), can be associated with optic neuritis.

eponym.name: Purkinje cells
eponym.desc: Neurons in the cerebellar cortex that secrete GABA; some of the largest cells in the brain.

eponym.name: Purtilo's syndrome
eponym.desc: X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome, more commonly known as Duncan's disease.

eponym.name: Purtscher's angiopathic retinopathy
eponym.desc: In acute pancreatitis, sudden and severe loss of vision due to posterior retinal artery occlusion with aggregated granulocytes; discrete flame-shaped hemorrhages with cotton-wool spots; also seen in fat embolization. First described in 1919 by Othmar Purtscher.

eponym.name: Pyle's disease
eponym.desc: Metaphyseal dysplasia, few clinical associations other than genu valgum despite bizarre radiographic findings (e.g. marked thickening of ribs, clavicles, Erlenmeyer flask-like flare of femur). Autosomal recessive.

eponym.name: Quebec platelet disorder
eponym.desc: From excessive production of u-PA (urine plasminogen activator) within alpha granules of platelets. Autosomal dominant; characterized by mild thrombocytopenia and moderately severe bleeding 12-24 hours after surgery or trauma; also known as factor V Quebec (as 20% of factor V carried within alpha granules of platelets; u-PA activates plasminogen, degrades intraplatelet stores of factor V).

eponym.name: Queckenstedt's maneuver
eponym.desc: Applying pressure on the internal jugular vein to dilate cranial veins and increase incranial pressure and assess change in lumbar puncture opening pressure. In spinal stenosis, delayed response.

eponym.name: Queen Anne's sign
eponym.desc: In hypothyroidism, sparse eyebrows laterally; apparently it was fashionable to shave the lateral third of the eyebrow during the reign of Queen Anne (1707-1714) in Great Britain.

eponym.name: Quellung reaction
eponym.desc: Swelling of bacterial capsule when exposed to antibody; used for diagnosis of S. pneumoniae, H. influ type B, N. meningitidis groups A and C.

eponym.name: Queyrat, erythroplasia of
eponym.desc: Carcinoma in situ or invasive squamous cell cancer of the penile glans described by Auguste Queyrat, French dermatologist, born 1872.

eponym.name: Quilty lesion
eponym.desc: Endocardial infiltrates; associated with cyclosporine and waxing and waning levels of immunosuppresion; of unclear clinical significance; named after patient with this lesion.

eponym.name: Quincke's disease
eponym.desc: Angioedema.

eponym.name: Quincke's sign
eponym.desc: In aortic regurgitation, capillary pulsations detected by pressing a glass slide on the patient's lip or by transmitting a light through the patient's fingertips; of questionable utility since also seen in normal individuals.

eponym.name: Rabson-Mendenhall syndrome
eponym.desc: Congenital syndrome characterized by insulin resistance, acanthosis nigricans, and growth retardation; associated with developmental abnormalities of bones and teeth, polycystic ovarian disease, genitomegaly, and pineal gland hyperplasia; associated with mutation in insulin receptor.

eponym.name: Raeder's syndrome
eponym.desc: Also known as Raeder's paratrigeminal neuralgia, condition characterized by severe, unilateral headache, facial pain in distribution of ophthalmic division of trigeminal nerve combined with ipsilateral Horner's syndrome; also associated with nasal stuffiness or rhinorrhea. Felt to reflect pathology in location where oculosympathetic fibers exit the internal carotid artery to join the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve. First described in 1918 by George Raeder, Norwegian neurologist.

eponym.name: Raisinghani sign
eponym.desc: Paradoxical motion of the infero-posterior left ventricular wall in patients with liver disease and high intraabdominal pressures from hepatomegaly, ascites, splenomegaly or a combination of these.

eponym.name: Ramirez sign
eponym.desc: In deep vein thrombosis, sphygmomanometer cuff placed above knee inflated to 40 mm Hg causing pain at site of thrombosis.

eponym.name: Ramsay Hunt syndrome
eponym.desc: Herpes zoster infection of the geniculate ganglion; facial nerve involvement (ear, palate, pharynx, or neck); pain and vesicles appear in external auditory canal along with hyperacusia, and patients lose sense of taste in anterior 2/3 of tongue while developing ipsilateral facial palsy. Described by James Ramsay Hunt, American neurologist (1872-1937).

eponym.name: Randall disease
eponym.desc: Monoclonal light chain deposition disease; distinct from amyloidosis; associated with kappa light chains.

eponym.name: Randle cycle
eponym.desc: Glucose-free fatty acid cycle; inverse relationship between glucose and free fatty acid use.

eponym.name: Ranke complex
eponym.desc: Combination of Ghon lesion and involved lymph nodes in tuberculosis.

eponym.name: Ranson's criteria
eponym.desc: For evaluating acute pancreatitis at presentation, age>55; WBC>16,000; glucose>200; AST>250; LDH>350. During initial 48 hrs, base deficit>4; BUN increase>5; fluid sequestration>6L; Ca<8; Hct decrease>10; pO2<60. Mortality with 0-2 criteria, <5%; 3-4, 15%; 5-6, 40%; 7-8, 100%.

eponym.name: Rapoport-Luebering shunt
eponym.desc: In red blood cells, pathway converting 1,3-diphosphoglyceric acid to 2,3-DPG and then to 3-phosphoglyceric acid; enzyme is diphosphoglycerate synthetase; 2,3-DPG reduces affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen; 2,3-DPG rises with alkalosis and decreases with acidosis, result of effect of pH on enzyme.

eponym.name: Rapunzel syndrome
eponym.desc: Small bowel obstruction by trichobezoar, named after Rapunzel, the German princess in Grimms' fairytales who let her golden hair down from her tower to facilitate a tryst with her lover.

eponym.name: Rashkind's atrial septostomy
eponym.desc: For treating transposition of great arteries, tricuspid atresia, and mitral atresia; catheter-based creation of atrial septal defect via foramen ovale.

eponym.name: Rasmussen's aneurysm
eponym.desc: Aneurysm of the PA or pulmonary arteriole within or adjacent to a tuberculosis cavity.

eponym.name: Rasmussen's encephalitis
eponym.desc: Progressive childhood disease characterized by severe epilepsy, hemiplegia, dementia, and inflammation of the brain potentially from autoantibodies to GluR3 antigen.

eponym.name: Rastelli procedure
eponym.desc: For treating transposition of great vessels with pulmonary stenosis, patching ventricular septal defect such that LV outflow passes through VSD into aorta, and a valved conduit or graft is placed between the RV and pulmonary arteries.

eponym.name: Rathke's pouch
eponym.desc: A diverticulum involved in development of pituitary gland, vestigial remnants are the origin of craniopharyngioma.

eponym.name: Raynaud's phenomenon
eponym.desc: Exaggerated vascular response to cold temperatures or emotional stress, manifested by symmetrical, sharply demarcated color changes of the skin of the digits due to abnormal vasoconstriction of digital arteries and cutaneous arterioles.

eponym.name: Rebuck skin window
eponym.desc: For assessing inflammatory response, dermal abrasion technique to visualize tissue penetration of neutrophils, scraping forearm, then putting coverslip over it, checking glass for neutrophils.

eponym.name: Reed-Sternberg cells
eponym.desc: In Hodgkin's disease, giant macrophage-like cells with two nuclei.

eponym.name: Refsum's disease
eponym.desc: Autosomal recessive disorder from absence of the enzyme alpha-phytanic acid alpha-hydroxylase, leading to accumulation of phytanic acid. Treated with large amounts of nicotinic acid or triparanol, chemicals that inhibit lipid synthesis. Dryness and scaling similar to the appearance of icthyosis develop, associated with neuropathy.

eponym.name: Reichert's cartilage
eponym.desc: Branchial arch 2.

eponym.name: Reid index
eponym.desc: Comparing the relative thickness of the mucous glands with the total thickness of the airway wall; increased in patients with chronic bronchitis (normally < 0.4).

eponym.name: Reifenstein syndrome
eponym.desc: Partial androgen insensitivity; from mutation in androgen receptor; male pseudohermaphroditism characterized by hypospadias, hypogonadism, gynecomastia, normal XY karyotpe, X-linked recessive.

eponym.name: Reinke crystals
eponym.desc: In 25% of Leydig cell tumors, intracytoplasmic rod-shaped crystalloids.

eponym.name: Reinke's edema
eponym.desc: Vocal cord polyposis in female smokers, 50s-70s.

eponym.name: Reitan trail test
eponym.desc: Timed connect-the-number test for detecing alterations in mental status; time >60 s pathologic in all age groups.

eponym.name: Reiter's syndrome
eponym.desc: Reactive arthritis, triad of arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis described by Reiter in 1916; 80% possess HLA-B27; associated with Shigella flexneri; develops in 20% of exposed B27+ individuals. Triad present in 1/3 of patients; incidence estimated as 3.5/100K in males under age of 50. Associated with balanitis circinata (penis) and keratoderma blenorrhagica. Reiter was a Nazi physician and war criminal, participating in experiments on prisoners at Buchenwald.

eponym.name: Renshaw cells
eponym.desc: Inhibitory cells in the ventral horn of the spinal cord.

eponym.name: Rett syndrome
eponym.desc: Childhood developmental disorder almost exclusively affecting girls who develop normally for the first few months of life before undergoing a period of regression. Patients develop stereotypic hand-wringing movements, loss of speech, ataxia, and episodes of hyperventilation. From mutation in MECP2 on X chromosome which binds to single methylated CpG base pairs and "silences" other genes. This results in excessive transcriptional noise.

eponym.name: Retzius, space of
eponym.desc: The preperitoneal space anterior to the bladder.

eponym.name: Retzius, veins of
eponym.desc: Numerous small veins in the retroperitoneum that connect the retroperitoneal viscera to the posterior abdominal wall; may be dilated in portal hypertension.

eponym.name: Reye's syndrome
eponym.desc: Rare disease characterized by fatty change in liver and encephalopathy that in its most severe forms may be fatal; associated with VZV and influenza virus B in children given aspirin.

eponym.name: Reynold's pentad
eponym.desc: Charcot's triad plus altered mental status and shock in cholangitis.

eponym.name: Ribot's law
eponym.desc: In retrograde amnesia, recent memories are more likely to be lost; hypothesized by Ribot in 1881.

eponym.name: Rich foci
eponym.desc: Small subpial or subependymal foci of metastatic tuberculosis lesions in meninges or brain parenchyma.

eponym.name: Richter syndrome
eponym.desc: The evolution of chronic lymphocytic leukemia to a diffuse large B cell lymphoma with high fever, weight loss, enlarging lymph nodes, and hepatosplenomegaly.

eponym.name: Richter's hernia
eponym.desc: Incarcerated or strangulated hernia involving only one sidewall of the bowel, which can spontaneously reduce, resulting in gangrenous bowel and perforation within the abdomen without signs of obstruction.

eponym.name: Riddoch's sign
eponym.desc: In cerebellar disease, with outstretched hands, the hand on the affected side begins to hyperpronate, so that the palm faces outward, and rises above the level of the other hand.

eponym.name: Riedel's lobe
eponym.desc: Elongated, right lobe of the liver that projects downward towards the iliac crest, especially in individuals with a lean build.

eponym.name: Riedel's thyroiditis
eponym.desc: Unknown etiology, marked by glandular atrophy, hypothyroidism, and replacement of the thyroid by fibrous tissue with adhesion to surrounding structures.

eponym.name: Riesman's sign
eponym.desc: Bruit over closed eyes in thyrotoxicosis.

eponym.name: Rigler's sign
eponym.desc: On plain abdominal films in pneumoperitoneum, bowel wall is outlined by air. Named after Leo Rigler (1896-1979), an American radiologist.

eponym.name: Riley-Day syndrome
eponym.desc: Hereditary sensory and autonomic neuropathy type III (familial dysautonomia), autosomal recessive disorder that commences in infancy and is characterized by conspicuous autonomic dysfunction (absent tearing, labile temperature, and blood pressure), and accompanied by absent taste sensation, absent fungiform papillae on tongue, impaired pain and temperature sensation, and areflexia. Occurs among Ashkenazi; associated with mutation in IKBKAP gene.

eponym.name: Rinne test
eponym.desc: Vibrating tuning fork placed against mastoid and then next to ear; in sensorineural loss, air conduction is better than bone conduction; in conduction loss, bone conduction better than air conduction.

eponym.name: Ritgen maneuver
eponym.desc: For delivery of the fetal head by pressing with the tips of the fingers upon the perineum via the anus; alternatively, protection of the perineum by providing support of the perineum with pressure over the coccygeal area.

eponym.name: Ritter's disease
eponym.desc: Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome.

eponym.name: Roberts syndrome
eponym.desc: Autosomal recessive syndrome characterized by absence of leg bones, hypoplastic arms, bilateral cleft lip and cleft palate, prominent eyes. Due to mutation in ESCO2 gene.

eponym.name: Robertsonian translocation
eponym.desc: Joining of two acrocentric chromosomes at the centromeres with loss of their short arms to form a single abnormal chromosome; acrocentric chromosomes include Y chromosome and chromosome numbers 13, 14, 15, 21, and 22.

eponym.name: Robinow's syndrome
eponym.desc: Short stature syndrome, mesomelic shortening, hemivertebrae, genital hypoplasia, and "fetal facies." Due to mutation in ROR2.

eponym.name: Rocky Mountain spotted fever
eponym.desc: Rickettsial illness caused by Rickettsia rickettsii, spread to human by ixodid ticks; characterized by sudden onset of fever, headache, myalgias, purpura. First recognized in 1896 in Snake River Valley of Idaho. However, name is a misnomer as it occurs throughout the U.S.

eponym.name: Roger's disease
eponym.desc: Small congenital ventricular septal defect <0.5 cm in diameter (most are muscular); Henri L. Roger, French physician, 1809-1891.

eponym.name: Rokitansky-Aschoff sinuses
eponym.desc: Small outpouchings of the gallbladder mucosa that may penetrate into and through the muscle wall; their prominence in inflammation and gallstone formation (e.g. chronic cholecystitis) suggests that they are acquired herniations.

eponym.name: Romaña's sign
eponym.desc: In the first week of Chagas disease, unilateral periorbital edema and swelling of the eyelid associated with reduviid bug of eye.

eponym.name: Romano-Ward syndrome
eponym.desc: Long QT syndrome without deafness, inherited as autosomal dominant.

eponym.name: Romanus lesion
eponym.desc: Anterior spondylitis, focal destruction of anterior borders of vertebral body, resulting in "shiny corner" sign. Seen in ankylosing spondylitis.

eponym.name: Romberg test
eponym.desc: Patient stands feet together, eyes open and then closes both eyes for 20 to 30 sec without support; positive test with eyes open suggestive of cerebellar ataxia; with eyes closed suggestive of impaired proprioception (e.g. from pathology of dorsal columns).

eponym.name: Roos sign
eponym.desc: In thoracic outlet syndrome, abduction of the shoulders to 90 degrees, flexion of the elbows to 90 degrees, and opening and closing the hands slowly for 3 minutes causing hand pallor, ulnar dysesthesias, diminished pulse.

eponym.name: Rosai-Dorfman disease
eponym.desc: Sinus histiocytosis with massive lymphadenopathy (mainly neck), fever, polyclonal hypergammaglobulinemia; extranodal sites involved in 43%; first described in 1969.

eponym.name: Rosenbach's sign
eponym.desc: In aortic regurgitation, hepatic pulsations.

eponym.name: Rosenbach's sign
eponym.desc: In thyrotoxicosis, tremor of the closed eyelids.

eponym.name: Rosenmuller fossa
eponym.desc: A pharyngeal fossa behind the eustachian orifice where nasopharyngeal carcinoma most commonly occurs; named after Italian anatomist.

eponym.name: Rosenthal fibers
eponym.desc: Eosinophilic inclusions that develop in astrocytes in chronic reactive and neoplastic proliferations; abundant in Alexander's disease.

eponym.name: Rosenthal syndrome
eponym.desc: Factor XI deficiency; described by Rosenthal in 1953; also referred to as plasma thromboplastin antecedent deficiency. May be associated with bleeding. Predominantly in patients of Ashkenazi background.

eponym.name: Ross procedure
eponym.desc: Aortic valve replacement involving translocation of native pulmonary valve into aortic position with coronary artery relocation followed by reconstructing RV outflow tract with pulmonary homograft.

eponym.name: Ross's syndrome
eponym.desc: Tonic pupils (generally bilateral), anhydrosis, and areflexia which may appear in a different pattern distribution; possible link with Holmes-Adie syndrome.

eponym.name: Roth-Bielschowsky syndrome
eponym.desc: Internuclear ophthalmoplegia; caused by lesions in medial longitudinal fasiculus; bilateral lesions almost always due to multiple sclerosis; unilateral lesion often due to vascular occlusion.

eponym.name: Rothmann-Makai syndrome
eponym.desc: A variant of idiopathic lobular panniculitis seen in infants, tends to be localized and spontaneously resolves; associated with autoimmune diseases such as juvenile rheumatoid arthritis, diabetes, and Hashimoto's thyroiditis.

eponym.name: Rothmund-Thomson syndrome
eponym.desc: Autosomal recessive disorder characterized by poikilodermatous skin changes that develop in infancy, premature aging, juvenile cataracts, sparse hair, short stature, skeletal defects, dystrophic nails, and predisposition for malignancies including osteosarcoma.

eponym.name: Roth's spots
eponym.desc: In bacterial endocarditis and other retinal hemorrhagic conditions, a round white spot surrounded by hemorrhage (secondary to microemboli in endocarditis).

eponym.name: Rotor's syndrome
eponym.desc: Poorly defined defects in hepatic uptake and storage of bilirubin, resulting in jaundice; resembles Dubin-Johnson syndrome, but liver is of normal appearance. Named after Filipino internist, Arturo Rotor (1907-1988).

eponym.name: Rotter's lymph nodes
eponym.desc: Lymph nodes between the pectoralis minor and pectoralis major; can be site of involvement in breast cancer.

eponym.name: Rouget cells
eponym.desc: Pericytes or periendothelial cells.

eponym.name: Roussy-Levy syndrome
eponym.desc: Hereditary areflexic dystasia; phenotypic variant of Charcot-Marie-Tooth (CMT-1B) associated with postural tremor and ataxia; autosomal dominant inheritance.

eponym.name: Roux-en-Y anastomosis
eponym.desc: Anastomosis between small bowel and small bowel that is distal from the cut end; used as part of e.g. gastric bypass or gastrectomy. Named after Swiss surgeon Cesar Roux.

eponym.name: Rovsing's sign
eponym.desc: In appendicitis, pain in the right lower quadrant when applying left-sided pressure or quick withdrawal of pressure (i.e. referred rebound tenderness).

eponym.name: RSH syndrome
eponym.desc: See Smith-Lemli-Opitz syndrome. "RSH" refers to first initial of the first three patients with Smith-Lemli-Opitz syndrome.

eponym.name: Rubinstein-Taybi syndrome
eponym.desc: Congenital condition characterized by mental and growth retardation, short broad thumbs and/or halluces, and typical facial features. Associated with mutation in CREB-binding protein.

eponym.name: Ruffini's corpuscles
eponym.desc: Sensory receptor nerve ending for heat; not lamellated.

eponym.name: Rumpel-Leede sign
eponym.desc: Test for capillary fragility carried out by increasing venous pressure in forearm with BP cuff and then inspecting the skin for petechial eruptions. Also called Hess test; associated with scurvy.

eponym.name: Russell bodies
eponym.desc: Distended, eosinophilic inclusions in endoplasmic reticulum of plasma cells engaged in active synthesis of immunoglobulins. Seen in Waldenström's macroglobulinemia.

eponym.name: Russell viper venom time
eponym.desc: Sensitive screening test for lupus anticoagulant activity. Russell viper venom directly activates factor X to Xa and requires phospholipid; from the venom of Vipera russelli. In the presence of lupus anticoagulant, prolongs time due to the presence of antiphospholipid antibody.

eponym.name: Russell's sign
eponym.desc: Lanugo, dry skin, and hand calluses, associated with purging and bulimia.

eponym.name: Ruvalcaba-Myhre-Smith syndrome
eponym.desc: Association of macrocephaly, intestinal polyposis, and pigmentation of the penis; related to Bannayan-Zonana syndrome.

eponym.name: Sabin-Feldman dye test
eponym.desc: Serum titer rises in toxoplasma infection.

eponym.name: Sabouraud's agar
eponym.desc: For growing fungi, low pH of medium and chloramphenicol and cycloheximide.

eponym.name: Saethre-Chotzen syndrome
eponym.desc: Craniosynostosis syndrome characterized by craniofacial and limb anomalies; associated with mutation in TWIST transcription gene.

eponym.name: Sailer's sign
eponym.desc: In aortic regurgitation, pulsation of spleen in the setting of splenomegaly. See also Gerhardt's sign.

eponym.name: Saint's triad
eponym.desc: The coexistence of hiatal hernia, gallbladder disease, and diverticulosis in a patient; named after Saint, a South African surgeon; no pathophysiologic basis for the coexistence of all three processes, emphasizing that more than one disease process may be responsible for a patient's symptoms.

eponym.name: Salisbury effect
eponym.desc: Reduction in left ventricular diastolic distensibility with increase in coronary flow and perfusion pressure.

eponym.name: Salter-Harris fracture
eponym.desc: Fracture involving growth plate. Six types: type I, transverse fracture through growth plate; type II, fracture through growth plate and metaphysis, excluding epiphysis (75% incidence); type III, fracture through growth plate and epiphysis, sparing metaphysis; type IV, fracture through growth plate, metaphysis, and epiphysis; type V, compression fracture of growth plate; type VI, injury to periphery of physis, leading to bony bridge formation and angular deformity.

eponym.name: Salus's sign
eponym.desc: Deflection of veins at AV crossings in hypertensive retinopathy (grade 2); see also Bonnet's sign and Gunn's sign.

eponym.name: Sampson's artery
eponym.desc: Artery found within and nourishes round ligament of uterus.

eponym.name: Samter's triad
eponym.desc: Nasal polyps, bronchial asthma, aspirin sensitivity; associated with excessive production of cysteinyl leukotrienes both before and after aspirin challenge.

eponym.name: San Joaquin valley fever
eponym.desc: Coccidiomycosis, from infection with Coccidiomycosis imites.

eponym.name: Sandhoff's disease
eponym.desc: Lysosomal storage disorder, a GM2 gangliosidosis, from mutation in beta subunit of both hexosaminidase A and B; clinically similar as Tay-Sachs disease but more rapid progression of disease.

eponym.name: Sandifer syndrome
eponym.desc: Association of torsional dystonia, mainly involving the neck and upper extremities, with either esophageal reflux or hiatus hernia; presents in childhood; at times mistaken for seizures.

eponym.name: Sanfilippo's syndrome
eponym.desc: Mucopolysaccharidosis, four types (A-D) from deficiency of enzymatic steps necessary for removal of N-sulfated or N-acetylated glucosamine residues from heparan sulfate, leading to mental retardation, CNS disorders, coarse facies.

eponym.name: Sanjad-Sakati syndrome
eponym.desc: Congenital syndrome hypoparathyroidism, mental retardation, facial dysmorphism, and growth failure. Associated with mutation in tubulin-specific chaperone E. Mutation in same gene associated with Kenney-Caffey syndrome.

eponym.name: Sano modification
eponym.desc: Modification of the Norwood procedure for hypoplastic left heart syndrome. Instead of placement of a Blalock-Taussig shunt for pulmonary blood flow, a right ventricle to pulmonary artery conduit is used.

eponym.name: Santavuori-Haltia disease
eponym.desc: Infantile neuronal ceroid lipofuscinosis, CLN1, associated with mutation in palmitoyl-protein thioesterase-1 (PPT1).

eponym.name: Santorini, duct of
eponym.desc: Dorsal duct of pancreas, embryologically, the biggest duct, clinically the smaller pancreatic duct.

eponym.name: Santorini's fissures
eponym.desc: Fissures in anterior aspect of cartilaginous portion of ear canal through which neurovascular tissues pass; may allow spread of ear disease to parotid joint, TMJ, soft tissues of upper neck.

eponym.name: Santos's syndrome
eponym.desc: Hirschsprung's disease with renal agenesis, polydactyly, hypertelorism, and deafness.

eponym.name: Sappey, veins of
eponym.desc: Retroperitoneal veins located around liver and diaphragm connecting epigastric and internal mammary veins with azygos; become dilated in portal hypertension.

eponym.name: Sapporo criteria
eponym.desc: Criteria used for making diagnosis of antiphospholipid syndrome, including vascular thrombosis, spontaneous abortions, and presence of anticardiolipin and lupus anticoagulant. Antiphospholipid syndrome present if one of the clinical and one of the laboratory criteria present.

eponym.name: Saturday night palsy
eponym.desc: Radial neuropathy from compression at the spiral groove.

eponym.name: Saxon test
eponym.desc: For diagnosing Sjögren's syndrome, measurement of whole mouth saliva production (analogous to Schirmer's test for tears) by asking patients to chew a gauze sponge; normal is increase in weight of 2.75 g over 2 min.

eponym.name: Scarpa's fasica
eponym.desc: Fascia around edge of subcutaneous inguinal ring.

eponym.name: Schafer's maneuver
eponym.desc: Extensor plantar response by squeezing Achilles tendon suggesting upper motor neuron defect.

eponym.name: Schaltenbrand sydnrome
eponym.desc: Spontaneous intracranial hypotension, a cause of headaches; characterized by orthostatic headaches. Leakage of CSF is the most common cause.

eponym.name: Schamberg's disease
eponym.desc: Idiopathic capillaritis in which inflammation weakens capillaries, causes petechial lesions resembling cayenne pepper.

eponym.name: Schamroth's window
eponym.desc: Normal diamond-shaped window formed by the nail bases when ends of opposing ends of fingers are placed together. In clubbing, this window is not seen.

eponym.name: Schatzki's ring
eponym.desc: Esophageal rings and webs in lower esophagus, located at or just above the squamocolumnar junction; most common cause of intermittent solid food obstruction.

eponym.name: Schaumann's bodies
eponym.desc: Laminated concretions composed of calcium and proteins, seen in granulomatous diseases (e.g. sarcoidosis).

eponym.name: Scheibe dysplasia
eponym.desc: Cochelosaccular dysplasia of the inner ear.

eponym.name: Scheie's syndrome
eponym.desc: Mucopolysaccharidosis (I S), from alpha-L-iduronidase deficiency (same as Hurler's syndrome), milder than Hurler's syndrome, resulting in corneal clouding, stiff joints, aortic valve disease, normal intelligence and potentially normal life span.

eponym.name: Scheuermann's disease
eponym.desc: Juvenile kyphosis characterized by end-plate irregularities and wedging of the vertebral body without loss of bone density, develops in adolescence.

eponym.name: Schick's test
eponym.desc: For testing immune status to Cornyebacterium diphtheriae, intradermal injection of 0.1 mL of purified standardized toxin; if no inflammation, antitoxin present.

eponym.name: Schilder's disease
eponym.desc: Adrenoleukodystrophy, X-linked disorder, presents in childhood with weakness, spasticity, leading to dementia, blindness, and quadriparesis, associated with adrenal insufficiency; from defect in beta-oxidation of fatty acids in peroxisomes leading to accumulation of very long-chain saturated fatty acids.

eponym.name: Schiller-Duval body
eponym.desc: In endodermal sinus tumor (yolk sac tumor), tumor cells arranged around a capillary.

eponym.name: Schilling test
eponym.desc: For determining cause of B12 deficiency. First stage, measuring cobalamin (B12) absorption by measuring urinary excretion of p.o. radioactive cobalamin over 24 to 48 hours (after i.m. injection of B12 to saturate the transcobalamins and to "flush" orally absorbed radiolabeled B12 into the urine). Second stage, test repeated with oral intrinsic factor, which should normalize B12 absorption in pernicious anemia but not in intestinal malabsorption.

eponym.name: Schimke immuno-osseous dysplasia
eponym.desc: Autosomal recessive pleiotropic disorder with the diagnostic features of spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia, renal dysfunction and T-cell immunodeficiency; associated with mutation in SMARCAL1 (SWI/SNF2-related, matrix-associated, actin-dependent regulator of chromatin, subfamily a-like 1).

eponym.name: Schinzel-Giedion syndrome
eponym.desc: Congenital, autosomal recessive condition characterized by seizures, spasticity, and mental retardation with high protruding forehead, midface retraction, hypertelorism, and prominent ear lobes. Described in 1978.

eponym.name: Schirmer's test
eponym.desc: Used for diagnosing Sjögren's syndrome, measure quantity of tears secreted in 5 minutes in response to irritation from a filter strip placed under each lower eyelid; normal young person moistens 15 mm; 33% of elderly wet only 10 mm in 5 minutes; in Sjögren's syndrome, <5 mm in 5 min, 85% sensitivity, 85% specificity.

eponym.name: Schlesinger's solution
eponym.desc: Morphine and scopolamine.

eponym.name: Schmid metaphyseal chondrodysplasia
eponym.desc: A type of chondrodysplasia due to mutation in collagen 10A1, mechanical pressure reduces growth; associated with bow legs and coxa vara.

eponym.name: Schmidt's syndrome
eponym.desc: Type II polyglandular autoimmune syndrome, coexistent adrenal and thyroid disease, sometimes accompanied by diabetes.

eponym.name: Schmorl's nodule
eponym.desc: Herniated nucleus pulposus; resembles osteomyelitis.

eponym.name: Schnitzler's syndrome
eponym.desc: Association of IgM monoclonal protein (e.g. as with Waldenström's macroglobulinemia) with erythematous, urticarial skin lesions.

eponym.name: Schober test
eponym.desc: Measure distance between two marks on the skin during forward flexion; increase in distance decreased in ankylosing spondylitis.

eponym.name: Schüffner's granules
eponym.desc: Pigment in trophozoite, seen in Plasmodium vivax.

eponym.name: Schultz-Charlton phenomenon
eponym.desc: Blanching observed after intradermal injection of 0.1 mL of antitoxin to erythrogenic toxin of scarlet fever into an area of scarlet fever rash within 12-24 h. The test has to be performed during the very early phase of the eruption before exudation into the lesion makes skin changes irreversible. See also Dick test.

eponym.name: Schwartz-Bartter syndrome
eponym.desc: SIADH.

eponym.name: Schwartze's sign
eponym.desc: In otosclerosis, reddish hue behind an intact tympanic membrane, due to increased vascularity of cochlear promontory in otosclerotic lesion. Seen in 10% of otosclerosis.

eponym.name: Schwartzman reaction
eponym.desc: Two intravenous injections of sublethal lipopolysaccharide, 24 hrs apart, causing DIC in rabbits from widespread intravascular thrombus formation on surfaces of endothelial cells; TNF obligatory mediator.

eponym.name: Schwartz's dictum
eponym.desc: No acid, no ulcer.

eponym.name: Scott syndrome
eponym.desc: Defect in primary homeostasis, prolonged PT, deficiency in platelet coagulant activity characterized by a failure to expose phosphatidylserine (PS) to the outer leaflet of the platelet plasma membrane.

eponym.name: Seckel syndrome
eponym.desc: Rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by "bird-headed" facial appearance, growth retardation, and microcephaly with mental retardation; associated with mutation in gene encoding ataxia-telangiectasia and RAD3-related protein (ATR).

eponym.name: second disease
eponym.desc: Scarlet fever, aka scarlatina, caused by Strep pyogenes exotoxin, first described in 1626.

eponym.name: Segawa syndrome
eponym.desc: Hereditary progressive dystonia with marked diurnal fluctuation from defect in GTP cyclohydrase I, cofactor for synthesis of dopamine; dystonia treatable with levodopa. Autosomal recessive.

eponym.name: Seidel's sign
eponym.desc: In eyeball globe rupture, fluorescein streaming away from puncture site in a tear drop pattern.

eponym.name: Seldinger technique
eponym.desc: Guide wire-assisted vascular cannulation, i.e., small-bore needle first used to enter vessel, then wire passed through needle, needle removed, leaving wire in place for guiding cannulation of vessel, developed in 1953.

eponym.name: Seligmann's disease
eponym.desc: Alpha heavy chain disease, a rare B cell lymphoproliferative disease characterized by infiltration of the lamina propria of the small intestine with lymphoplasmacytoid cells that secrete truncated alpha chains.

eponym.name: Sellick's maneuver
eponym.desc: Cricoid pressure during intubation. Described by Brian Sellick in 1961, an anesthesiologist at Middlesex Hospital in London.

eponym.name: Selye's syndrome
eponym.desc: General adaptation syndrome; reactions and physiological changes following exposure to stress.

eponym.name: Semmes-Weinstein nylon test
eponym.desc: Nylon monofilament developed in 1950s for sensation testing; can be used in diabetic foot screening with a 5.07 monofilament which delivers 10 g of force.

eponym.name: Semont maneuver
eponym.desc: In benign positional vertigo, a liberatory maneuver where the patient is moved rapidly from side to side; not favored in the U.S. (also see Epley maneuver and Brandt-Daroff exercises).

eponym.name: Senear-Usher syndrome
eponym.desc: Pemphigus erythematosus; a localized variant of pemphigus foliaceus confined to seborrheic sites.

eponym.name: Sengstaken-Blakemore tube
eponym.desc: A double-balloon system tube, one for stomach, one for esophagus, for tamponade of bleeding varices.

eponym.name: Sennetsu fever
eponym.desc: Human ehrlichiosis from Ehrlichia sennetsu, generally not fatal, occurring mainly in Japan.

eponym.name: Senning procedure
eponym.desc: Variant of Mustard procedure.

eponym.name: Sertoli cell tumors
eponym.desc: Testicular tumor derived from the sex cord.

eponym.name: Sever's disease
eponym.desc: Apophysitis or osteochondrosis of the calcaneus, common (but frequently source of heel pain), condition occurs before or during the peak growth spurt, often resolves two weeks or two months after initiation of conservative treatment.

eponym.name: Sézary-Lutzner cells
eponym.desc: Found in cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, T-helper cells that characteristically form band-like aggregates within the superficial dermis and invade the epidermis as single cells and small clusters (Pautrier's microabscesses).

eponym.name: Sézary's syndrome
eponym.desc: Rare special variant of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma characterized by generalized or universal erythroderma, peripheral lymphadenopathy, and cellular infiltrates of atypical lymphocytes (Sézary cells) in the skin and blood.

eponym.name: Shah-Waardenburg syndrome
eponym.desc: See Waardenburg's syndrome type IV.

eponym.name: Shapiro's syndrome
eponym.desc: Agenesis of the corpus callosum associated with spontaneous recurrent hypothermia and hyperhidrosis.

eponym.name: Sheehan's syndrome
eponym.desc: Postpartum pituitary necrosis, syndrome results from sudden infarction of the anterior lobe precipitated by obstetric hemorrhage or shock (in pregnancy, pituitary enlarges to almost twice its normal size, compressing blood supply).

eponym.name: Shelley's sign
eponym.desc: In aortic regurgitation, pulsation of the cervix (J Indiana State Med Assoc 1959;52:1283-89).

eponym.name: Shenton's line
eponym.desc: A radiological line drawn between the medial border of the femoral neck and the superior border of the obturator foramen; interrupted in dislocations and fractures.

eponym.name: Shiraz dwarfism
eponym.desc: Zinc deficiency seen in Iran, associated with short stature and aspermia.

eponym.name: Shohl's solution
eponym.desc: An alkalinizing citrate solution used to treat e.g. renal tubular acidosis.

eponym.name: Shone's complex
eponym.desc: Series of four obstructive or potentially obstructive congenital left-sided cardiac lesions: supravalvular mitral ring, parachute deformity of mitral valve, subaortic stenosis, and coarctation of the aorta.

eponym.name: shoshin syndrome
eponym.desc: Acute fulminant cardiac beriberi (in Japanese, sho is acute damage, shin is heart).

eponym.name: Shprintzen syndrome
eponym.desc: Velo-cardio-facial syndrome, associated with cleft palate, cardiac anomalies, typical facies, and learning disabilities; may result from mutation in same gene as DiGeorge syndrome given clinical overlap between the two syndromes. Maps to 1.5-3.0 Mb region of 22q11.2.

eponym.name: Shulman's syndrome
eponym.desc: Eosinophilic fasciitis, characterized by acute onset of erythema, swelling, induration of the extremities, and eosinophilia, often following exercise; epidermis and dermis normal.

eponym.name: Shwachman-Diamond syndrome
eponym.desc: Combination of neutropenia, metaphyseal dysplasia, and exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, associated with recurrent infections in the first year of life in the sinuses, bones, lungs, skin and urinary tract, fatty replacement of liver. Associated with increased risk of aplasia, myelodysplasia, and leukemia; life expectancy is 35 years. Second most common cause of pancreatic insufficiency in children after cystic fibrosis.

eponym.name: Shy-Drager syndrome
eponym.desc: Multiple system atrophy, a degenerative disorder characterized by parkinsonian features (leading to postural hypotension, anhidrosis, disturbance of sphincter control, impotence, etc.) and signs of more widespread neurologic involvement (pyramidal or lower motor neuron signs and often a cerebellar deficit).

eponym.name: Siegrist streaks
eponym.desc: Linear hyperpigmented areas over choroidal vessels in hypertensive retinopathy.

eponym.name: Siewert syndrome
eponym.desc: See Kartagener's syndrome.

eponym.name: silk glove sign
eponym.desc: Indirect hernia sac in the pediatric patient; the sac feels like a finger of a silk glove when rolled under the examining finger.

eponym.name: Silk Road disease
eponym.desc: See Behçet's disease.

eponym.name: Silver-Russell syndrome
eponym.desc: Syndrome characterized by lateral asymmetry and low-birth-weight dwarfism.

eponym.name: Simmond's disease
eponym.desc: Hypopituitarism, especially in the presence of cachexia (e.g. from Sheehan's syndrome).

eponym.name: Simmond's test
eponym.desc: For testing Achilles tendon, lack of plantar flexion after squeezing calf muscles suggests rupture of tendon; see Thompson's test.

eponym.name: Simon focus
eponym.desc: In tuberculosis, nodule in subapical region which develops from hematogenous spread from initial infection in lower half of lung.

eponym.name: Sims-Huhner test
eponym.desc: Post-coital test, done 2-4 hrs after intercourse to assess number and motility of sperm that have entered the cervical canal.

eponym.name: singers's nodule
eponym.desc: Small, benign laryngeal polyp, usually induced by chronic irritation, such as excessive use of the voice, and is associated most commonly with heavy cigarette smoking. Uually localized to the true vocal cords.

eponym.name: Sipple's syndrome
eponym.desc: Multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) type IIa: pheochromocytoma, medullary carcinoma of the thyroid, and hyperparathyroidism due to hyperplasia or tumor. Associated with mutation in RET (a receptor tyrosine kinase).

eponym.name: Sippy powders
eponym.desc: For treating peptic ulcer disease in early 1900s, powder containing 600 mg of magnesium carbonate and 600 mg sodium bicarbonate alternating with a powder containing 600 mg of bismuth subcarbonate and 1200 to 1800 mg of sodium bicarbonate; associated with milk alkali syndrome.

eponym.name: Sister Mary Joseph nodule
eponym.desc: Metastasis to the umbilicus from an abdominal malignancy, especially gastric. English surgeon Sir Hamilton Bailey named this finding after Sister Mary Joseph (1856-1939), a superintendent nurse at St. Mary's Hospital in Rochester, Minn., who noted the association between periumbilical nodules and intraabdominal cancer.

eponym.name: Sistrunk procedure
eponym.desc: Removal of benign thyroglossal duct cysts where the cyst, the central portion of the hyoid bone, and the entire thyroglossal tract are removed.

eponym.name: sixth disease
eponym.desc: Roseola infantilis, also known as exanthem subitum, caused by HHV 6, described in 1910.

eponym.name: Sjogren-Larsson syndrome
eponym.desc: Metabolic disorder characterized by icthyosis, mental retardation, and spastic diplegia or tetraplegia; due to deficiency of fatty aldehyde dehydrogenase.

eponym.name: Sjögren's syndrome
eponym.desc: Autoimmune disorder with lymphocytic infiltration affecting salivary and lacrimal glands, associated with dry mouth and dry eyes (keratoconjunctivitis sicca). May also have either interstitial pulmonary fibrosis or a lymphocytic infiltration of the alveolar walls. Also may be associated with malignant transformation to lymphoma.

eponym.name: Skene's glands
eponym.desc: Paraurethral glands in women.

eponym.name: Skirrow's medium
eponym.desc: Contains vancomycin, trimethoprim, cephalothin, polymixin, and amphotericin B; for growing e.g. Campylobacter.

eponym.name: Skoda's sign
eponym.desc: With large pleural effusion or area of consolidation, increased resonance above effusion.

eponym.name: Sluder's disease
eponym.desc: Lower-half headache, characterized by unilateral pain involving maxilla, teeth, ear, mastoid, and base of nose; tendency for long remissions and serial attacks.

eponym.name: Sly's syndrome
eponym.desc: Mucopolysaccharidosis (VII), from beta-glucoronidase deficiency, resulting in hepatosplenomegaly, physical deformity from defect in degradation of dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate.

eponym.name: Smith-Lemli-Opitz syndrome
eponym.desc: Autosomal recessive disorder in cholesterol synthesis caused by mutation in the sterol delta-7-reductase gene; characterized by constellation of congenital anomalies: microcephaly, mental retardation, hypotonia, incomplete development of the male genitalia, short nose with anteverted nostrils, failure of masculinization; also known as RSH syndrome after initials of surnames of three families with syndrome.

eponym.name: Smith-Magenis syndrome
eponym.desc: Brachycephaly, growth retardation; associated with hair and nail pulling, reversed sleep pattern, and polyembolokoilamania (insertion of foreign bodies into body orifices); associated with deletion in 17p11.2 (or RAI1 gene). Compare with Potocki-Lupski syndrome, which is associated with duplication of 17p11.2.

eponym.name: Smith's fracture
eponym.desc: Opposite of Colle's fracture; fracture of the distal radius, but from falling on the dorsum of the hand.

eponym.name: Sneddon's syndrome
eponym.desc: Triad of livedo reticularis, stroke-like episodes, and hypertension; associated with antiphospholipid antibodies.

eponym.name: Sneddon-Wilkinson disease
eponym.desc: Subcorneal pustular dermatosis; rare, chronic , recurrent pustular eruption characterized by subcorneal pustules that contain abundant neutrophils.

eponym.name: Somogyi phenomenon
eponym.desc: Rebound hyperglycemia following an episode of hypoglycemia due to counterregulatory hormone release.

eponym.name: Soret band
eponym.desc: Strong absorption band in blue region for hemoglobin.

eponym.name: Sotos syndrome
eponym.desc: Cerebral gigantism with excessive growth in first 2-3 years of life, mild mental retardation, and delayed development; associated with mutation in NSD1; shares features with Weaver syndrome.

eponym.name: Spanish flu
eponym.desc: 1918 influenza with 20-100 million deaths worldwide with 2.5% mortality (influenza normally 0.1% mortality); influenza A H1N1 subtype.

eponym.name: Spigelian hernia
eponym.desc: Hernia through the linea semilunaris, also known as spontaneous lateral ventral hernia.

eponym.name: Sprengel scapula
eponym.desc: Congenital elevation of the scapula.

eponym.name: Spurling's test
eponym.desc: For diagnosing cervical radiculopathy, exerting downward pressure on the head while rotating the head towards the symptomatic side creating pain radiating into affected extremity.

eponym.name: St. Anthony's fire
eponym.desc: Erysipelas; also refers to ergotism.

eponym.name: St. Anthony's fire
eponym.desc: Chronic ergotism. Classically an epidemic in the Middle Ages caused by consumption of rye contaminated by the ergot fungus, leading to chronic ergotism characterized by intense burning pain and gangrene of feet, hands, and whole limbs due to vasconstrictive properties of ergot. Acute ergotism characterized by manic episodes and hallucinations due to serotonin antagonism of ergot related to LSD. St. Anthony's fire may also refers to erysipelas.

eponym.name: St. Jude valve
eponym.desc: Prosthetic valve, bileaflet, with two semicircular discs that pivot between open and closed positions without supporting struts, first used in 1977.

eponym.name: St. Vitus's dance
eponym.desc: See Sydenham's chorea.

eponym.name: Starr-Edwards valve
eponym.desc: Ball and cage heart valve, oldest prosthetic valve in continuous use, first used in 1965.

eponym.name: Stauffer's syndrome
eponym.desc: Elevation of liver function tests due to cholestasis in renal cell carcinoma.

eponym.name: Steele-Richardson-Olszewski syndrome
eponym.desc: Also known as progressive supranuclear palsy.

eponym.name: Steinert's disease
eponym.desc: Myotonic muscular dystrophy, i.e. myotonic dystrophy type 1.

eponym.name: Stein-Leventhal syndrome
eponym.desc: Polycystic ovarian disease.

eponym.name: Stellwag's sign
eponym.desc: Incomplete and infrequent blinking in Graves's disease.

eponym.name: Stensen's duct
eponym.desc: Parotid duct, enters oral cavity opposite crown of second maxillary molar tooth.

eponym.name: Stevens-Johnson syndrome
eponym.desc: Extensive and symptomatic febrile form of erythema multiforme, more common in children; 1-6 cases/million person-years.

eponym.name: Stewart's granuloma
eponym.desc: Generally extranodal NK/T-cell lymphoma, tend to be positive for EBV. Leads to gradual ulceration of nose and mid-face cartilage and bone. Also known as "lethal midline granuloma."

eponym.name: Stewart-Treves syndrome
eponym.desc: Angiosarcoma arising out of chronic lymphedema; e.g. following mastectomy. Described in 1948.

eponym.name: Stickler syndrome
eponym.desc: Mild spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia, osteoarthritis, and sensorineural hearing loss, some forms associated with a autosomal dominant negative mutation in the human COL11A2 gene encoding the alpha 2(XI) chain; another form of Stickler syndrome from mutation in COL2A1.

eponym.name: stiff-man syndrome
eponym.desc: Chronic disorder of involuntary stiffness, painful muscle spasms, and rigidity, predominantly in the axial muscles; often occurs in conjunction with autoimmune diseases, e.g. type I diabetes, associated with circulating antibodies to glutamic acid decarboxylase.

eponym.name: Still's disease, adult onset
eponym.desc: Polyarthritis associated with sudden onset of high spiking fever, sore throat, and an evanescent erythematous salmon-colored rash.

eponym.name: Still's murmur
eponym.desc: Described by George Still in 1909; normal vibratory midsystolic murmur; an innocent type of murmur.

eponym.name: Stockholm syndrome
eponym.desc: Victims sympathizing with victimizer, e.g., kidnapper; described after incident in summer of 1973 in Stockholm where hostages were taken in a failed bank robbery and after end of their captivity in six days, the hostages resisted rescue.

eponym.name: Stokes collar
eponym.desc: In superior vena caval obstruction, enlargement of neck with non-pitting edema.

eponym.name: Stokes-Adams attacks
eponym.desc: Syncope associated with complete heart block (or other types of bradycardia).

eponym.name: Stoppa repair
eponym.desc: Hernia repair using tension-free intraparietal prosthetic mesh.

eponym.name: Stransky's sign
eponym.desc: An upper motor neuron sign where there is involuntary dorsiflexion of the toes after firmly abducting the 5th digit for 2 seconds, and then acutely letting it go.

eponym.name: Stroop test
eponym.desc: A psychological stress test, also used for checking frontal function, where patients are tested for the ability to read off the color of text where the text spells a different color.

eponym.name: Strümpell's sign
eponym.desc: An upper motor neuron sign where there is involuntary pronation of the forearm/wrist with passive extension and flexion of the arm at the elbow.

eponym.name: Stuart factor
eponym.desc: Factor X; also known as Stuart-Prower factor. Named after patients Audrey Prower and Rufus Stuart.

eponym.name: Stuart-Prower factor
eponym.desc: See Stuart factor.

eponym.name: Sturge-Weber syndrome
eponym.desc: Association of port-wine stain with vascular malformations in the eye (glaucoma) and leptomeninges and superficial calcifications of the brain; attributed to faulty development of certain mesodermal and ectodermal elements, and associated with mental retardation, seizures, hemiplegia, and radiopacities in the skull.

eponym.name: Sudeck's point
eponym.desc: Watershed region between sigmoid and superior rectal artery in ileocecal region; see also Griffth's point.

eponym.name: Sudeck's syndrome
eponym.desc: Reflex sympathetic dystrophy syndrome occurring in older people characterized by cystic changes and subchondral erosion in bone, diffuse osteoporosis, and muscle atrophy, but not necessarily associated with trauma.

eponym.name: Sugiura procedure
eponym.desc: For treating esophageal varices, esophageal and gastric devascularization, esophageal transection.

eponym.name: Susac syndrome
eponym.desc: Microangiopathy of the inner ear, retina, and brain leading to deafness, retinal artery occlusion, and encephalopathy.

eponym.name: Sutton's disease
eponym.desc: Major aphthous stomatitis; recurrent aphthous stomatitis with large deep ulcers >1 cm, may leave scarring; unknown etiology.

eponym.name: Swedish porphyria
