eponym.desc: Acute intermittent porphyria.

eponym.name: Sweet's syndrome
eponym.desc: Acute febrile neutrophilic dermatosis or Sweet syndrome, initially described in 1964 by Robert Sweet. It is characterized by fever, neutrophilic leucocytosis, abrupt appearance of erythematous, painful, cutaneous plaques, and dense dermal infiltrate consisting of mature neutrophils without vasculitis signs.

eponym.name: Swyer-James syndrome
eponym.desc: In pediatrics, acquired hypoplastic lung that develops after severe obliterative bronchiolitis associated with bronchiolar obstruction, bronchiectasis, and distal air-space destruction.

eponym.name: Swyer's syndrome
eponym.desc: XY gonadal dysgenesis.

eponym.name: Sydenham's chorea
eponym.desc: Postinfectious chorea appearing several months after a streptococcal infection with subsequent rheumatic fever. Chorea typically involves the distal limbs and is associated with hypotonia and emotional lability; improvement occurs over weeks or months and exacerbations occur without associated infection occurrence; also known as St. Vitus's dance.

eponym.name: Sylvian aqueduct
eponym.desc: Cerebral aqueduct of the midbrain that connects the third and fourth ventricle.

eponym.name: Syme's amputation
eponym.desc: Amputation at the ankle with removal of the malleoli and placement of the heel pad over the end of the remaining tibia; devised in 1842.

eponym.name: Takayasu's disease
eponym.desc: Aortic arch syndrome, pulseless disease; panartertis of the great vessels that is most common in Asian women. Described in 1908 by Takayasu, an ophthalmologist.

eponym.name: takotsubo syndrome
eponym.desc: Apical ballooning syndrome, characterized by acute onset of chest pain, EKG changes, cardiac marker release and transient extensive akinesia of the apical portions of left ventricle without significant coronary stenosis.

eponym.name: Tamm-Horsfall protein
eponym.desc: Uromodulin, major component of renal casts; 30-50 mg secreted per day by cells in thick ascending limb; homologous to GP2, a protein secreted from the acinar cell and a major component of plugs in noncalcific chronic pancreatitis.

eponym.name: Tangier disease
eponym.desc: Rare recessive disease characterized by enlarged orange tonsils, peripheral neuropathy affecting small fibers involved in pain and temperature, and a near-complete absence of HDL-cholesterol. ABC1, the ATP binding-cassette transporter 1 gene, mutated in Tangier disease; gene mediates efflux of cholesterol from cells. Named after small island in Chesapeake Bay where disease first identified in five-year-old boy.

eponym.name: Tanner stages
eponym.desc: Stages of sexual development in puberty; described by James Tanner.

eponym.name: Tarlov cyst
eponym.desc: Perineural cyst found in the lower spinal cord.

eponym.name: Tarui disease
eponym.desc: Glycogen storage disease type VII, deficiency of muscle phophofructokinase, presents as early onset of fatigue and pain with exercise, resulting in myoglobinuria.

eponym.name: Tay-Sachs disease
eponym.desc: Autosomal recessive sphingolipidosis; GM2 gangliosidosis, results from mutations that affect alpha subunit of hexosaminidase A gene and cause a severe deficiency in hexosaminidase A; blindness and cherry-red spot (see also Sandhoff's disease with similar symptoms; involves beta subunit of both hexosaminidase A and B); previously called "amaurotic idiocy." Fatal in early childhood.

eponym.name: Terry's nails
eponym.desc: Mostly whitish nails with a distal band of reddish brown; may be seen with aging and in people with chronic diseases such as cirrhosis of the liver, congestive heart failure, renal disease, and diabetes; seen in 10% of patients with uremia.

eponym.name: Terson's syndrome
eponym.desc: Intra-vitreous hemorrhage associated with subarachnoid hemorrhage.

eponym.name: Texidor's twinge
eponym.desc: Sudden and sharp chest pain in pediatric settings, from precordial catch or sudden restrictrion in pleural movement. Described by Miller and Texidor in 1955.

eponym.name: third disease
eponym.desc: German measles, aka rubella or rötheln, caused by rubivirus, described in 1881.

eponym.name: Thompson's test
eponym.desc: Verifies if gastroc-soleus complex intact: squeeze calf belly, foot should plantar flex; see also Simmond's test.

eponym.name: Thomsen-Friedenreich antigen
eponym.desc: Cryptic antigen in membranes of erythrocytes, platelets, and glomerular capillary endothelial cells exposed by S. pneumoniae-derived neuraminidase removal of sialic acid.

eponym.name: Thomsen's disease
eponym.desc: Myotonia congenita. Autosomal dominant. From mutation in skeletal muscle chloride channel 1 (CLCN1). Characterized by muscle stiffness and inability to relax after muscle contraction.

eponym.name: Thorel's pathway
eponym.desc: Posterior internodal tract in atrial conduction system.

eponym.name: Throckmorton sign
eponym.desc: Positive sign when penis points towards lesion seen radiographically; see also John Thomas sign.

eponym.name: thumb sign
eponym.desc: In Marfan's disease, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, and similar syndromes, thumb protrudes from clenched fist.

eponym.name: Tietze syndrome
eponym.desc: Benign inflammation and swelling of costochondral and costosternal joints which are painful on palpation; may be perceived as breast pain.

eponym.name: Tillaux fracture
eponym.desc: Fracture seen in older adolescents in which the anterolateral portion of the distal tibial epiphyseal plate is avulsed from the medial portion of the plate by the anterior tibiofibular ligament.

eponym.name: Tinel's sign
eponym.desc: A sensation of tingling or pins and needles felt in distal extremity when percussion is made over the site of an injured nerve, as in carpal tunnel syndrome; it indicates a partial lesion or early regeneration of the nerve; 60% sensitive, 67% specific.

eponym.name: Todd's paralysis
eponym.desc: Transient hemiparesis in postictal period, resolves over a period of 0.5-36 hours, suggests focal brain lesion as cause.

eponym.name: Toldt, white lines of
eponym.desc: The peritoneal reflections of the ascending and descending colon.

eponym.name: Tolosa-Hunt syndrome
eponym.desc: Idiopathic inflammation of the cavernous sinus producing painful palsy of third, fourth, or sixth cranial nerve.

eponym.name: Tornwaldt's bursa
eponym.desc: Pharyngeal bursa, located above the pharyngeal tonsil in the midline of the posterior wall of the nasopharynx; remnant of embryonic communication between the anterior tip of the notochord and the roof of the pharynx.

eponym.name: Tourette's syndrome
eponym.desc: Chronic multiple motor and verbal tics, symptoms typically begin before 21 y.o., first signs motor tics in 80% and vocal tics in 20% but eventually both motor and vocal; higher than expected number of left-handedness and ambidexterity; 40-50% involve self-mutilation such as nail-biting, hair-pulling, etc.

eponym.name: Towne's view
eponym.desc: AP view with the X ray tube angled caudad to show the occipital bone.

eponym.name: TRALI syndrome
eponym.desc: Transfusion Related Acute Lung Injury; transfusion reaction occurring within 6 hours after transfusion of blood product, characterized by pulmonary edema; due to anti-granulocyte antibodies in donor's plasma causing pulmonary sequestration of recipient leukocytes in susceptible patient.

eponym.name: Traube's sign
eponym.desc: In aortic regurgitation "pistol shot sounds" referring to booming systolic and diastolic sounds over the femoral artery.

eponym.name: Traube's space
eponym.desc: A crescentic space about 12 cm wide, bounded medially by the left sternal border, above by an oblique line from 6th costal cartilage to the lower border of the 8th or 9th rib in the mid-axillary line, and below by costal margin. Usually tympanitic because of stomach but can be affected by emphysema, pleural effusion, or splenomegaly.

eponym.name: Treacher Collins syndrome
eponym.desc: First arch syndrome, mandibulofacial dysplasia, resulting in malar hypoplasia with down-slanting palpebral fissures, defects in the lower eyelids, deformed external ears, and sometimes abnormalities of the middle and internal ears. Autosomal dominant, due to mutation in trecle gene, TCOF1. Described by Edward Treacher Collins, an English surgeon and ophthalmologist (1862-1932).

eponym.name: Treitz, ligament of
eponym.desc: Suspensory muscle of the duodenum which supports the duodenojejunal flexure. Separates upper from lower gastrointestinal bleeding.

eponym.name: Trendelenburg position
eponym.desc: Position where angle of the head of bed or table is inclined at 45 degrees down; used in surgery to push the abdominal organs towards the chest.

eponym.name: Trendelenburg's gait
eponym.desc: Waddling gait in people with weakness or paresis of gluteal muscles; seen in progressive muscular dystrophy.

eponym.name: Trendelenburg's sign
eponym.desc: Sign of weakness of gluteus medius muscle seen when standing on one leg, failure to elevate contralateral side of pelvis. May be due to congenital dislocation of hip, trochanteric fracture, polio, or spinal nerve root lesions with muscule atrophy.

eponym.name: Trevor's disease
eponym.desc: Also known as dysplasia epiphysealis hemimelica, asymmetric limb deformity due to cartilaginous overgrowth of a tarsal or carpal bone, less often other bones.

eponym.name: Troisier's node
eponym.desc: French eponym for Virchow's node.

eponym.name: Trotter's syndrome
eponym.desc: Triad of unilateral deafness due to eustachian tube involvement, neuralgia affecting branches of the trigeminal nerve, and defective mobility of the soft palate due to nasopharyngeal cancer.

eponym.name: Trousseau's sign
eponym.desc: In hypocalcemia and latent tetany, carpal spasm induced by occluding the brachial artery for 3 min with an inflated BP cuff.

eponym.name: Trousseau's spot
eponym.desc: Also known as tache cerebrale, the red streak seen on scratching the skin in acute meningitis.

eponym.name: Trousseau's syndrome
eponym.desc: Migratory thrombophlebitis seen in setting of malignancy, e.g. pancreas or lung.

eponym.name: Trummerfeld zone
eponym.desc: In scurvy, a lucent line below a dense zone of provisional calification at the margins of the growth plate (i.e. Fränkel's sign).

eponym.name: Tullio's phenomenon
eponym.desc: Induction of vertigo by loud noises, i.e. sound-induced vestibular activation. Associated with and previously considered pathognomonic of syphilis.

eponym.name: Turcot's syndrome
eponym.desc: Rare variant of familial adenomatous polyposis, with combination of adenomatous colonic polyposis and tumors of the central nervous system, mostly glioblastoma multiforme.

eponym.name: Turner's syndrome
eponym.desc: Females with XO, short, low-set ears, shield chest, congenital heart defect (usually coarctation), café-au-lait spots, freckles, webbed neck, lymphedema.

eponym.name: Tzanck smear
eponym.desc: Cytologic technique most often used in the diagnosis of herpesvirus infections (simplex or varicella-zoster); multinucleated giant cells suggest the presence of herpes; named after Arnault Tzanck.

eponym.name: Uhl's anomaly
eponym.desc: Paper-thin parietal myocardium, usually but not always limited to right ventricle, presents as heart failure in infancy or early childhood.

eponym.name: Uhthoff's phenomenon
eponym.desc: In multiple sclerosis, sensitivity of symptoms to changes in body temperature or exercise (e.g., visual loss with exercise); initial description in 1890 of amblyopia following exercise.

eponym.name: unhappy triad
eponym.desc: Lateral knee injury resulting in anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) tear, medial collateral ligament (MCL) tear, and medial meniscal injury.

eponym.name: Unna boot
eponym.desc: Compression dressing impregnated with medication for treating venous stasis ulcers; named after Paul Gerson Unna, German dermatologist 1850-1929.

eponym.name: Unterberger's stepping test
eponym.desc: For assessing vestibular function, having patient step in one spot with the eye closed: in peripheral lesions, body rotates to side of lesion whereas in central disorders, deviation is irregular.

eponym.name: Unverricht-Lundborg disease
eponym.desc: Progressive myoclonus epilepsy (EPM1), onset at age 6-15, stimulus-sensitive myoclonus, tonic-clonic seizures, marked sensitivity to photic stimulation, leads to cerebellar ataxia and mental deterioration; from unstable expansion of a dodecamer minisatellite repeat unit in the promoter region of cystatin B, a widely expressed cysteine protease inhibitor; more common in Finland and western Mediterranean; also known as Baltic myoclonus.

eponym.name: Upshaw-Schulman syndrome
eponym.desc: Congenital thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP); caused by an inherited deficiency in von Willebrand factor cleaving metalloprotease (ADAMTS13), characterized by the constellation of findings seen in TTP, namely microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, neurologic symptoms, renal dysfunction, and fever.

eponym.name: Urbach-Wiethe disease
eponym.desc: Lipoid proteinosis with cutaneous and mucosal infiltrations of eyelids, tongue, larynx; associated with early hoarseness with an unusual skin eruption. Autosomal recessive, associated with mutation in ECM1 gene.

eponym.name: Usher's syndrome
eponym.desc: Type I, profound bilateral sensorineural congenital deafness with onset of loss of vision due to retinitis pigmentosa by age 10 (type 1B due to mutation in myosin-VIIa); type 2, moderate to severe congenital deafness with onset of retinitis pigmentosa by age 10; type III, retinitis pigmentosa first noted at puberty with progressive hearing loss; type IV, possible X-linked form.

eponym.name: Utley's maneuver
eponym.desc: For controlling bleeding from a tracheo-innominate fistula, digital pressure through the stoma on the back of the sternum to controls the fistula.

eponym.name: VACTERL association
eponym.desc: Vertebral, anal, cardiovascular, tracheoesophageal, renal, and limb defects.

eponym.name: Valentino's syndrome
eponym.desc: Duodenal ulcer with retroperitoneal perforation presenting with pain in the right lower quadrant.

eponym.name: Valsalva maneuver
eponym.desc: First described in 1704 as a method for expelling pus from the middle ear: deep inspiration followed by forced exhalation against a closed glottis for 10-12 seconds; four phases, phase 1 transient rise in BP with straining; phase 2 decrease in systemic venous return, blood pressure, and reflex tachycardia; phase 3 begins with cessation of straining, associated with abrupt transient decrease in blood pressure and in systemic venous return (generally not perceivable); phase 4 an overshoot of systemic arterial pressure and relatively obvious reflex bradcycardia. Described by Valsalva, a 17th century physician.

eponym.name: Van den Bergh reaction
eponym.desc: Used to distinguish between unconjugated and conjugated bilirubin; bilirubin pigments are exposed to sulfanilic acid to generate diazo conjugates, forming chromogenic products.

eponym.name: Van der Hoeve syndrome
eponym.desc: Osteogenesis imperfecta.

eponym.name: Van der Woude syndrome
eponym.desc: An autosomal dominant condition in which lip pits are seen in all gene carriers but only some individuals have cleft lips with or without cleft palate owing to variable expressivity.

eponym.name: Van Wyk-Grumbach syndrome
eponym.desc: Primary hypothyroidism associated with precocious puberty and galactorrhea.

eponym.name: Vanek tumor
eponym.desc: Benign inflammatory fibroid polyp seen in gastrointestinal tract.

eponym.name: Van't Hoff's law
eponym.desc: Osmotic pressure of a solute equals the gas pressure it would exert if it were a gas in the same volume of solution. Dutch chemist (1852-1911), received Nobel Prize for this finding in 1901.

eponym.name: Vater, ampulla
eponym.desc: Location where common bile duct enters the duodenum; described by German anatomist Vater (1684-1751).

eponym.name: Vaughn-Jackson lesion
eponym.desc: Seen in rheumatoid arthritis, rupture of tendons in distal ulnar head, associated with loss of extension in the little and ring, finger; associated with caput ulna syndrome.

eponym.name: Verner-Morrison syndrome
eponym.desc: Secretory diarrhea associated with VIPoma; characterized by watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, achlorhydria.

eponym.name: Vespignani sign
eponym.desc: Edema of the ureteral vesical junction in renal colic.

eponym.name: Vietnamese time bomb
eponym.desc: Burkholderia pseudomallei, causative agent of melioidosis, described as "time bomb" because of its occurrence in war veterans more than two decades after their return from Vietnam.

eponym.name: Villaret's syndrome
eponym.desc: Involvement of four lower cranial nerves (IX-XII) clinical manifestations manifesting as Horner's syndrome and paralysis of the soft palate, pharynx, and vocal cords; associated with tumor in posterior retroparotid space.

eponym.name: Vincent's infection
eponym.desc: Acute necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis or "trench mouth" from concurrent infection with the symbiotic bacteria Fusobacterium fusiforme and Borrelia vincentii. Rare in post-antibiotic era.

eponym.name: Virchow-Robin spaces
eponym.desc: Perivascular spaces in brain; become unusually widened in edema of the brain.

eponym.name: Virchow's node
eponym.desc: Supraclavicular adenopathy associated with a malignancy, often on left side, associated with GI (e.g. stomach) and pelvic malignancies. First described by Virchow in 1848, more cases added by Troisier in 1886; referred to as Troisier's node in France.

eponym.name: Virchow's triad
eponym.desc: Predisposing factors in thrombus formation (1) endothelial injury, (2) hypercoagulability, and (3) stasis or turbulence of blood flow; first described in 1860.

eponym.name: Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada syndrome
eponym.desc: Bilateral, diffuse granulomatous uveitis associated with poliosis (premature graying of some or all of the hair), vitiligo, alopecia, and central nervous system and auditory signs (including dysacusia).

eponym.name: Vogt's triad
eponym.desc: In tuberous sclerosis, triad of seizures, mental retardation, and facial angiofibromas. Occurs in fewer than 50% of patients with tuberous sclerosis.

eponym.name: Voight, lines of
eponym.desc: Boundaries which delimit distribution area of main cutaneous nerves; seen in black and Asian skin and rarely in white subjects.

eponym.name: Volkmann contracture
eponym.desc: Sequelae of compartment syndrome where there is contraction of forearm flexors.

eponym.name: von Braun-Fernwald's sign
eponym.desc: See Piskacek's sign.

eponym.name: Von Economo's encephalitis
eponym.desc: Encephalitis lethargica, associated with postencephalitic parkinsonism, first described in 1917; also associated with influenza A epidemic of 1918. Response to levodopa subject of book and movie Awakenings.

eponym.name: von Frey hairs
eponym.desc: Hairs originally derived from horses tails and graded according to their stiffness and caliber, used as a method of grading sensation in the neurologic examination.

eponym.name: Von Gierke's disease
eponym.desc: Glycogen storage disease type I, deficiency in glucose-6-phosphatase, results in hepatomegaly and hypoglycemia. Most common glycogen storage disease. Autosomal recessive. Treated with frequent feedings of foods high in glucose or starch.

eponym.name: Von Graefe sign
eponym.desc: In Graves's disease, lag of the upper eyelid as it follows the rotation of the eyeball downward.

eponym.name: Von Hippel-Lindau disease
eponym.desc: Autosomal dominant condition characterized by hemangioblastoma or cavernous hemangioma of the cerebellum, brain stem, or retina, adenomas, and cysts of the liver, kidney, pancreas, and other organs, pheochromocytomas; 35% develop renal cell carcinoma; associated with mutation in VHL gene.

eponym.name: Von Myenburg complexes
eponym.desc: Close to or within portal tracts, small clusters of modestly dilated bile ducts embedded in a fibrous, sometimes hyalinized stroma; contain inspissated bile concrements and may communicate with the biliary tree; common and usually without clinical significance.

eponym.name: Von Recklinghausen's disease
eponym.desc: Neurofibromatosis type 1.

eponym.name: Von Recklinghausen's disease of bone
eponym.desc: Generalized osteitis fibrosa cystica; hallmark of severe hyperparathyroidism, including increased bone cell activity, peritrabecular fibrosis, and cystic brown tumors.

eponym.name: Von Willebrand factor
eponym.desc: Von Willebrand factor bridges collagen and platelets and favors platelet aggregation, ensuring platelet and vessel wall interactions. Glycoprotein Ib-IX on platelets is a major receptor for vWF. vWF also serves as carrier for factor VIII. Made in endothelial cells and megakaryocytes.

eponym.name: Von Willebrand's disease
eponym.desc: Deficiency in von Willebrand factor; frequency of 1%, most common inherited disorder of bleeding; type 1 and 3 reduced quantity of vWF; type 2 qualitative defects in vWF.

eponym.name: Von Zumbusch psoriasis
eponym.desc: Generalized acute pustular psoriasis.

eponym.name: Waardenburg's syndrome
eponym.desc: TYPE I, hearing loss; dystopia canthorum, high nasal root, heterochromia irides, white forelock, early graying; from mutation in PAX3 gene, transcription factor involved in neural crest development; TYPE II, same as type I except for absence of dystopia; associated with mutation in MITF; TYPE III (Klein-Waardenburg), camptodactyly and other upper limb defects in addition to type I; TYPE IV (Shah-Waardenburg), deafness, pigmentary defects, and aganglionic megacolon.

eponym.name: Wada test
eponym.desc: A test for hemispheric dominance for language by injecting amobarbital into carotid artery, one hemisphere at a time; the barbiturate shuts down that hemisphere. Initially described by Wada in 1949.

eponym.name: Waddell's signs
eponym.desc: In low back pain, responses that predict worse outcome or non-organic component to pain, including tenderness unrelated to anatomic structures, inconsistent performance of seated versus supine straight leg raise, pain on axial loading, and neurological deficits without physiologic explanation.

eponym.name: Waddell's triad
eponym.desc: Triad of injury seen in children struck by motor vehicles: fractured femoral shaft; thoracic or abdominal injuries; contralateral head injury.

eponym.name: WAGR
eponym.desc: Wilms's tumor, Anirida, Genital anomalies, and mental Retardation; 33% chance of developing Wilms's tumor; associated with mutation in WT1 gene.

eponym.name: Waldenström's macroglobulinemia
eponym.desc: A subset of lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma (a malignancy involving small B lymphocytes, plasmactyoid lymphocytes, and plasma cells) with bone marrow involvement and IgM monoclonal gammopathy in the blood. Characterized by macroglobulinemia and associated with visual impairment, neurologic problems, bleeding, cryoglobulinemia, and hyperviscosity.

eponym.name: Waldeyer's throat ring
eponym.desc: The broken ring of lymphoid tissue, formed of the lingual, facial, and pharyngeal tonsils, commonly involved in non-Hodgkin's lymphoma and rarely in Hodgkin's disease.

eponym.name: Walker-Warburg syndrome
eponym.desc: Congenital condition characterized by hydrocephalus, agyria, retinal dysplasia, with or without encephalocele; autosomal recessive from mutation in O-mannosyltransferase-1 POMT1 and -2 POMT2; usually lethal within first few months.

eponym.name: Wallenberg syndrome
eponym.desc: Lateral medullary syndrome from infarction in posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) which supplies the lateral medulla. This affects: (1) nucleus ambiguus, leading to difficulty in swallowing and hoarseness, loss of gag reflex; (2) vestibular nucleus, leading to dizziness and nystagmus; (3) trigeminal nucleus, leading to loss of pain and temperature on ipsilateral side; (4) inferior cerebellar peduncle, leading to ipsilateral limb ataxia; (5) anterolateral system, leading to reduced pain and temperature on contralateral limb; (6) ipsilateral Horner's syndrome; and (7) hiccup. For reasons not known solitary nucleus may also be destroyed, leading to loss of taste on ipsilateral half of tongue.

eponym.name: Wallerian degeneration
eponym.desc: Pattern of degeneration of distal portion of nerve following axonal injury with break down of axon and formation of myelin ovoids from catabolized axon fragments.

eponym.name: Warburg effect
eponym.desc: In malignant transformation, increased anaerobic glycolysis leads to increased lactic acid production; described by Otto Warburg in 1930.

eponym.name: Warren shunt
eponym.desc: For treating portal hypertension, distal splenorenal shunt.

eponym.name: Wartenberg migratory sensory neuritis
eponym.desc: Benign relapsing and remitting condition with pain and loss of sensation in distribution of individual cutaneous nerves; induced by stretch; intact deep-tendon reflexes.

eponym.name: Warthin-Finkeldey cells
eponym.desc: On measles pneumonia, cells with multiple nuclei and eosinophilic intranuclear inclusions.

eponym.name: Warthin's tumor
eponym.desc: Papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum, parotid gland involved, benign, more in males than females, 50s-70s.

eponym.name: Warthin-Starry stain
eponym.desc: A silver stain, will stain H. pylori, Bartonella henselae.

eponym.name: Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome
eponym.desc: Massive bilateral adrenal hemorrhage seen with with N. meningitidis or gonococci, pneumococci, or Staph. septicemia, characterized by hypotension, DIC with widespread purpura, and adrenocortical insufficiency.

eponym.name: Waterston-Cooley shunt
eponym.desc: For treating tetralogy of Fallot, anastomosis of direct ascending aorta to right pulmonary artery; rarely performed currently.

eponym.name: Watson's water hammer pulse
eponym.desc: Also known as Corrigan's pulse; seen in aortic regurgitation.

eponym.name: Watson-Schwartz reaction
eponym.desc: Screening test for porphobilinogen (elevated for example in acute intermittent porphyria); mixing 4-dimethylaminobenzaldehyde with urine and then extract with chloroform; porphobilinogen extracts into upper aqueous layer giving it a pink color and urobilinogen extracts into chloroform layer; 50% positive at urinary concentration 5x upper limit of normal and consistently positive 10-20x upper limit of normal; see also Hoesch test.

eponym.name: Weaver syndrome
eponym.desc: Congenital disorder associated with rapid growth beginning in the prenatal period, unusual craniofacial appearance, hoarse and low-pitched cry, and hypertonia with camptodactyly. Occasionally has mutations in NSD1 (which is same mutation in Sotos syndrome).

eponym.name: Weber fracture
eponym.desc: Used to determine the severity of tibiofibular ligament injury by the level of fibular fracture; Weber A, fibular fractures distal to the level of the tibiotalar joint; Weber B, fracture of the fibula near the joint and a transverse fracture of the medial malleolus (or disruption of the deltoid ligament); Weber C consists of a proximal fracture of the fibula and a transverse fracture of the medial malleolus (or an intact malleolus and a ruptured deltoid ligament).

eponym.name: Weber syndrome
eponym.desc: Medial midbrain syndrome with ipsilateral third nerve palsy combined with contralateral hemiplegia due to peduncular lesion.

eponym.name: Weber test
eponym.desc: 512 Hz tuning fork placed on patients's forehead; sound localizes towards side with conductive hearing loss; localizes away from the side with sensorineural loss.

eponym.name: Weber-Christian disease
eponym.desc: Relapsing febrile nodular nonsuppurative nonvasculitic panniculitis (an inflammatory reaction in the subcutaneous fat). Usually occurs in young white females; characterized by tender skin nodules and constitutional symptoms (fever, arthralgias, myalgias).

eponym.name: Wegener's granulomatosis
eponym.desc: Systemic vasculitis of medium and small arteries, as well as venules and arterioles defined by a clinical triad of involvement of the upper airways, lungs, and kidneys and by a pathological triad consisting of necrotizing granuloma in the upper respiratory tract and lungs, vasculitis involving both arteries and veins, and focal glomerulonephritis. Described by Wegener in 1936, who was associated with Nazi party.

eponym.name: Weibel-Palade bodies
eponym.desc: Granules contain von Willebrand's factor and P-selectin, found in endothelial cells of vessels larger than capillaries.

eponym.name: Weigert stain
eponym.desc: Iron hematoxylin, preceded by a dichromate mordant, stains myelin.

eponym.name: Weil-Felix reaction
eponym.desc: Proteus cell wall O antigens, such as OX-2, OX-19, and OX-K, cross-reacting with antigens of several species of rickettsiae.

eponym.name: Weill-Marchesani syndrome
eponym.desc: Rare, autosomal recessive syndrome of ectopia lentis, short stature, brachydactyly, and glaucoma. Associated with mutation in ADAMTS10 gene.

eponym.name: Weil's disease
eponym.desc: Severe form of leptospirosis with hepatic dysfunction, renal dysfunction, and hemorrhage.

eponym.name: Welander distal myopathy
eponym.desc: Distal myopathy seen in Sweden and Finland.

eponym.name: Wellens's sign
eponym.desc: In critical stenosis high in left anterior descending coronary artery, a pattern of ST-T segment in V2 and V3: isoelectric or minimally elevated (1 mm) takeoff of the ST segment, a concave or straight ST segment passing into a negative T wave at an angle of 60 to 90 degrees, and a symmetrically inverted T wave (Am Heart J 103:730, 1982).

eponym.name: Wells's syndrome
eponym.desc: Eosinophilic cellulitis, characterized by recurrent cutaneous swellings which resemble acute bacterial cellulitis, and by distinctive histopathological changes. Skin lesions show dermal eosinophilic infiltration and the characteristic "flame figures" are composed of eosinophil major protein deposited on collagen bundles. Described by Wells in 1971.

eponym.name: Wenckebach block
eponym.desc: Second-degree AV block, Mobitz type I.

eponym.name: Wenckebach's bundle
eponym.desc: Middle internodal tract in atrial conduction system.

eponym.name: Werdnig-Hoffmann syndrome
eponym.desc: Spinal muscular atrophy type I, autosomal recessive lower motor neuron disease, survival motor neuron protein affected, due to mutation in SMN1, presents between birth and 6 months of age, death before 2 y.o. Characterized by degeneration of spinal cord anterior horn cells, resulting in muscle atrophy and weakness. Of note, spinal muscular atrophysecond most common lethal, autosomal recessive disease in Caucasians after cystic fibrosis.

eponym.name: Werlhof's disease
eponym.desc: Immune thrombocytopenic purpura; described by Werlhof in 1735.

eponym.name: Wermer's syndrome
eponym.desc: Multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) type I: hyperplasias or tumors of the thyroid, parathyroid, adrenal cortex, pancreatic islets, or pituitary.

eponym.name: Werner's syndrome
eponym.desc: A form of progeria characterized by scleroderma-like skin changes (especially in extremities), bilateral juvenile cataracts, subcutaneous calcifications, wizened and prematurely-aged facies, hypogonadism, and diabetes mellitus; autosomal recessive inheritance; from mutation in WRN helicase locus.

eponym.name: Wernicke's area
eponym.desc: Important cortical center for recognizing speech, found in the superior temporal gyrus; communicates with Broca's area with arcuate fasciulus.

eponym.name: Wernicke's encephalopathy
eponym.desc: Chronic thiamine deficiency (seen in alcoholics since alcohol impairs thiamine absorption) resulting in ataxia, global confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and often nystagmus. May lead to a particular focal necrotizing encephalopathy affecting the hypothalamus, medial thalamus, and oculomotor nuclear groups in the periventricular brainstem. Can be precipitated by administration of glucose to patient depleted of thiamine. After treatment with thiamine, a minority of patients have profound memory deficit (Korsakoff's syndrome).

eponym.name: Westermark's sign
eponym.desc: In chest film, an abrupt tapering of a vessel caused by pulmonary embolism, focal oligemia.

eponym.name: West's syndrome
eponym.desc: Triad of infantile spasms, psychomotor developmental arrest, and characteristic EEG pattern of hypsarrhythmia (multifocal, chaotic, high-amplitude spike-and-slow wave pattern).

eponym.name: Wharton's duct
eponym.desc: Submandibular duct.

eponym.name: Whipple procedure
eponym.desc: Pancreaticoduodenectomy with cholecystectomy, truncal vagotomy, choledochojejunostomy, pancreaticojejunostomy, gastrojejunostomy.

eponym.name: Whipple's disease
eponym.desc: Systemic bacterial infection with Tropheryma whipplei characterized by fever (50%), weight loss (most common presenting symptom), diarrhea, lymphadenopathy, and polyarthritis (in 80%, first symptoms experienced) and, occasionally, by cardiac manifestations such as myocarditis, pericarditis, and endocarditis or by central nervous system involvement (10%); most commonly affects men in 40-60s. See small intestinal mucosa laden with distended macrophages in the lamina propria, PAS positive granules, with no inflammation; gram positive actinomycete Tropheryma whipplei.

eponym.name: Whipple's triad
eponym.desc: In insulinoma, (1) attacks precipitated by fasting or exertion; (2) fasting blood glucose <50 mg/dL; (3) symptoms relieved by glucose.

eponym.name: Whitaker's syndrome
eponym.desc: Autoimmune polyglandular syndrome type 1 (mucocutaneous candidiasis, hypoparathyroidism, autoimmune adrenal insufficiency).

eponym.name: Wickham's striae
eponym.desc: In lichen planus, papules are highlighted by a shiny surface with a lacy white pattern.

eponym.name: Widal test
eponym.desc: Typhoid agglutination test.

eponym.name: Wilkie's disease
eponym.desc: Partial obstruction of third part of duodenum by superior mesenteric artery resulting in abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, weight loss.

eponym.name: Will Rogers phenomenon
eponym.desc: Stage migration with improvements in diagnosis, causing apparent improvements in survival, i.e., stage I cases becoming stage II (N Engl J Med 1985;312:1604).

eponym.name: Williams-Campbell syndrome
eponym.desc: Congenital cartilage deficiency, associated with bronchiectasis.

eponym.name: Williams-Fitzgerald-Flaujeac factor
eponym.desc: High molecular weight kininogen; see description under Fitzgerald factor.

eponym.name: Williams's syndrome
eponym.desc: Neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by loquacious personality, abnormally sensitive hearing, supravalvular aortic stenosis, mental retardation, elfin facies, association with hypercalcemia due to abnormal sensitivity to vitamin D, idiopathic hypercalcemia of pregnancy. Due to deletion in elastin gene and probably several adjacent genes on 7q.

eponym.name: Willis, circle of
eponym.desc: Cerebral arterial circle, an anastomosis between the two vertebral and two internal carotid arteries.

eponym.name: Wilms's tumor
eponym.desc: Childhood primary renal tumor, 5% of patients with sporadic Wilms tumor have mutations in WT-1, cancer suppressor gene on 11p13.

eponym.name: Wilson's disease
eponym.desc: Hepatolenticular degeneration, autosomal recessive disorder involving gene in incorporation of copper into ceruloplasmin and excretion of copper into bile, leading to accumulation of copper in liver and brain. Incidence 1:200,000, diagnosis based on decrease in serum ceruloplasmin, increased urinary excretion of copper, increase in hepatic copper content; 40% have neurologic findings (Parkinson's, psychosis) and subclinical liver disease. Associated with Kayser-Fleischer rings.

eponym.name: Wimberger sign
eponym.desc: In congenital syphilis, bilateral, symmetric destruction in upper medial tibias metaphyses. May also be seen in bacterial osteomyelitis, hamartomosis, hyperparathyroidism.

eponym.name: Winslow, foramen of
eponym.desc: Omental foramen between abdominal cavity and omental bursa, bounded anteriorly by the portal triad; posteriorly by the IVC and right crus of diaphragm; superiorly by the caudate lobe; and inferiorly by the superior part of duodenum, portal triad.

eponym.name: Winterbottom's sign
eponym.desc: In West African trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness, caused by Trypanosoma brucei gambiense, humans primary reservoir), classic finding of posterior cervical triangle lymphadenopathy; described by Thomas Winterbottom who noted that slave traders in late 18th century used neck swelling as indicator of sleeping sickness in slaves.

eponym.name: Winter's formula
eponym.desc: Gives expected pCO2 from respiratory compensation in uncomplicated metabolic acidosis; expected CO2=[HCO3]*1.54 + 8.36.

eponym.name: Wintrobe indices
eponym.desc: Mean cell volume; mean cell hemoglobin; mean cell hemoglobin concentration.

eponym.name: Wirsung, duct of
eponym.desc: Duct embryologically confined to the ventral pancreas, becomes functionally the main pancreatic duct after duct fusion occurs. Drains the bulk of pancreatic secretion through the major papilla.

eponym.name: Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome
eponym.desc: X-linked characterized by triad of eczema, thrombocytopenia (from autoantibodies), and repeated infections; small platelets (3-5 fL); failure to express sialic acid-rich glycoprotein, sialophorin or CD15. Treatment primarily supportive and can include hematopoietic stem cell transplant. Due to mutation in WASP gene.

eponym.name: Wohlfart-Kugelberg-Welander disease
eponym.desc: Spinal muscular atrophy type III, presents in late childhood, runs a slow, indolent course, weakness greatest in proximal muscles, autosomal recessive or autosomal dominant, survival motor neuron protein affected.

eponym.name: Wolff-Chaikoff effect
eponym.desc: When increasing doses of iodide inhibit organification and hormonogenesis of thyroid hormone.

eponym.name: Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome
eponym.desc: Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia caused by conduction through abnormal accessory bypass tract (bundle of Kent) between atria and ventricles characterized by triad of (1) wide QRS complex, (2) relatively short PR interval, and (3) slurring of initial part of QRS delta wave; in familial WPW, associated with mutation in gamma2 regulatory subunit of AMP-activated protein kinase (PRKAG2).

eponym.name: Wolf-Hirschhorn syndrome
eponym.desc: Deletion 4p syndrome, from de novo deletion of 4p16.3 to 4pter; associated with growth and mental deficiency, seizure disorder, prominent glabella, among other features.

eponym.name: Wolfram syndrome
eponym.desc: Diabetes insipidus and mellitus with optic atrophy and deafness, also referred to as DIDMOAD; diabetes is non-autoimmune; caused by mutation in gene encoding wolframin.

eponym.name: Wollfian duct
eponym.desc: In male embryonic development, duct that gives rise to epididymis, vasa deferentia, seminal vesicles, and ejaculatory ducts.

eponym.name: Wolman disease
eponym.desc: Lysosomal storage disease. Autosomal recessive, from lysosomal acid lipase deficiency, resulting in impaired hydrolysis of cholesteryl esters and triglycerides in the lysosome leading to mild mental retardation, hepatomegaly, adrenal calcification, fatal in infancy with inanition, malabsorption, and intractable diarrhea.

eponym.name: Woodruff's plexus
eponym.desc: Site for posterior epistaxis; made up of anastamoses between branches of the internal maxillary artery; located where the sphenopalatine artery enters the nasal cavity through the sphenopalatine foramen at the posterior limit of the middle turbinate.

eponym.name: Wood's lamp
eponym.desc: Lamp that emits UV light.

eponym.name: Wood's maneuver
eponym.desc: In management of shoulder dystocia, rotating posterior shoulder 180 degrees.

eponym.name: Woolf's syndrome
eponym.desc: Autosomal dominant syndrome with albinismus circumscriptus and deaf-mutism without other features of Waardenburg's syndrome.

eponym.name: Word catheter
eponym.desc: A catheter with an inflatable balloon tip used for draining cysts, e.g. Bartholin gland abscesses; described by Word in 1968.

eponym.name: Woronets trait
eponym.desc: Autosomal dominantly-inherited trait characterized by small population of markedly distorted red blood cells resembling keratocytes; normal RBC life span.

eponym.name: Wright's maneuver
eponym.desc: In thoracic outlet obstruction: evaluating the radial pulse at the wrist with the shoulder in external rotation and abduction, positive sign if it reproduces shoulder and arm symptoms and obliterates radial pulse.

eponym.name: Wright's stain
eponym.desc: Stain used for blood and bone marrow films.

eponym.name: Wrisberg's ligament
eponym.desc: Posterior meniscofemoral ligament.

eponym.name: Wunderlich's syndrome
eponym.desc: Spontaneous renal bleeding of non-traumatic origin, confined to the subcapsular and perirenal space.

eponym.name: Wyburn-Mason syndrome
eponym.desc: Arteriovenous malformations in both the central nervous system and the retina; also known as Bonnet-Dechaume-Blanc syndrome.

eponym.name: Yergason's sign
eponym.desc: In biceps tendinitis or shoulder impingement, worsening of pain with resisted supination while the elbow is flexed to 90 degrees, arm adducted.

eponym.name: Young's syndrome
eponym.desc: Clinical features similar to cystic fibrosis, including bronchiectasis, sinusitis, and obstructive azoospermia. However, does not have increased sweat chloride values, nor pancreatic insufficiency, nor abnormal nasal potential differences, nor the CF delta F508 mutation. Affected individuals are often middle-aged males identified during evaluation for infertility.

eponym.name: Yuzpe regimen
eponym.desc: Postcoital contraception with ethinyl estradiol 100 mcg and levonorgestrel 0.5 mg taken twice, 12 hours apart; reduces number of anticipated pregnancies by 75-80%. Described by Canadian Yuzpe in 1974.

eponym.name: Zahn, infarct of
eponym.desc: In occlusion of an intrahepatic branch of portal vein, sharply demarcated area of red-blue discoloration, not infarct, not necrosis, only marked stasis in distended sinusoids, with secondary hepatocellular atrophy.

eponym.name: Zahn, lines of
eponym.desc: Thrombi formed within a cardiac chamber or the aorta, may have apparent laminations, produced by alternating layers of paler platelets admixed with some fibrin, separated by darker layers containing more red cells.

eponym.name: Zavanelli maneuver
eponym.desc: For management of shoulder dystocia, cephalic replacement of infant followed by caesarian delivery.

eponym.name: Zellweger syndrome
eponym.desc: Disorder of peroxisomes characterized by the congenital absence of functioning peroxisomes resulting in a cerebrohepatorenal syndrome; associated with prenatal development problems, hepatomegaly, increased serum iron and copper, visual disturbances; generally fatal by 1 year; caused by mutations in genes involved in peroxisome biogenesis (PEX genes).

eponym.name: Zenker's diverticulum
eponym.desc: A pharyngeal diverticulum from premature contraction of the cricopharyngeus muscle on swallowing, leads to progressive UES narrowing, leading to a posteriorly directed hypopharynx; causes progressive food stasis and dysphagia.

eponym.name: Zieve's syndrome
eponym.desc: Jaundice, hyperlipemia, and hemolytic anemia in alcoholic liver disease; described in 1958.

eponym.name: Zinn, annulus of
eponym.desc: Ring of fibrous tissue that surrounds the optic foramen, where the optic nerve enters at the apex of the orbit. Serves as the origin of five of the six extraocular muscles.

eponym.name: Zollinger-Ellison syndrome
eponym.desc: Circulating hypergastrinemia seen in gastrinoma. Associated with gastric acid hypersecretion and severe peptic ulcer diathesis. Associated with peptic ulcers and diarrhea; 60% malignant, only 20% resectable; 25% of gastrinoma patients have multiple endocrine neoplasia type I; >80% of gastrinomas found in gastrinoma triangle.

eponym.name: Zoon's balanitis
eponym.desc: Plasma cell balanitis (also known as balanitis circumscripta plasmacellularis), idiopathic, rare, benign, penile dermatosis with plasma cell infiltration; treated with circumcision; described in 1952.

eponym.name: Zuckerkandl, organ of
eponym.desc: Collection of para-aortic, paraganglion cells around the origin of the inferior mesenteric artery; a site where extra-adrenal pheochromocytomas may arise.

eponym.name: Zuckerkandl, tubercle of
eponym.desc: Part of thyroid that tracts posterior to the sides of the trachea and esophagus; found in nearly 2/3 of patients undergoing thyroid surgery, usually enlarges lateral to recurrent laryngeal nerve; described in 1902.
